HEADLINE: Q&A/ADVOCACY; 
The Case for 2 Approaches

BYLINE:  By NANCY WARTIK

 BODY:
It has long been a truism in philanthropy that service programs are financed more readily than so-called advocacy programs.
 The Meyer Foundation, endowed in 1944 by the Washington Post publisher Eugene Meyer and his wife, Agnes E., to invest in the greater D.C. area, is an exception to the rule. In September, when the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy issued a report based on asking 118 advocacy groups in the Washington region to name their most reliable source of funds, the Meyer Foundation was far above the crowd. 
 "Many foundations are controversy-shy and risk-averse," said Rick Cohen, the executive director of the N.C.R.P. "They don't like sticking their neck out."
Julie Rogers, 53, has been the Meyer Fund's executive director for 17 years. She says that her early experience as a teacher informs her belief that dollars go further when they are used to help change the system. "When you teach one child at a time, you can't get families what they need to ensure a child's success," she said. "You can't get that kid a doctor's appointment or mom more money for food. You're just one piece of a very complicated equation." 
Recently, Ms. Rogers spoke about the philosophies that guide her foundation's grant-making decisions:

How do you define advocacy?
Sometimes advocacy means bringing people together to create a voice for themselves around issues that matter to them. Sometimes it means coalition building, like gathering all the agencies in your region that work with Latino people. Sometimes it means data analysis, strategizing and actually lobbying and going to work with government officials on specific legislation. The broadest piece is how do you create and sustain a voice for the population you're working with. For us, advocacy means giving a voice.

Is financing nonprofits that do advocacy work particularly important right now?
These times are so difficult for poor people as the income gap gets more acute and for nonprofits as they face lots of different financial pressures. Our grantees are facing a higher demand for service because the economy's been down at the same time as almost all their revenue streams are down. Most states are having longterm revenue issues that won't be resolved soon. We have always funded service and advocacy, but I think we're feeling it's even more important now to fund the advocacy groups because the public policy issues that matter so much in the lives of clients of our grantees are big ones. 

Statistics suggest maybe only 2 to 3 percent of the $30 billion or so that American foundations give out each year goes to support advocacy activities. Why such a small percentage?
A lot of the charitable world supports work on the ground that helps people. Feeds, clothes, shelters, houses them. You have to think about this work a little differently to also want to fund the creation of a voice for poor people. Some people see it as either/or. We see it as you've got to do both: direct service and advocacy. If you do that, you will get greater outcome because it's synergistic.
We fund a lot of nonprofits that deliver health care services to poor families: Mary's Center for Maternal and Child Care. The Washington Free Clinic. La Clinica del Pueblo. When the District of Columbia decided to change to a managed care system for its Medicaid population in 1996, all the clinics faced a new way of doing business. It was a big change that meant that clinics serving 60 percent of the city's poor patients might no longer be reimbursed for their services. So we helped those organizations form a coalition, the DC Primary Care Association.
We made a small grant that got them organized and then we continued to fund the coalition. They argued successfully for better coverage with D.C. public health officials, and they got their own reimbursement rate raised from $35 to $65 a visit. That has made it possible for this group of clinics to serve an additional 13,000 children and families and 4,000 adults. 

Is it actually harder to finance advocacy from a regulatory point of view?
I don't think it's really harder. We don't sit here worrying intensely about it. There is a body of I.R.S. regulation around what nonprofits can do and what foundations can fund that is very understandable. The onus is on the groups we support to know the rules. If you're going to fund a soup kitchen versus funding organizing and people who are collecting data, developing positions and eventually planning to lobby the city council, it may seem a little more complex.
People, I think, get hesitant. It is true that probably some part of advocates' agendas will include working with government officials and legislatures, though it is certainly not everything they do.

Do you sense that some of your colleagues, other heads of foundations, are starting to think more in terms of financing advocacy?
I don't have any empirical data, but among many very thoughtful funders there is renewed interest in working with advocacy organizations. The pressures that are on poor people and the providers of services have created a sort of a wake-up call to some funders that they also need to pay attention to creating a voice. Again, using an example from my region, after 9/11 and the attacks on the Pentagon, a lot of low-wage workers in hotel and airline industries lost their jobs. Tourism had declined. We had a magnificent gift that Meyer helped broker from the Ford Foundation, and we created a pooled fund called the Community Capacity Fund that was run by a regional association, the Washington Grantmakers. We had money from Ford and several other sources.
We regranted those dollars by putting a bunch of really smart program people from foundations in our region on a committee. And I think the work the committee was doing on issues like the displaced workers rekindled everybody's interest in advocacy for safety net programs. It just broughtto the foreground again how vulnerable those families were. How narrow the margin is for the working poor in our region. Even though the project is now over, there is a group of funders and advocates still meeting to try to figure out how we could strengthen the capacity of advocacy groups in the region. 

Is that a healthy trend? Do you want to see more people doing it the way Meyer does it?
I'm torn between saying more people should do what we do and another part of me that says it is O.K. for different foundations and givers to come at this with their own perspectives. There's a lot of money coming into this territory. Families are inheriting wealth, people are setting up their philanthropic vehicles. We are often approached by families, other foundations who sometimes seek advice. And every family looks at this differently, based on their own politics, religion, how they want to do their charity. People have different views on what they see the community's needs as, and how they want to make a difference. Some people just want to do direct service. So I think that the way Meyer approaches this, and some of our other colleagues, too, is smart and strategic. But I also think philanthropy has room for all different styles. Like a quilt.

HEADLINE: OVERSEAS; 
Take Books, Add Food, Watch the World Change

BYLINE:  By DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER

 BODY:
MOHAMMED ADOW, a 28-year-old Somali journalist with the BBC World Service in London, attended primary school in Garissa, a dry, dusty region in Kenya. The school was poor, but students received meals through an international school feeding program.
 "The food was not good," he said. "Just beans and maize, with a lot of maize and very few beans, cooked in a big pot. But when I look back on it, it used to be delicious." 
 Basic education is one of the most far-reaching single investments that can improve the economies and foster the emergence of literate, self-reliant societies in the developing world. And when meals are offered in schools, enrollment and attendance rates increase significantly, as a student's ability to concentrate and learn is generally sharply improved.
In poor societies, the ramifications of this simple formula are more clear-cut and wide-ranging than in the developed world. In the last several years they have fostered a minor renaissance in the culture of humanitarian aid.
Aid organizations have become increasingly mindful of the fact that by feeding a child in school, they address not only short-term hunger but some of the societal ills that allow it to endure. In 2001, with a $124 million contribution from the United States Government, the World Food Program of the United Nations tried to reach more schoolchildren.
In 2000, the agency provided daily meals to 12.3 million pupils in 54 countries; this year, the agency says more than 15.6 million children in 70 countries will receive the meals.
"If you feed children, they come to school and they stay in school and they learn better," said Arlene Mitchell, who heads the agency's School Feeding Program.
Some charities have supported schoolfeeding programs for decades. But the school meal programs fell out of fashion in the 1990's, Ms. Mitchell said. Interest was revived with the McGovern-Dole global food initiative, a two-year pilot program approved by President Bill Clinton in 2000 with $300 million in financing.
The program, which provides American farm surpluses for school feeding programs in developing countries, was made permanent by the Bush administration in 2002. But Congress may cut funds to about a quarter of 2001 levels in the budget process.
The United States Government is by far the greatest contributor to the World Food Program. The agency, based in Rome, has an annual budget of $1.9 billion and is financed by donations, almost all from governments, although it is trying to get more help from private sources and institutions. The agency says it costs $34 a year to feed a child in school, or 19 cents a day.
School feeding programs tend to operate in desolate areas where enrollments are low and a nutritious meal has the biggest impact. The greatest beneficiary by far in 2002 was North Korea, followed by Kenya, India, Bangladesh and Cuba.
The programs hope to overcome the kind of hunger that is generally associated with poor diet and poverty rather than with famine. When possible, fortified foods are used to counter deficiencies and help school performance. Iodine is usually added to salt, and oils are fortified with vitamin A.
School meals usually consist of a fortified cereal-based drink and simple gruel or fortified biscuits, prepared by parents or paid cooks in canteens. When possible, the foods are familiar to the region -- couscous in Niger, for instance, or pumpkin porridge in North Korea.
Every attempt ismade to serve a meal early in the school day, when children's energy levels are lowest. "Internationally, many kids have to walk kilometers and kilometers just to get to school, so they start out with no energy and reduce it even more," Ms. Mitchell said. "Your chances of having their attention and good behavior are really limited. They literally fall asleep from lack of energy."
A Unicef study completed this year found that of the world's 300 million chronically hungry children, 134 million do not attend school. School meals add nutrition and savings to the family food budget. Research by the World Food Program has shown that when schools provide a meal, enrollments can double in a year.
In many poor countries, parents depend on children to work in the fields, care for siblings and search for food. Some programs try to compensate by providing take-home rations or cooking oil for the child's family. In some instances, families are allowed to sell these additional rations.
This strategy has been successful where poverty and tribal or cultural traditions keep girls out of school. Two out of three children who do not attend primary school are girls, and many meal programs are designed to narrow this gap.
"To encourage attendance by girls or other hard-to-reach groups, we use take-home rations for good attendance," Ms. Mitchell said. "In Pakistan, for example, if a girl attends school 20 days a month she gets food to take home to her family."
Girls who attend school tend to marry later and have fewer children, the food experts say. Educated mothers are more likely to contribute to family income, are better able to manage the food supply and are more likely to educate their daughters.
School feeding is not without pitfalls. Some students do not improve because parents cut back on meals served at home. Storage and transportation are complex, and mealtimes vary greatly from country to country. Teachers may be forced to take time out to prepare and serve meals.
Most important, a transition strategy must be put in place to help the community take over school feeding when the local World Food Program has run its course, usually about five years in the least-developed countries. More than 12 countries, including Brazil, Namibia and Swaziland, have taken over school feeding from the World Food Program in recent years.
"You go in, you show the benefit to the community, you get them involved in the process, and eventually you're trying to see how they can take over the program," said Trudy Bower, the director for the World Food Program in Ghana. "That's our strategy. Aid does not become endless."

Combining Hunger Programs and Education

HEADLINE: IN THE CHURCHES; 
For Boston's Archdiocese, An Appeal Is Rebranded

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
FOR nearly two decades, Cardinal Bernard F. Law was the face of the annual Cardinal's Appeal, the primary fund-raising drive for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston. A letter from the popular archbishop, featuring his photograph, was enough to attract significant donations.
 Then Cardinal Law became associated with the sexual abuse scandals that rocked the archdiocese and forced his resignation last December amid allegations that he had tolerated the abuse of children by priests under his supervision. Furious at Cardinal Law and other church leaders, many Boston Catholics boycotted the Cardinal's Appeal, and some pastors refused to take part. The archdiocese staff that handles the appeal culled mailing lists as more people said they would not pledge. The Cardinal's Appeal scraped in $8.9 million last year, a drop from the $16.2 million raised in 2001. 
 In the words of Damien J. DeVasto, the director of the appeal, there has been a rebranding: the name has been changed from the Cardinal's Appeal to the Annual Catholic Appeal (a title that is also used by several other cities for their yearly diocesan appeals). This year's fund-raising letters, which were sent out beginning in April, feature photos of parochial school students and other laypeople, not the archbishop of Boston. And a new slogan, "one church, many works," highlights the 80 programs and ministries that benefit from the appeal.
This new approach signals a departure from the old one, which Mr. DeVasto described as "steeped in hierarchy." The personality-centered campaign was not suited to realities in the church, nor did it reflect the image of the new archbishop, Sean P. O'Malley, a Capuchin Franciscan who wears the order's simple brown robe.
Although it is still far below the levels of two years ago, this year's appeal has reached $8.2 million so far, which is 10 to 20 percent more than last year's contributions at this time, and is expected to reach the $9 million goal. (As of 2001, there were about 2.1 million Catholics in the archdiocese.)
How much is attributable to the new marketing campaign is hard to say. About a third of this year's donors did not give last year, Mr. DeVasto said. He attributes most of the gains to positive feelings about Archbishop O'Malley, who was appointed by Pope John Paul II on July 1, 2003. Two months after the appointment, Mr. DeVasto said, the appeal raised about $1 million. And Archbishop O'Malley's decision in September to settle almost 550 lawsuits over sexual abuse by priests is likely to be received favorably by donors.
"He's been totally positive," said Fred O'Neill, referring to Archbishop O'Malley. Mr. O'Neill, a Catholic, lives in Duxbury and is a senior vice president of the Suffolk Construction Company in Boston. He stopped donating to the archdiocese last year, but said he was giving again because he was impressed with the archbishop's sincerity, straightforwardness and ability to "tell it like it is."
Mr. DeVasto hoped that the appeal, which finances more than 50 percent of the archdiocese's operating expenses, can reach its pre-scandal levels in a relatively short time. "We're hopeful that over a three-year period, we'll find our way back," he said. 
Not all Boston Catholics have returned to the flock, though, and many say they want to see more changes before they commit to opening their wallets. James E. Post, the president of Voice of the Faithful, a local group that seeks church reform, wants the archdiocese to publicize how the appeal money will be spent. 
"I cannot see how to contribute to a diocesan or archdiocesan campaign without a clear understanding of where that money is going to go and how it is going to be used, and I know I am not alone in that," Mr. Post said. "The trust that was shattered doesn't come back as if by magic."
Dr. Charles E. Zech, a professor of economics at Villanova University in Villanova, Pa., who studies Catholic giving, said he expected that financial accountability would continue to be an issue. When the scandal first began, Dr. Zech said, major Catholic donors tended to be loyal to the church and did not cut off their sponsorship, but those donors may demand more now. "There is some evidence, Dr. Zech said, "that major donors are really worried about where their money goes." 
Some religious charities have rebounded from overwhelming scandals, said Francis J. Butler, the president of Foundations and Donors Interested in Catholic Activities, a group of family foundations in Washington. Mr. Butler said that few people expected Covenant House, the child welfare agency in New York, to survive after its founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, resigned in 1990 amid allegations of sexual and financial misconduct, leaving the organization $38 million in debt. But under its new president, Sister Mary Rose McGeady, the charity regained 80 percent of its donors within three years. 
"What's operative here is people's faith," Mr. Butler said. "They want this institution to work."
Boston Catholics seem willing to give to Catholic organizations besides the archdiocese. Boston Catholic Television held its most successful telethon ever this fall, and the Blessed John XXIII National Seminary in Weston had a record-breaking fund-raiser too. Although some parishes are still behind on their weekly collections, others have surpassed their 2001 totals.
The Rev. Robert Bullock, the pastor of Our Lady of Sorrows in Sharon, a Boston suburb, said he campaigned for the appeal this year, but understood why other donors might hold back.
"There is going to be a very strong wait-and-see attitude," he said. "The only voice they have is a financial one, and they are making their voice heard."

HEADLINE: VOLUNTEERING; 
Plattsburg's Favorite Phrases? 'Stop By' and 'Pitch In'

BYLINE:  By ANNA BAHNEY

DATELINE: PLATTSBURG, Mo. 

 BODY:
AT 11:30 a.m., Helen Russell, a petite 78-year-old, left the genealogy library office at the Courtyard Community Center, where she volunteers every Monday. As she walked briskly down Main Street toward the Plattsburg Senior Center for lunch, she pointed at one of the many flowerpots on the sidewalk. 
 "These are another thing done by volunteers," Mrs. Russell said, explaining how her town of 2,300 -- and others like it --gets things done. 
 The plantings -- courtesy of the high school's FFA (formerly the Future Farmers of America) chapter, its agricultural education department and the Master Gardeners -- are among the civic services and amenities that Plattsburg has because of its residents' unpaid support. Firefighters and reserve deputy sheriffs are volunteers; the mayor and the six councilmembers are essentially volunteer positions, with a stipend of $600 and $300 each year. 
Volunteers stock the food pantry, tutor children and pick up litter. They also delivered 25,000 meals to shut-ins and helped serve them at the Senior Center last year and renovated a 19th-century livery stable (most recently used as a roller skate factory) into a community center.
Yet, the word "volunteerism" is not big in Plattsburg, 35 miles north of Kansas City, Mo., and the seat of Clinton County. In this town, people sign up for traditional volunteer leadership roles like scout leader or choir director, but they are just as likely to "pitch in," "stop by" or "bring a pie." (Mrs. Russell's pecan pies are a staple at the numerous fund-raisers, fairs and funeral dinners for which she bakes every year.)
"We don't preach the gospel of volunteering," said Dr. Jim Hobbs, 60, a dentist who is the president of the board that worked 10 years to transform donations of money, time and labor into the community center. Instead, Dr. Hobbs said, "you appeal to people's sense of civic pride and the value of the impact of the project. And the fact that unless someone offers to do it, it will never get done." 
Scholars have a name for that kind of pitching in: "helping behavior." Peter Dobkin Hall, the Hauser Lecturer on Nonprofit Organizations at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, called it a fading element in American culture, "because physical proximity doesn't define community anymore, except if you live in a small town."
When people volunteer in the context of their profession, for instance, they tend to feel that their responsibility -- and the help they can get -- is limited to that role, Mr. Hall said. It is not the same understanding created by the interconnectivity of a small town, in which neighbors are members in a community that includes school, work, church and governance. Like Plattsburg. 
But Mrs. Russell saw nothing extraordinary in the townspeople's involvement. "I don't think that Plattsburg is unusual," she said. "Of course, I haven't lived anyplace else." 
This particular week, Mrs. Russell, who was the town's circuit clerk and ex officio recorder of dates for 39 years before retiring in 1990, stopped by the Senior Center, taught Sunday school, helped a worship service at a nursing home, met with the United Methodist Women and made crafts for a bazaar. Monthly, she attends board meetings at the Senior Center, and every few months she goes to meetings at the Clinton County Historical Society and the Plattsburg High School Alumni Association. 
Then there are things she does that are not related to any organization, like taking 98-year-old Halkaline Bergsten to St. Joseph, 30 miles northwest, to get new glasses. 
"Maybe she might need a light bulb changed that she can't reach," Mrs. Russell said. "So you get up on the ladder. She'll call me to take her to the beauty shop. Someone picks her up to take her to church. A lady takes her to the grocery store. She has people that take care of her all the time." 
Mrs. Russell also handles research requests and compiles documents at her genealogy library, a branch of the historical society. In her roles at the library and as founder of the alumni association, she has collected most senior class pictures from 1907 to 1947 and enlarged them to hang in the high school. On this day, she brought a picture of the class of 1939 to the Senior Center for Leon Montgomery, an 83-year-old volunteer there, who was 18 in the photograph. "We come by here, oh, about five times a week," Mr. Montgomery said as he put menus into envelopes to go out with deliveries to the shut-ins. 
Joyce Ketchem, 72, who was a waitress at the Starlite restaurant in nearby Stewartsville for 25 years and now lives in Plattsburg, also volunteers at the center. "I do anything they ask me to do," she said. "I sack lunches. Wipe the tables. If people are not able to go get their lunch, why, I go and get it for them.
"It's a nice town to live in. The people are friendly. And where else can you go and get a free cup of coffee at a filling station? Right here at Larry's One Stop." 
While for some, life in Plattsburg may sound as fictional as in Lake Wobegon, the mayor, John Huffman, insists that pitching in is "just something you do. It's part of living in the Midwest. It's the culture." 
There are downsides to a small community that is not off a major highway. Mr. Huffman, 63, who owns a bed-and-breakfast and an antiques store, said that Plattsburg's largest problem was slow economic growth. With 12 percent of the population living below the poverty line, according to the 2000 census, and more people commuting to Kansas City or St. Joseph for jobs, the economic troubles in Plattsburg are evident.
But, Mr. Huffman said, people "may cut back on buying an antique. They may decide to not buy a car for an extra year. But you don't see a decline in donations of time, labor and effort."
Mickey Streeter, 51, the city clerk, handles the registration and finances for the Christmas Family Project, which is an adopt-a-family program, and the Mayor's Christmas Tree Fund, which gives hams and turkeys to needy families. Neither is part of her job. "I'm in an office that people frequent," Mrs. Streeter said. "So I'm happy to do it." 
Other things occur at her office that happen only in small towns. "Every year at Christmas time," Mrs. Streeter said, "I have a couple of elderly people who come in and ask if anyone needs help with their utility bills. We do gas and utility here, therefore I know who is behind on their bills."
Mrs. Streeter knows both sides of gifts like these. She said that when her husband died of cancer 16 years ago, leaving her with two young children and dizzying bills, "the community did so much for me. They had chili suppers, spaghetti dinners and fund-raisers to help us with medical expenses. So while I can't always financially help people, I can do this." 
Not all volunteer endeavors have worked. Mrs. Russell said she tried to organize a program at her Methodist church called People Helping People, which had been successful in other towns. In the program, a group of people donates talents and services. For example, if someone needs an electrician, a coordinator will see that the service is provided. 
"Well, it didn't go over," Mrs. Russell said, laughing. "The reason was, everybody was already doing all that." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: TIME FOR OTHERS -- Helen Russell, far left, with Joyce Tollman at the senior center in Plattsburg, Mo. (Photo by Reed Hoffmann for The New York Times) Map of Missouri shows the location of Plattsburg.

ORGANIZATION: NATIONAL FFA ORGANIZATION (57%)

HEADLINE: Exploring New Ideas for Making Finances Clearer and Scandals Rarer 

BYLINE:  By JON CHRISTENSEN

 BODY:
EVERYWHERE you turn in the world of philanthropy and nonprofits these days, people are talking about accountability. And it's no wonder. 
 "Public humiliation is quite a motivator," said Kathleen P. Enright, the executive director of Grantmakers for Effective Organizations, at a recent gathering of nonprofit groups and foundations. A chief executive of a major national foundation, Ms. Enright added, had given her that nugget of wisdom. 
 A rash of embarrassing news emanating from the nonprofit world was much on the minds of foundation and nonprofit executives earlier this month at the annual conference of Independent Sector, an industry group that includes 700 foundations and nonprofit organizations among its members.
As part of this industry soul-searching and housecleaning, Independent Sector circulated a draft code of ethics for nonprofit and philanthropic organizations. The code counsels a straight and narrow path through the familiar shoals of ethical misconduct in charities, including lapses in personal and professional integrity, straying from the mission, dishonesty in fund-raising, conflicts of interest among staff members and boards, outlandish executive compensation and mismanagement of financial resources. 
But the code also adds something new: measuring effectiveness. It calls on nonprofits to regularly review their programs and learn from the results. According to many in the industry, that opens up a whole new scope for accountability: judging nonprofits not just by the standards of traditional ethics codes, but also by their results, just like a business. 
But in a survey presented at the conference, Jed Emerson, a senior fellow at the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, and a colleague, Sheila Bonini, found "little consensus on how best to approach the creation of a single, commonly endorsed set of metrics" that can assess the performance on nonfinancial aspects of organizations and funds. 
One of the most promising attempts they discovered was emerging not in the United States, where relatively well-off nonprofit groups and foundations have been debating how to measure their work for many years, but from development work in poorer countries elsewhere. 
A London partnership called Access is beginning to test a global reporting system for nonprofit organizations among a wide variety of groups from India to South Africa to Latin America. The effort is the idea of David Bonbright, the director for civil society programs at the Aga Khan Foundation, the nondenominational international development agency, and Simon Zadek, the chief executive of AccountAbility, a pioneer promoter of standards for businesses to report on corporate social responsibility. 
Their goal is to create a system that will provide credible information about the past performance of NGO's that will allow donors to make plausible predictions about future performances, the kind of credibility that generally accepted accounting principles are supposed to ensure for financial investors in the stock market. Their guiding philosophy is that open, reliable accountability is the only way to increase the market share of global giving that goes to solving important problems in developing countries. 
Currently, only $12 billion to $17 billion of total charitable donations of $240 billion a year in the United States is sent overseas, Mr. Bonbright said.
The Access system provides nonprofit organizations with a standard database in which to report on their governance, finances, management systems, strategies and results of their work, with any external audits of their reports. 
"It's pretty straightforward stuff," Mr. Bonbright said. 
The Nelson Mandela Foundation, one of the first to test the system, is gearing up to use Access to evaluate the effectiveness of projects helping H.I.V./AIDS patients in rural South Africa. John Samuel, the foundation's chief executive, said the foundation, like many, had conducted evaluations of its programs. But Access will help his staff and the groups they work with to understand more quickly the relative impacts of various approaches, ranging from simple educational efforts to support groups and treatment centers. 
"It frees you from the imprisonment of historical evaluation," Mr. Samuel said. "It's not just looking backward, it's looking forward. And being able to predict challenges and difficulties is often more important than what you've done."
The Inter-American Foundation plans to use Access for more than 330 grant recipients supported by a network of 40 corporate foundations across Latin America. These foundations play an increasingly important role in grass-roots work, said Walter Price, the director for corporate outreach at Inter-American.
But they all measure their results in different ways. "You can't add up what people are doing," he said. "They can't communicate with each other. And they can't communicate with the world." 
Mr. Bonbright said that previous attempts to create rating systems for NGO's have foundered on deep-seated suspicions about imposing standards in a field that prides itself on diversity and creativity. 
"There's a kind of historical self-righteousness that sits in nonprofits," he said. " 'We're doing God's workor we're doing good work. So help us!' As soon as you misstep, they say: 'Aha! That's what it's really about. It's an attempt to fit us into a straitjacket.' "
Here in the United States, Grantmakers for Effective Organizations has encountered some of the same skepticism. The group was formed in 1997 as an informal caucus in which foundation people could share ideas about "how we can help nonprofits perform better," Ms. Enright said. "They wisely realized they didn't have a lot of credibility if they didn't look at their own performance."

HEADLINE: ACCOUNTABILITY; 
They're Mad as Hell, and They're Not Making Donations Anymore

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
ROBERT FORD and Ihor Belinsky believe they do their social good on their jobs -- investigating inequities and complaints for the federal Department of Education's Philadelphia office. They used to give outside the office, too, by donating to charities.
 Mr. Ford gave a substantial sum to his church and smaller checks here and there to charities. But when he got divorced several years ago, his habits changed. 
 "The church was my wife's place, so that stopped," he said. "And since I was no longer itemizing deductions, the other donations were no longer write-offs, so I cut back there." With a daughter going to college, he also needed to save.
But for Mr. Belinsky, his cutbacks were a measure of trust, or the lack of it.
"There were these scandals in charities and I was using the write-off at work to contribute," he said. "I decided to investigate whether my money was going to the right place and doing what I wanted, and I just wasn't assured, so I stopped."
Charities and other nonprofit agencies depend on repeat givers for a substantial part of their financial base. But lately, many fund-raisers say, the number of those donors who has fallen off the wagon appears to be growing. 
"There are lots of reasons people stop giving, and they get really heightened in these times," said Kae Dakin, the president of Washington Grantmakers, a clearinghouse for donations to nonprofits. "Since 9/11 and the stock-market downturn, especially in Washington and New York, people have been turned off. 
"There have been scandals at some nonprofits and the big confusion with the American Red Cross about where monies for 9/11 victims would go," Ms. Dakin continued. "And people are scared. They either don't have the money or they are worried about losing their jobs, or their stock portfolios have gone belly-up. So they just stop giving."
In some cases, the money flow stops because of a dispute over policy. The United Way of Southeastern Pennsylvania this year decided to stop financing an inner-city Boy Scout program after the Boy Scouts announced they would not allow homosexuals to be scout leaders. "I don't know how long we have been funding that program, but surely at least 15 or 20 years," said Edward A. Montgomery Jr., vice president for relationship management at the regional United Way. "We have a policy that we don't discriminate, and that goes for sexual orientation."
The policy may have caused the United Way group to lose donors, Mr. Montgomery said, "but you have to be responsible to your goals." 
At Carleton College in Minnesota, officials realized that some alumni might be angered by the school's choice of President Bill Clinton as commencement speaker in 2001.
It upset Thom Gunderson, who had given to the Carleton Alumni Annual fund nearly every year since he graduated in 1972. The sexual scandal that embroiled Mr. Clinton offended Mr. Gunderson, who thought he was not appropriate for the occasion. And his anger about Mr. Clinton started him thinking about other issues at his alma mater.
Carleton has lost nearly a quarter of its endowment in shrinking stock investments. "Unlike other colleges, Carleton decided to run with the bulls and lost a quarter-billion dollars," said Mr. Gunderson, who is a stock analyst for US Bancorp Piper Jaffray in Minneapolis. "Clinton got me going and the quarter-billion clinched it. So I am taking a sabbatical from contributions."
Christopher Clark, the director of the alumni fund, understands the frustration. It is his job to woo back people like Mr. Gunderson.
"A generation ago, a lot of people stopped giving when dormitories went co-ed," he said. "Some stopped because of the Clinton speech. But when you lose someone, you try to reconnect them with classmates and other things they felt good about when they were here. You acknowledge their problem with you and then you do your best personally to get them back."
Nancy Raybin, the president of Raybin Associates, a New York consulting firm for nonprofit groups, said that it was often "the little things" that led to donor dropouts. "The biggest thing can be that a donor hasn't been paid attention to," Ms. Raybin said. "They are called too many times. Maybe an acknowledgment letter spells their name wrong. 'Maybe they don't care about me,' is what they think, and maybe they are right. Donors of $1,000 or $100 can get just as angry as those who give $100,000. A good development staff takes note of these people, too."
For Dr. Hetty Hall of Iowa City, it was too many phone calls. Dr. Hall said she knew all about the good things that Amnesty International did and was happy to give a few hundred dollars to an organization that shared her views.
"But then they started calling and calling," Dr. Hall said. "We might have given $200 one year and now they wanted $500. Then they called and asked for $250. And they called again. I just finally told them to forget it and haven't given again."
Global Impact, a federation of international development organizations, coordinates the Combined Federal Campaign, the salary check-off system for the 330,000 federal employees around Washington. Anthony DeCristofaro, a spokesman, said that participation was about 60 percent among workers in the mid-1990's but down to 43 percent this year.
"I think after you have publicized scandals or economic downturns, you have to do a better job of getting donors back connected with something," Mr. DeCristofaro said. 
William H. Gray III has done a lot of wooing of donors in the last several decades, first as a Congressman from Pennsylvania and now as the president and chief executive of the United Negro College Fund. Mr. Gray said it was difficult to get people to contribute in the first place, but is even harder after they have stopped.
"Sometimes people are just mad at you," he said. "They had a bad experience with someone on your staff or they asked you to solicit them only once and you called them three times. You have to not just let it drop, but find out why they are mad at you. Then you learn to apologize and, more important, do not let it happen again."

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY DRIVES; 
Coats, Cans, Books, Toys, Quilts and More

BYLINE:  By SARA IVRY

 BODY:
 HOLIDAY charitable drives often call to mind drop boxes for canned goods or Santa-clad volunteers ringing bells for spare change on city streets. A little imagination, though, can go a long way to create a local tradition and raise donations for a variety of causes. Here is a roundup of some innovative drives:

ITEM: Books
SPONSOR: Book 'Em
PLACE: Nashville
THE STORY: Book 'Em, a nonprofit organization founded in 1989 to promote literacy among children, donates and distributes new and used books to 25,000 youngsters each year. Over the last eight years, the group has held a fund-raiser called the Emperor's New Clothes Gala Ball, an imaginary event that takes place on a make-believe date, Sept. 32, and has no invited guests. The "event" is a way to encourage donors to send money that would have been spent on a benefit ticket or a tuxedo. A month after the "ball," the organization sets up drop boxes for book donations at stores, churches, offices and schools. On average, they collect about 11,000 books a year. The group hopes to encourage children to read. "If you can't read, you can't do homework, you can't do anything," said Lee Fairbend, a co-founder of Book 'Em. "Even something as simple as how to turn the page in a book, you're not born knowing that."

ITEM: Blessing bag
SPONSOR: Bowery Mission
PLACE: New York City
THE STORY: Every Thanksgiving, the Bowery Mission, a charity that has been caring for alcoholic and derelict men since 1879, prepares about 130 turkeys, 1,500 pounds of potatoes and 80 gallons of gravy for the 1,800 dinners it offers the homeless at three sites in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. This year, mission guests will receive a "blessing bag," provided by the Boy Scouts of America, Atari, the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, church groups and holiday volunteers, with nonperishable food items, hats and gloves and toiletries. "Thanksgiving is our first introduction to a lot of our guests -- they're coming hungry and alone," said Glenn McKinney, the mission's development director. "Blessing bags may seem a little simple, but it's an opportunity to say, 'There's more here for you if you want it.' "

ITEM: Quilts
SPONSOR: Canyon Quilters
PLACE: San Diego
THE STORY: Last March, when Sandi Delman became the chairwoman of Canyon Quilters, a local guild, she had an agenda: to increase the number of quilts the group donates to Project Linus, a nonprofit organization in Bloomington, Ill., that has given away more than 650,000 quilts and blankets to sick or traumatized children in the United States and abroad. Since 2000, the guild has donated about 150 handmade quilts a year to Project Linus, named for the boy in the comic strip "Peanuts," who balked at the notion of giving up his security blanket. This year, Canyon Quilters will be sending more than 200 quilts, including some with Christmas patterns.

ITEM: Men's coats
SPONSOR: Hands on Charlotte
PLACE: Charlotte, N.C.
THE STORY: For the last decade, Hands on Charlotte, a nonprofit volunteer service founded in 1991, has held an annual coat drive. The drive, which begins Oct. 20 and ends on Thanksgiving, has collected nearly 40,000 coats since its inception. Roughly 100 local banks, businesses, churches and schools volunteer as drop points for donations. This year, the group has made a plea for men's coats, because men tend to buy fewer coats than women, said the organization's director, Rochelle Brown. And the city's homeless male population exceeds that of women and children.

ITEM: Decorated Christmas trees
SPONSOR: Hope House
PLACE: Fredericksburg, Va.
THE STORY: For the last six years, Hope House, a transitional home for women and children that offers long-term shelter for up to 13 families, has been the host of a silent auction called a Festival of Trees, which starts in late November and ends in early December. The items up for bid are professionally decorated wreaths and trees provided by businesses and clubs. Most of the trees are made of artificial materials and available in all sizes. Proceeds from the bids, which rise in five-dollar increments and do not exceed $300, subsidize expenses for the home. Last year's bidding netted $30,000 for 80 trees. So far this year, more than 80 items have been promised for the auction, which starts Nov. 25.

ITEM: Toys
SPONSOR: The Christmas Bureau
PLACE: Plattsburgh, N.Y.
THE STORY: Nine years ago, the Christmas Bureau, a volunteer service group that distributes toys to children at Christmas, changed its focus: it decided to provide new toys instead of refurbished ones. In the past, the old toys were repaired by inmates at two local prisons -- in Clinton, N.Y., and Altona, N.Y. But the shifted focus did not slow down that collaboration. Now, the inmates make new toys -- doll cribs, carriages and rocking horses -- from scratch. Their contribution is about a quarter of the gifts the bureau gives away each year to about 2,500 young residents of Clinton County, in northern New York State. The rest of the gifts are bought by the bureau with monetary donations or are in-kind donations from businesses, fraternal organizations and other groups, including bicycles that are refurbished year-round by one volunteer. In addition to toys, the bureau gives each family a voucher to buy food for a holiday meal.

ITEM: Gifts
SPONSOR: The Santa Claus Girls
PLACE: Grand Rapids, Mich.
THE STORY: In November 1908, Adriana Van Doorn, a Sunday-school teacher, organized nine women to start a gift-giving program for local children. Calling themselves the Santa Claus Girls, they collected donations totaling $199.01, which they used to create 473 gift packages containing fruit, clothes, candy, toys and books. Since then, the scope of the program has ballooned. Volunteers now raise more than $175,000 a year and give presents to more than 10,000 children countywide. The packages bear each child's name and contain the same items they did nearly a century ago -- minus the fruit -- for delivery the Saturday before Christmas. The volunteers, who include men, solicit names of children through a state agency.

ITEM: Nonperishable food
SPONSOR: America's Second Harvest of Wisconsin
PLACE: Milwaukee
THE STORY: Times are tough for domestic hunger-relief organizations. The sluggish economy has meant fewer corporate donations just when more people need help. America's Second Harvest of Wisconsin, the state's largest soup kitchen and food-bank distributor, has also seen a decline. Founded in 1982, it serves an estimated 300,000 people daily in 36 counties. In anticipation of Thanksgiving, the group has bolstered lagging donations by piggybacking on entertainment events. At a Milwaukee Brewers' fan day in late October, patrons were asked to donate nonperishable food, which resulted in 500 pounds of goods. A similar solicitation occurred at a recent Nascar promotion, where guests were allowed to drive their own cars on the Milwaukee Mile race course if they donated $15 and a canned food item. The event brought in 700 pounds of food. Despite these efforts, Second Harvest's reserves are low.

HEADLINE: MARKETING; 
Selling to Nonprofits Proves Not That Easy

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
IN terms of numbers, the nonprofit sector of the economy might look like a golden sales opportunity for almost any business. Nonprofit groups had revenues of $665 billion in 1997 and employed 9.3 percent of all paid workers in the United States in 1998, the last years in which such statistics were gathered by Independent Sector, a Washington clearinghouse for management and policy discussion in the nonprofit world. 
 Not only is the sector big, but when it goes shopping for supplies it usually looks for the same things that a profit-making business looks for, like a product that has a good price and is reliable and easy to use. 
 In reality, the nonprofit world is so fragmented into specialized enterprises that few businesses devote much effort to creating marketing programs aimed at the nonprofit universe. 
"We looked at it as one industry at first," said Robert Leavy, the national leader of the nonprofit practice at Grant Thornton, an accounting and consulting firm that has been expanding its presence in the sector since the 1980's. 
"But if you really want to serve the broad industry, you have to understand the distinctions."
It is true that some issues on which Grant Thornton advises cut across all nonprofit institutions, like policies for directors and conflicts of interest, Mr. Leavy said. But, for example, when Grant Thornton is working for a college or other nonprofit higher education client, many accounting and tax questions grow out of the relationship between schools and students, which is particular to that corner of the nonprofit world. 
The biggest piece of this pie is made up of hospitals, 90 percent of which operate as nonprofit groups, and other health-service providers. Such nonprofits account for just under 50 percent of all nonprofit revenues. But the health sector bears little resemblance to the rest of that world. 
Perhaps the main barrier to selling supplies or products to nonprofit groups in fields like social services and religious, arts and environmental activities is that so many have so little money. Such groups sometimes receive goods that others must routinely pay for through donations.
Some financial-service institutions have separate units that specialize in helping nonprofits manage what money they have. The Merrill Lynch Center for Philanthropy and Nonprofit Management, for example, has 34,000 nonprofits as clients, said David Ratcliffe, its director. Clients also receive advice on fund-raising, board organization and management issues. The unit was formed in 2000, as an outgrowth of its traditional business of serving rich people, many of whom traditionally turn to brokerages for advice in managing their donations to nonprofit groups. 
In the field of technology, there is a growing network of suppliers, many of them also nonprofit groups, that compete with mainstream businesses. TechRocks, for example, is a nonprofit organization in San Francisco that provides other such groups with free software called ebase for managing their e-mail messages, donor lists and data about volunteers, among other things. 
CompuMentor, another San Francisco nonprofit group, operates a consulting service and DiscounTech, a Web-based marketplace for donated and discounted software and hardware available to nonprofits from companies like Microsoft, Cisco and Intuit. TechFoundation, in Cambridge, Mass., provides a similar service with TechMarketplace. 
CompuMentor has joined NPower, a new Microsoft-backed nonprofit in Seattle that is setting up affiliates in numerous cities to help nonprofits use and manage technology better. 
But most of these efforts, as well as many direct corporate discount programs, are restricted to nonprofits that are eligible to receive deductible donations under Section 501(c)3 of the tax code. 
Those excluded include AARP, the National Rifle Association and environmental groups that lobby and engage in other political activities.
"We get standard discounts for buying in volume, but we don't receive price breaks like other nonprofits because we don't qualify for tax deductions," said Lou Barnes, the chief financial executive of the Sierra Club. 
Volume buying is not the only way to get a discount from a vendor. Nonprofit groups can sometimes save money by agreeing to endorse a product. But some nonprofits, including the Sierra Club, have strict rules against allowing their names to be used commercially.
Although nonprofits look closely at costs, social values can also play a role in doing business with nonprofits. Mr. Barnes said that the Sierra Club, which has 550 employees based mostly in San Francisco and Washington, buys its office supplies from Give Something Back, a 12-year-old company in Oakland, Calif., that donates 92 percent of its after-tax profits to charities. 
"We were sold on the environmental quality of their products, which have a high recycled content, and how they distribute profits," Mr. Barnes said. "They are not the cheapest, but they are competitive." 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 24, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Giving section last Monday about businesses that sell to nonprofits referred incorrectly to TechRocks, a nonprofit organization that developed a software product called ebase. Ebase is now distributed by Groundspring.org, no longer TechRocks.
The article also misstated the current relationship between Npower and CompuMentor, nonprofits that provide technology support to other charities. CompuMentor ceased being the San Francisco affiliate of Npower in April, though the two groups are exploring a nationwide affiliation agreement.

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Rising Demand Squeezes Food Banks

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

DATELINE: ROCHESTER 

 BODY:
EVERY day, tractor-trailer rigs pull up to the loading dock of an old paper warehouse on the bank of the Genesee River here and unload donated food. The sturdy concrete warehouse was a donation itself, to Foodlink, a nonprofit wholesaler that distributes about six million pounds of food each year to soup kitchens, food pantries and meals-on-wheels programs in the Finger Lakes region of western New York.
 In the last decade, government has shifted onto charities the job of making food available to the poor, unemployed, disabled and housebound. Foodlink is one of 230 nonprofit food banks that are vital to a large portion of Americans who might otherwise go hungry. 
 From 1977 to 1997, one in four Americans at some point received federal food stamps, Labor Department studies show, as millions of people slipped in and out of poverty depending on the strength of the job market, changes in marital status and other conditions. Similar numbers depend on soup kitchens, food pantries and other charitable organizations for food, especially when jobs are scarce. 
Food banks are now caught in a financial vise, squeezed on one side by rising demand for food, especially from the long-term unemployed, and on the other side by shrinking donations from food manufacturers and cuts in federal spending. At the same time, food banks face a growing demand for cash. They must buy about a third of the food they distribute, mostly items that fill gaps between what is donated and what is needed to prepare balanced meals. And food banks have their own operating expenses, from maintaining refrigeration rooms to fueling trucks and vans that deliver groceries to charities. 
Janet Poppendieck, a professor of sociology at Hunter College who has studied food banks and nutrition among the poor, said that "there is a built-in squeeze on food banks, a constant downward pressure on supplies, which means they have to work harder and harder to get the same level of supply."
She compared it with "extracting oil from a declining field where you have to do more and more to get less and less out."
Tom Ferraro, the executive director of Foodlink since he founded it in 1976, said that "the meat and potatoes for food banks used to be the waste and mistakes of production."
"Too much oregano in the spaghetti sauce, or too little, and we would be offered tractor-trailer load after tractor-trailer load of the stuff that tasted fine, was perfectly nutritious, but did not meet the manufacturers' standards," he said.
"Back then there were tons of boxes of cereals with the name'General Mills' printed upside down or some other mistake that had nothing to do with nutrition," Mr. Ferraro said. "Food banks would trade everything back and forth so we had some balance between what the manufacturers in our area produced. That was food banking in the early days and it was easy."
Then corporations embraced ideas like Total Quality Management, resulting in improved production controls at food factories, which have benefited consumers with lower prices and investors with higher profits, but have taken a toll on donations to food banks. 
"Fewer production mistakes have made it harder for food banks to sustain themselves," Mr. Ferraro said. "The only part of the food industry that has not redone its production processes is the cereals business, where a $4 box of cereal has 5-cents worth of food in it, so there is no point in replacing even pre-World War II machinery if it still works."
Foodlink and other food banks are nonprofit wholesalers in the middle of a three-tier system. Above them is America's Second Harvest, a Chicago-based charity that coordinates requests to food manufacturers and other big suppliers and directs donations from them to food banks. The bottom tier is composed of thousands of soup kitchens, pantries, churches and other organizations that either hand out food or serve meals. 
Last year, Foodlink distributed six million pounds of food valued at $6.9 million. It also raised $2.7 million in cash, a chunk of it through an annual promotion with the Wegmans supermarket chain. Of $9.8 million in total expenses, management cost Foodlink $209,000 and fund-raising an additional $187,000, which together amounted to 4 percent of total expenses. 
On the demand side, America's working-age population grew more than 3 percent in the last three years, while the number of jobs shrank 2 percent, creating a gap of more than six million jobs. One in five of the unemployed has been jobless for more than six months, Labor Department data show.
Over the last three decades, incomes for those at the bottom have fallen in real terms. The poorest fifth of families averaged $271 a week in income last year, according to the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research organization in Washington whose data on the working poor are widely respected.
One result of reduced incomes can be seen in New York City, where a third of the population lives below or only modestly above the poverty line. The number of food pantries and kitchens citywide has grown to nearly 1,000 from 35 in 1983.
The way government poverty statistics are reported understates the scope of the problem, said J. Larry Brown, who runs the Center on Hunger and Poverty at Brandeis University's Heller School for Social Policy and Management.
"If the official figures show that 34 million people are poor all year," Dr. Brown said, "the question to ask is how many families are so poor that their incomes fall below the poverty line one month during the year. When you ask the question that way, the number rises to 74 million people, or one of every four Americans."
The first food bank is widely attributed to John van Hengel, a commodities trader who retired to Arizona in the mid-60's and volunteered at a soup kitchen. He started soliciting donations of food, applying his knowledge of commodities in a state where warm weather allows nearly year-round farming with three annual crops from the same field. Van Hengel was so successful that a warehouse was needed to take in the donated food, much of which was passed on to other soup kitchens and food pantries.
By 1976, after others copied van Hengel's warehouse idea, the federal government gave grants to start more food banks. Congress also passed a tax incentive in 1976, allowing manufacturers to deduct the cost of goods they donated and a portion of the profit they would have earned, which increased donations for a time. 
A Carter-era change in the food stamps program has also had a big effect on the poor in ways that have unintentionally caused many people to run out of food at the end of each month.
For years, advocates for the poor fought the Agriculture Department's policy that required people to buy the stamps, paying, say, $30 to get food stamps worth $100. The Carter administration changed the program so that those eligible could get $70 worth of stamps without paying any cash.
"People kept that $30 sacrosanct," Mr. Ferraro said, "because they needed it to get the extra $70 worth of food. But once you could get $70 worth of food stamps for nothing, then that $30 was no longer sacrosanct, and it was sometimes spent on some other pressing needs. And that was when we started seeing this phenomenon of people running out of food before the end of the month because they had $70 worth of food when they needed $100."
Professor Poppendieck sees other forces at work that push people toward food pantries and soup kitchens.
"I do believe many consumers are profoundly disempowered by not having learned basic food-preparation skills," she said, "so they are at the mercy of a market that peppers them with advertisements for high-value-added foods which have been extensively processed."
In addition, she said, many neighborhoods, urban and rural, do not have access to supermarkets. "If you must do your grocery shopping at the convenience store on the highway or the neighborhood bodega," she said, "you are paying an exaggerated price for a limited supply in terms of nutrition." 
So, she said, the lack of access to supermarket prices and weak food-preparation skills, combined with falling incomes, have resulted in a growing demand for the food banks and the soup kitchens and pantries they supply.

HEADLINE: VOLUNTEERING; 
This Mayor's a Workhorse, and She Does It for Nothing

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW

DATELINE: SALEM, Ore. 

 BODY:
AT 60, Janet Taylor was contemplating retirement. But there was the nagging question of what she could do for Salem, the city she describes as her "salvation." 
 Salem is the city where Mrs. Taylor's mother, who was raising her four children alone, nearly deaf and suffering from other health problems that made it difficult for her to work, moved the family in 1956. It was then a small town, the slow-moving Oregon state capital in the Willamette River Valley. 
 The children, born in Portland, 47 miles north of here, were raised on welfare in a blue-collar neighborhood in northeast Salem. Which is all the more reason Mrs. Taylor still sounds awed and tickled when she talks about being the new mayor of Salem.
"I feel like this is really, truly a way that maybe I can give some good back again," said Mrs. Taylor, who won the mayoral primary in May 2002 with such a high percentage of the vote, 63 percent, that she was declared the winner and allowed, under Oregon law, to bypass the general election, although she did not take office until last January. 
"When people say to me, 'I can't believe you're doing it,' I say, 'I can't believe that I wouldn't have tried,' " she said. "Truthfully, I needed to say thank you."
When the previous mayor decided not to run, Mrs. Taylor, who is 61, received a lot of encouragement to jump into the race. She had been managing a successful metal roofing company that she and her husband, Duane, started in the early 1980's, but had been involved in Salem politics, first through her local neighborhood association, and later as the chairwoman of the board of Salem's economic development corporation. She was also vice president of the Chamber of Commerce. All these positions provided her with a raw look at an economically depressed city, she said, that was in dire need of new, pro-business leadership. 
But she was also discouraged from running -- by Duane, for one, who had retired in 1995 -- and other friends and associates who advised her that becoming mayor of Salem, the second largest city in Oregon with a population of 142,000, when the city was struggling would wear her out. 
"Knowing her as a business associate and as a friend, I told her I thought she should be enjoying the fruits of her labor," said Larry Glassock, the president of the Strategic Economic Development Corporation of the mid-Willamette Valley, the board of which Mrs. Taylor was chairwoman. "Being mayor was going to interfere with that. We had a heart-to-heart and I had her convinced for about 30 days."
Salem has a long history of volunteerism. Dozens clean the parks, staff the libraries and patrol the city's neighborhoods, and volunteerism is an ethic that Mrs. Taylor, as mayor, often mentions. So it was fitting, she said, that she would take on the challenge for no compensation. Technically, the job pays $274 a month, but Mrs. Taylor declined the stipend, saying she thought the money could go to better uses. 
In July, six months after she took office, the Taylors sold their metal roofing business, Taylor Metal Products. Although they are still receiving some income from it, Mrs. Taylor is making a lot less money. 
In Salem, the city manager, who draws a salary, runs the daily operations, and the mayor and city councilors set policy. The job of mayor could, potentially, be mostly ceremonious, presiding over the Monday night City Council meetings and attending the occasional ribbon cutting or groundbreaking. 
But Mrs. Taylor, who has the demeanor of a chipper school principal and often describes things, particularly the various new development projects she has spearheaded in Salem, as just wonderful, has made her tenure as hands-on as possible. She works 40 to 50 hours a week and has already declared she will run for a second two-year term. She had no plans to become a career politician at the outset, she said, but she was not ruling out running for other offices later on.
"If you'd asked me three or four months ago, I would have said no," Mrs. Taylor said, referring to the possibility of making a career of politics. "But I think I'd like to see what opportunities are there and make that assessment down the road."
She said the two-year mayoral term seemed too short, since she took office. "I'd like to accomplish some things here before I make any decisions. It was never about going into politics, it was that I wanted to head this ship in a positive direction and change the political climate."
Mrs. Taylor is a registered Republican, although she was a Democrat for 20 years, and said she defied political pigeonholing. 
Her days are a whirl of activity, usually beginning by 7:30 with meetings -- on what to do about the huge waste-water fees being imposed on Salem by the federal government, or about the silicon-chip company that is threatening to leave town with hundreds of jobs because it can receive much better tax breaks in Ohio. 
What Mrs. Taylor says she loves about the job are the little and big victories that make her feel that she is making a difference. For instance, the $32 million convention center downtown, which the city was planning to build for 40 years, was stalled until last summer, when Mrs. Taylor and other city officials got involved and helped cut through the red tape. Construction began in August and the center is scheduled for completion in 2005.
Then there was the Puentes Brothers tortilla factory, whose owner, George Puentes, was so frustrated by the city bureaucracy standing between him and a new plant that he was also planning to leave Salem.
But Mr. Puentes, who knew Mrs. Taylor as a member of the Chamber of Commerce, was receptive to her hard selling of Salem, and decided he would stay. And Mrs. Taylor promised him she would help streamline the permit process for building a new tortilla factory. He employs 110 people and the city, Mrs. Taylor said, could ill afford to lose those jobs.
"We knew we had to grow, but we weren't going to do it blindly," Mr. Puentes said, during a recent tour with Mrs. Taylor of the new plant, which opened in October in the northeast part of the city. "And then Janet got elected and I said, 'I think we'll stay.' "
Mrs. Taylor smiled and said: "Thank you, George. I really appreciate it."
Mrs. Taylor acknowledged that she was not entirely prepared for the pressure-cooker atmosphere that comes with being mayor of a city plagued by unemployment, fiercely fighting to keep businesses, create new jobs and revitalize its slowly recovering historic downtown district. 
"People say I'm thriving on it, that it hasenergized me," Mrs. Taylor said. "Both are true. It has challenged me at times. It has exhausted me. But it feels so wonderful to me, it truly does."

HEADLINE: GRASS ROOTS; 
Speaking Up for Fishermen As Rules Cloud Their Future

BYLINE:  By DULCIE LEIMBACH

 BODY:
 NAME: Shore Support, New Bedford, Mass.

FOUNDED: In 1996 by Deb Shrader, a scalloper's wife.

MISSION: To create a "voice for the rank and file of fishermen and their families" regarding new restrictions in the last decade on fishing off New England, Mrs. Shrader said. (In 1994, major regulations restricted fishermen to when, where and how they fished.)

FINANCING: Sailors' Snug Harbor of Boston and the Island Foundation, about $15,000; in addition, the Heinz Family Philanthropies, Haymarket People's Fund and United Way Community Building mini-grant program.

THE STORY: Concerned about her husband's future, Mrs. Shrader first tried organizing other wives, to little avail. She then became a paralegal to understand the new laws and worked with Snug Harbor on entrepreneurial training for fishermen and their families. Learning how nonprofits operate, she set up Shore Support, which became part of the Community Economic Development Center of Southeastern Massachusetts.
Although the regulations have been tinkered with since 1994, the National Marine Fisheries Service reduced the number of days fishermen could fish last year, after a court case brought by environmentalists who say the fish population needs more time to rebound and the laws restricting fishing need to be met more fully. The rules will be tightened further in May, when Amendment 13 takes effect, specifically influencing those who catch bottom-dwellers: cod, haddock and several kinds of flounder.
Despite the restrictions, New Bedford was ranked first this year by the Commerce Department as the nation's most valuable fishing port. Fishermen there caught $169 million worth of fish in 2002.
Yet Mrs. Shrader remains worried about the fishermen. The unemployment rate in New Bedford was 9.4 percent in September. "My biggest concern is the economic effects this amendment will have," she said. "We're looking at 3,000 jobs lost in our region. In New Bedford alone, it will be about 800 to 1,000 jobs."
Shore Support and the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth, are working on a report of the economic conditions of fleets before and after days at sea, studying earnings and loss of jobs from the regulations. "We're going boat to boat," Mrs. Shrader said. 
With the information they gather, the groups will go to the New England Fishery Management Council, a federal office that manages fishing within the 200-mile limit off the New England coast, to shed light on what she calls "damages being done on the fishing-dependent families."
"Fishermen are used to working long, hard hours," Mrs. Shrader said. "But fishing is in their hearts. When these jobs are lost, what they stand for is taken away." DULCIE LEIMBACH

HEADLINE: CORPORATIONS; 
Fitting Gifts to the Business: Restaurant, Meet Food Bank

BYLINE:  By FRAN HAWTHORNE

 BODY:
THE Mandarin Oriental, Manhattan's newest hotel, does not have much in common with a soup kitchen. It boasts views of Central Park, a spa with what it calls Asian-based rituals and a butler on every floor. Rooms start at $600 a night, and its restaurant serves trendy Japanese-French cuisine. But the Mandarin Oriental has a close tie, in fact, with the soup kitchen business because it gives both leftover food from its catering events and nearly all of its cash donations to City Harvest.
 The charity, which distributes food to 800 soup kitchens, homeless shelters, centers for the aged and other groups, will also receive the $100,000 to $150,000 that the Mandarin Oriental hopes to raise in December from an auction to celebrate its opening in the new Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle. And the Mandarin Oriental will contribute hotel-room packages when City Harvest holds its own auctions. 
 The reason for focusing on just a single charity is simple. "It's a lot easier to make a bigger impact with one charity," said Kristin Ruble, the hotel's director of sales and marketing. 
Many other businesses have decided to focus their generosity on just a handful of carefully selected charities rather than giving to every good cause that comes knocking. It is a straightforward calculation, these companies say: channeling money into fewer but larger gifts is more efficient and effective. Besides, it makes the company look better, especially in this era of corporate scandals.
"Companies are asking, 'How can we be sure scarce resources deliver some impact?' " said Bradley Googins, the executive director of the Center for Corporate Citizenship at Boston College, which educates business managers about civic involvement. "There is a tendency to give larger grants to fewer organizations, so they can get even more bang for the buck."
There are other motivations as well. A program that makes fewer donations is easier to administer. For some companies, giving to one charity can tie in with a broader effort to use their philanthropy to increase business. And in the case of a merger between companies, this approach can help streamline the companies' charitable programs. That is what happened with the alliance of Time Warner and America Online.
No one has numbers on how widespread this practice is, but experts in corporate philanthropy say that in the last five years, it has been growing among companies of all types and sizes. The charities that are picked are known as charities of choice, signature projects or focus philanthropy. Because large companies give so much money away, however, they can end up with a few dozen charities of choice.
To pare their lists down from many to few, companies often use the same tactics they use in their core business. The Deutsche Bank Americas Foundation, which is based in New York City, sent out requests for proposals, or R.F.P.'s, in 2002 and 2003, inviting charities to apply for financing for projects that would use the arts to spur community development and create jobs in the city. 
The applications asked contenders to provide, among other things, a budget for the grant, a list of their directors, resumes of the staff members who would work on the project, their most recent audited financial statement and detailed goals of the project. Of the 99 groups that responded to the requests, Deutsche Bank selected 19 to receive a total $1.65 million over two years.
The foundation used to give grants of $15,000 each, on average, to 75 arts and community development groups. Now it helps 45, with grants averaging $50,000 to $75,000 apiece.
One of those groups is the Bronx Council on the Arts, which is getting $75,000 a year for two years. Among other things, it set up a free trolley to shuttle visitors to the art gallery at Hostos Community College and other arts attractions in the Bronx. The aim of the trolley, which runs only on the first Wednesday of each month, is to help spur the borough's economy by increasing tourism.
When Theresa Fay-Bustillos became the executive director of the Levi Strauss Foundation in 2000, she began a review of its $13 million annual donation program. She went through all the grants that had been made in the last five years, categorizing them by size and type. Her conclusion: "We were spreading our resources around to lots of different agencies, but you didn't see any emphasis in our work." 
Today, Levi Strauss restricts its grants to programs that help women and youths in three areas: education, economic development and preventing the spread of H.I.V. and AIDS. To refine its selection even further, Ms. Fay-Bustillos said: "We're looking for grantees that have a longer-term social change agenda. Also, we want organizations that emphasize collaborating." The number of grants the company has made dropped 57 percent from 2001 through October 2003, though more grants are likely to be made by the year's end. 
Before choosing City Harvest, Ms. Ruble of the Mandarin Oriental said that she had considered a couple dozen major organizations in a range of fields, including the arts and the environment. Six groups were interviewed in depth. She finally homed in on City Harvest because it was the only one specializing in food, and Mandarin Oriental's 250-room hotel includes the Asiate restaurant. "We felt it was an area where the hotel could make a strong impact," she said. 
City Harvest's local roots were also important. As Ms. Ruble put it, "We wanted to be part of the community and not be a global charity."
The downside of this more focused approach is having to say no to worthwhile causes. For Deutsche Bank and Levi Strauss, this has meant not renewing grants to groups they had helped for years. 
"It always is tough," said Gary Hattem, the president of the Deutsche Bank Americas Foundation. "We have begun to explain to organizations that we are doing it more through R.F.P.'s. You can defend that kind of grant-making as being open and transparent, rather than who runs into you at a party, or who has access to you." 
Levi Strauss is giving severance grants of $20,000 to $100,000 to about a third of the groups it will no longer donate to as the grants expire.
Many companies do not agree with this new method of giving. The Principal Financial Group, an investment management firm based in Des Moines, contributes $5 million to $6 million a year to about 150 organizations, mostly to improve the quality of life in the 12 cities where the company has a sizable presence. It plans to keep doing so. "One or two groups won't meet the needs of all our employees," said Libby Jacobs, the director for community relations at the company.
The new strategy also translates into tougher competition among charities. But Julia A. Erickson, City Harvest's executive director, played down any anxiety she might have felt as she awaited Mandarin Oriental's decision. "There's always that element where we cross our fingers and hope for the best," she said. "But we looked at it as a fantastic opportunity to show off what we've been able to accomplish." 

Some Giving Takes The Personal Touch
EVEN as some companies try to select their philanthropies according to their business principles, others still do it the old-fashioned way, by supporting the chief executive's favorite charities.
Take the example of the Ruder Finn Group, a public relations firm. David Finn, its chairman and a co-founder, is on the boards of the Academy of American Poets and Cedar Crest College in Allentown, Pa., as well as a friend of Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general. 
So, it is not surprising that Ruder Finn has contributed money, printing help and design work to the Poets Academy and to Cedar Crest. It has also published a book of Mr. Annan's acceptance speech for the 2001 Nobel Peace Prize, which he shared with the United Nations. 
Mr. Finn estimates that his company donates an amount equal to 10 percent of its billings each year in cash and pro bono work to at least a dozen philanthropic causes. Most of these are organizations that Ruder Finn's senior managers are actively interested in.
"I feel we as a firm should support things that we feel deeply about as individuals," Mr. Finn said. 
In New York, some executives say, corporations tend to support one another's charities. "We all go around in circles," said Jeffrey R. Gural, the chairman of Newmark & Company, a large real estate brokerage firm.
Mr. Gural will ask other executives to pony up for his special causes. For instance, he is president of the Starlight Children's Foundation, which tries to grant wishes to youngsters who have serious or terminal illnesses. In return, he will give to the other executives' charities.
Mr. Gural seemed surprised to be asked why Newmark donates to his personal philanthropic interests. "Why would I be active on a board and not have my company support it financially?" he said.
Far from being pruned, these personal lists tend to grow. "Different members of the firm come in with different interests," Mr. Finn said.
 FRAN HAWTHORNE
