HEADLINE: COMMUNITY ICON; 
Clarifying What Y.M.C.A. Stands For

BYLINE:  By JOANNA L. KROTZ

 BODY:
MENTION the Y.M.C.A. and everyone has a different notion of what it is all about.
 In places like Greenwich, Conn., where well-heeled matrons show up for weekly bridge games, and in downtown Washington, where hard-charging professionals pour in at lunchtime to lift weights in sports rooms filled with the latest gear, the Y is viewed as a hangout for the elite. 
 In some neighborhoods in New York City and Seattle, where in recent years local branches have sold off suddenly prime real estate, the Y.M.C.A. is viewed as indifferent to the concerns of neighborhood residents and urban preservationists. It has also been the object of lawsuits by several commercial health clubs that claimed the Y uses its tax-exempt status to compete unfairly in the luxury health-club business.
Kenneth L. Gladish, the national executive director of the Y.M.C.A., is aware of these perceptions, and he considers them grossly unfair. 
Mr. Gladish acknowledges the "swim and gym" reputation, but said it was a misconception. The Y's policy, he points out, is that no one is turned away because of an inability to pay. There are discounted, or free, memberships that total about $65 million a year. And he states correctly that the Y is one of the largest providers in the country of day-care services and after-school programs for working and homeless families.
Mr. Gladish said that the mission of the Y -- the nation's largest nonprofit with more than 2,500 branches serving 10,000 communities -- remains the same, to nurture youngsters. "Our kids in America are challenged in getting access to a sustained, caring adult presence in their lives," he said. "This is not a matter of race, economic class or geographic boundaries."
He added: "Is it okay for Y's to build and operate in middle-class, affluent communities, just as we operate and provide support in more disadvantaged communities? The answer is yes. And it's the right thing to do. And we've done it for 150 years."
Despite its religious origin and name, the Young Men's Christian Association (which has no connection to the Young Women's Christian Association or the Young Men's Hebrew Association) has a secular mission. It now serves more than 18 million Americans, half of them under age 18, and wields more social services' spending power than many small nations. In addition to its child-care and teenage programs, the Y.M.C.A. is also the largest provider of single-occupancy rooms, about 17,000, offering one of the few affordable places to live for people moving off welfare or out of homeless shelters. 
The Y's $4.2 billion in annual income is bolstered by government grants and corporate donations. But nearly 70 cents of every dollar comes from its own programs and membership fees. 
The slowed economy has affected some branches more than others. "Two or three years ago, the vast majority of the Y's were on the favorable side," in terms of their finances, Mr. Gladish said. "Now, depending on the marketplace, the Y's are suffering along with the local economy. Some are experiencing zero growth or even have lost some of their annual contributions or income andsome have sustained growth and development."
The stock market's decline has also produced problems. "Our income from endowments, from the equity markets, has been substantially decreased, although the Y's are not heavily endowed organizations," Mr. Gladish said. Instead, branches depend on annual operations and contributions, he said. The endowment of the Y's national organization -- called the Y.M.C.A. of the U.S.A. -- is now about $78 million, a decrease of 5 percent as of 2002.
Though chartered by the national organization, every Y is locally managed, governed and financed and free to adapt to community needs. After 9/11, for example, New York's Vanderbilt Branch on East 47th Street saw a drop in tourist bookings, so it renovated its 400 rooms of bunk beds and shared baths into offices and student housing.
Mr. Gladish has made several moves to support this emphasis on community, by making more resources available to the branches, and by improving access to professional training for the Y's local staff and half a million volunteers. 
His aim over the next few years is to make the independent Y's more consistent with one another without dismantling the autonomy of each branch. And he has begun a major marketing effort to raise the organization's national profile.
The Y.M.C.A. has signed a $5 million contract with the advertising agency BBDO Chicago to create a campaign that includes television commercials featuring John Glenn and the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. as young members. It has also forged a "charity of choice" alliance with Sports Illustrated and Sports Illustrated for Kids magazines, and is signing "cause marketing" contracts for lucrative partnerships with companies like J. C. Penney, Kimberly-Clark and PepsiCo, which will reap benefits from having their corporate identities associated with Y programs. The J. C. Penney after-school program is a five-year, $16 million grant.
Trent Stamp, the executive director of Charity Navigator, a group in Mahwah, N.J., that analyzes the finances of charities, calls the marketing campaign extremely savvy.
"There's great value in tying the organization together so that the success of the suburban fitness centers feeds added contributions or added effects for the inner cities," he said.
Brooke W. Mahoney, the executive director of the Volunteer Consulting Group, a company in New York that helps nonprofit boards find trustees, said the Y.M.C.A. was going through an evolution. "It is figuring out how to work smart, asking questions like, 'How do we make someone who walks into a Y in Spokane have the same experience as someone in Atlanta?' "
Jim Everett, the chief executive of the Treasure Valley Y.M.C.A. in Boise, Idaho, said he had mixed emotions about the ad campaign and corporate sponsors. "The Y probably needs to be out there, and its legacy may be underappreciated," he said. "But philanthropy is more about doing than talking about doing."
The Treasure Valley Y recently received a $1 million donation from the family, all members, of J. R. Simplot, who founded an agribusiness empire. "Here's a family worth $1.4 billion who are changing in the locker room alongside kids from the homeless shelter," Mr. Everett said. "There's no other place that offers such a wide spectrum of society, especially for kids."
A problem that remains is the Y.M.C.A.'s name. The Young Men's Christian Association is open to all. But many are either confused or put off by the seeming religious connection. The Y was founded on Protestant evangelical values; its mission statement says it intends to "put Christian principles into practice." The organization lets it go at that.
More complicated are the issues of serving people who supposedly are not in need, or of applying sophisticated business practices to support charitable causes.
"Philosophically, there's never been a needs test used to qualify an organization as a charity," Mr. Gladish said, in response to such criticism. "There are nonprofit theaters, hospitals and TV programming. It's not about the activity, it's about how it's done."
He said that selling off real estate, as some branches have done, "isn't a fund-raising tool." The money brought in by those sales, he said, was used to pay for upgrades or build new quarters. In New York, the McBurney Y.M.C.A. on West 23rd Street was sold to a developer and is being converted into condominiums. The second building on the site was sold to a nonprofit group, which builds housing for former homeless people and foster children. 
It was part of a decision, Mr. Gladish said, "to stay fully vested in the neighborhood while dealing with a deeply distressed and very ancient building." The new McBurney Y, a $35 million center, reopened on West 14th Street last December.
Ms. Mahoney of the Volunteer Consulting Group said that such property sales were a smart use of resources. "The image in society for nonprofits is that they should be doing for everybody," she said. "But that's not reality. Why shouldn't the Y use tools of entrepreneurship and take advantage of well-managed efficiencies, so long as they stay true to their philanthropic mission?"
In the cases of commercial fitness centers that brought suit against the Y for using its tax-exempt status to compete unfairly in providing health club services, its critics contend that the Y.M.C.A. "acts like a business" and thus should be "paying taxes like a business," in the words of Kevin Buckley, an executive with the International Health, Racquet & Sportsclub Association, a fitness industry group in Boston.
While a few Y's have ended up paying taxes on a portion of their offerings -- for example, discretionary or luxury services like saunas and steam rooms -- most of the legal cases have thus far been dismissed.
Milton Harrison, the chief executive of the newly renovated Y.M.C.A. in Newark, points out the importance of having high-quality centers no matter what the community's status is. "Urban people, poor people, deserve the same caliber of services as anyone else," he said. "It creates pride and says, 'We are somebody.' "

HEADLINE: Alexander Vagliano, 76; Aided Iran Talks 

 BODY:
Alexander M. Vagliano, who was involved in the negotiations for the return of American hostages from Iran, died on Thursday at his home in Norfolk, Conn. He was 76. 
 The cause was complications of diabetes, his wife, Sara, said. 
 In January 1981, as head of the international banking division of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, Mr. Vagliano joined a group of bank executives who were negotiating the release of Iranian assets from American banks. The negotiations were part of an agreement that the United States government had brokered with Iran for the return of American hostages, one of whom was Mr. Vagliano's cousin, Moorehead Kennedy. 
A native of Paris, Mr. Vagliano came to the United States in 1940 and was naturalized in 1945 after serving in the Army. He graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School and worked for six years as an associate at the law firm of White & Case before joining J. P. Morgan & Company. He also worked for the Agency for International Development in the 60's. 
After retiring, Mr. Vagliano turned to raising sheep in Connecticut. In the late 1980's, the French government awarded him the rank of Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres for his activities promoting French-American culture. 
He is survived by his wife; two sons, Andre, of Brookline, Mass., and Justin, of Dover, Mass.; a daughter, Barbara, of New York City; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Putting Her Hopes Where Her Heart Lies 

BYLINE:  By TOM MILLER; Tom Miller is the author of "Writing on the Edge," an anthology of literature about the U.S.-Mexico border.

 BODY:
BILL AND MELINDA GATES, through their foundation, have given away almost $6.25 billion, which includes more than $60 million to microbicide development, $5.8 million to 10 Alaska school districts and $2.5 million to a cancer research center in King County in Washington State.
 Shannon Cain, a foundation consultant in Tucson, used $5,000 in severance pay to start the Sonora Fund, a foundation that she hopes will help raise social consciousness and living standards on both sides of the border between the United States and Mexico. 
 Though tiny and barely off the ground, Ms. Cain's foundation represents a recent trend called community-based philanthropy. This "new philanthropy," as she calls it, is unabashedly progressive about who it finances and how it raises money and decides who receives it. Ms. Cain, 39, was the executive director of a small foundation in Tucson until it closed its doors in October 2002. Recently, she was a co-chairwoman of a conference in Tucson of the National Network of Grantmakers, a Brooklyn organization whose 200 members underwrite social and economic change. 
To explain the new philanthropy, Ms. Cain expanded on a biblical parable. "Four women see babies floating down a river," she said. "The first woman wades in the water and pulls the babies out one by one. The second woman teaches the babies how to swim. The third woman wades upriver to see who's putting the babies in the water. And the fourth woman sits in a university office analyzing why the babies were put in the water in the first place and how to prevent it in the future."
Ms. Cain said that "94 percent of all philanthropy goes to immediate needs and self-empowerment, like the first two women in the parable. The remaining 6 percent address root problems, much as the third and fourth women," she said. "We're concentrating on the root problems." Or, as the Funding Exchange, a network of social justice foundations in New York, says in its trademark, "Change, not charity."
For her first board of directors, Ms. Cain said she was looking for "a majority of people of color."
"We're returning power to the people most affected," she said. "It makes for better, smarter and more informed grants. We call it cross-class fund-raising." 
In other words, she would like the Sonora Fund's board to look much like its beneficiaries.
A typical potential recipient of the foundation is the Border Action Network, an advocacy group in Tucson, which, according to its director, Jennifer Allen, has "urged Arizona's attorney general to prosecute border vigilantes" -- the self-appointed patrols that round up Mexicans and others who have just crossed the border.
The Sonora Fund is also leaning toward cross-border grant giving to address problems like toxic waste and water contamination, Ms. Cain said. Another possible recipient is the Alianza Frontera de Obreros (the Border Workers' Alliance), a support group for assembly plant workers in the Mexican border towns of Nogales and Agua Prieta. "Their goals are consistent with ours," Ms. Cain said, "worker rights, decent housing, child care, health of workers and also corporate accountability for the foreign plant owners."
One person, Ms. McCain said, has volunteered to raise $5,000 by soliciting 500 donations of $10 each. Another way to raise money is through grants from more established organizations. Alan Rabinowitz, an urban economist in Seattle and the author of "Social Change Philanthropy in America," said: "When a small, local foundation discovers something wonderful to fund, it often serves as a recommendation to a larger foundation and confirms the smaller one's judgment."
The Sonora Fund has already won recognition, receiving $20,000 for administrative expenses earlier this year from Changemakers, a foundation in San Francisco that supports community-style philanthropy.
Ms. Cain and some colleagues have set a goal of raising $100,000 for the Sonora Fund by December 2004. She thinks that it is fitting that the first money was from her severance pay.
"I've always felt that people in philanthropy should give 10 percent of their income," she said. "If you are a fund-raiser, you have to be a donor, too."

HEADLINE: ACCOUNTABILITY; 
New Equation For Charities: More Money, Less Oversight

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
AMERICA has the world's biggest collection of charities, but oversight of the nonprofit sector is parochial, piecemeal, political and, at times, accidental.
 In the last decade, gaps in a regulatory system that could be described as more hole than net have widened, as the number of charities and their assets exploded and state and federal money spent monitoring them remained flat or declined. 
 The Internal Revenue Service, for example, has 800 employees monitoring more than 900,000 charities -- along with almost 690,000 other tax-exempt organizations, like trade associations, fraternal societies and veterans' groups.
Over all, charitable giving more than doubled in inflation-adjusted dollars from 1992 to 2002, reaching $240 billion last year, according to Giving USA, a report compiled by American Association of Fundraising Counsel Trust for Philanthropy. The number of private foundations almost doubled in those 10 years, while their inflation-adjusted assets rose even more, to $477 billion in 2001 from $177 billion in 1992, according to the Foundation Center, a research organization in New York. 
While scandals from Enron to mutual funds have commanded some of the biggest business headlines in the last few years, the nonprofit sector has not been immune, either: deceptive accounting was found at the United Way in the Washington area, and there was embezzlement at the United Way in Lansing, Mich. The Nature Conservancy, the environmental group, refused to comply fully with a Congressional demand for information about land transactions that had been criticized as possible sweetheart deals. PipeVine, a nonprofit that helped fund-raisers collect and distribute donations, went bankrupt, taking more than $2 million with it. Dubious compensation and spending at some foundations also frequent the news. 
A drumbeat of such reports has made regulators and leaders of large charities aware of the need for greater accountability. But efforts to bring change have faltered, victim to budget constraints or lobbying by nonprofits that have long mastered the art of casting themselves as on the side of the angels.
Some obstacles involve complicated legal or jurisdictional issues; other hindrances are simpler.
New York, for example, is regarded as one of the most aggressive states for nonprofit regulation. But until this year, files of the state's 48,000 registered charities were stored in a room straight out of Dickens. The Ford Foundation's tax return for one year, all four cartons, was stacked haphazardly in a corner. William Josephson, the assistant attorney general for oversight of charities in New York, received money to upgrade the room, so six years of files are now neatly crammed into 6,570 feet of metal racks and tended by a staff of five.
"I now have a state-of-the-art 1950's file room," Mr. Josephson said. His request for money to create an electronic system that would allow charities to file documents online has been repeatedly denied.
So Mr. Josephson recently hit the fund-raising circuit, taking foundation heads and trustees on tours of his file room to raise money from the very people the room helps regulate -- a conflict of interest that he acknowledges, though he is quick to say that it was approved by the state ethics commission.
His boss, New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, calls the regulatory system full of "huge, gaping holes."
"By no means do I feel confident with the degree of oversight that we're able to give," Mr. Spitzer said, "that we can protect those who contribute and charities who rely on good will to raise money."
Tax exemptions granted to nonprofit organizations are based on the idea that charities and foundations labor for the public. That trust has, theoretically, many guardians: the boards of the groups themselves, the I.R.S., state attorneys general and the media and the public through their access to public filings.
But the public's trust in charities, and the ability or willingness of those guardians to police the sector, has steadily eroded. That confidence was particularly shaken after the Sept. 11 attacks by reports that the Red Cross, which raised more than $1 billion, was planning to divert money from the immediate relief most donors had in mind. It was also shaken by the amount of time it took some groups to hand out the money. Preliminary results for a study by Paul C. Light, a professor of public service at New York University, suggested that confidence has not rebounded. 
"The questions raised about how the 9/11 charities were spending the money they received and how quickly they were disbursing it," Professor Light said, "were followed by scandals in the Catholic Church and a steady drip, drip, drip of news stories raising questions about many aspects of nonprofit accountability."

States' Oversight
State governments have perhaps the broadest mandate to monitor nonprofits. But differences exist in how that responsibility is handled. 
Most states look at charity oversight as an extension of their role as consumer watchdogs and focus on solicitation. Issues of financial mismanagement and governance often fall through the cracks.
In Virginia, oversight of the state's 13,000 charities is handled by the office of consumer affairs in the Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services. Michael Wright, the manager of regulatory programs, said the office concentrated on compliance with registration requirements.
Around the country, the smallest of groups can escape oversight -- virtually no paperwork is required from charities that collect less than $25,000 a year.
Most of what supervision there is focuses on fund-raising. Thirty-seven states require organizations that raise money in their states, and their professional fund-raisers if they have them, to register. Nine of those states require charitable trusts and charitable nonprofit corporations to register and report, according to research by Marion R. Fremont-Smith, a senior research fellow at the Hauser Center for Nonprofit Organizations at Harvard University. 
In Texas, those who raise money on behalf of police, firefighters and other uniformed officers and veterans must register with the secretary of state's office. Private foundations do not have to register, although they are supposed to file their tax returns with the attorney general's office, nor are public charities required to register.
Mary Henderson, the deputy chief for charitable trusts in the Texas attorney general's office, said the state's limited registration requirements have not affected law enforcement.
"Frankly, we have not seen that we're at a loss for things to do," she said.
But the varied nature of state regulation allows charities to shop around for the least-cumbersome environment. Lawyers representing nonprofit groups in New York, exasperated with Mr. Josephson's hard-nosed approach to oversight, have told him that they would advise clients to incorporate in other states.

Heavy Workloads
State regulators do have one thing in common: the feeling of falling behind expanding case loads. 
In New York, Mr. Josephson's unit has 21 full- and part-time lawyers, including two volunteers. They oversee 48,000 charities.
In California, 11 lawyers and 11 investigators are responsible for around 85,000 charities. Attorney General Bill Lockyer increased the budget for charity oversight to $5.2 million from $3.2 million in 1999, but the office is bracing for cutbacks because of the state's $10 billion deficit.
"We still have to turn cases away because we don't have the manpower to handle them," said Belinda J. Johns, the supervising deputy attorney general for charities in California. "We have to do triage when we get complaints."
Virginia's office has grown to eight, including Mr. Wright's assistant, from three in 1978. But Mr. Wright said the staff was struggling to keep up. "The public is now more aware that they need information," he said, "and they turn to us for it."
In states that pursue cases more aggressively, budget constraints have hindered litigation. A trial can be expensive, so attorneys general often try to settle cases, and charities often rush to do so. Bad publicity can kill fund-raising.
While that can save taxpayer money, it means corrective actions often occur behind the scenes, reducing the ability to educate or deter. Avoiding the courts slows the creation of laws and of precedents that could set boundaries for appropriate activity by charities.
It also lessens the accountability of the regulator, said Evelyn Brody, a professor at the Chicago-Kent College of Law.
"Invisibility at the informal end of the regulatory spectrum," Ms. Brody said, "makes it hard to judge the level and effectiveness of regulators in influencing charity behavior, and whether regulators are motivated by their own or the public's interests." 

Stretched at the I.R.S.
The I.R.S. provides a layer of uniform oversight by ensuring that charities meet various requirements for guaranteeing their tax exemption. But the division that oversees tax-exempt organizations has been affected by an overhaul of the I.R.S that was imposed by Congress in 1998 and the increase in demand for its services. 
The number of employees in the division has fallen to about 800 from 960 in the early 1990's, said Steven C. Miller, director for the exempt organizations division.
At the same time, the number of organizations seeking tax-exempt status has risen sharply, Mr. Miller said. In the early 90's, the division was receiving 60,000 applications for tax-exempt status a year. Last year, requests topped 90,000.
Besides the fact that auditors have more groups to monitor, the increase has stretched resources in another way. "What we saw in the 1990's was a big uptick in determination-letter requests," Mr. Miller said, referring to requests for tax exemption. "What that meant was that more of our examiners were pulled off to do this customer-driven work."
In other words, auditors who might have been combing tax returns for irregularities and pursuing investigations were processing applications. Mr. Miller said that practice was stopped last year.
One of his predecessors, Marcus S. Owens, a lawyer now in private practice, pointed to two indicators that he said showed the agency had become less aggressive and less feared. 
One is the number of requests for technical advice from agents, which dropped to 18 last fiscal year from 124 in 1991.
The other is requests for private-letter rulings, questions posed by groups about whether something the group is considering, like a merger, might fall afoul of tax law. Such requests by tax-exempt groups dropped to 265 last fiscal year from 625 in 1997.
"The decline in the number of technical-advice requests being made suggests a decline in the number of audits being conducted and/or a decline in the depth of the audits that do occur, confirming popular suspicions," Mr. Owens said.
The drop in requests for private-letter advice reflects "a more relaxed attitude," he said, one "fed by a perception that I.R.S. audits are few and far between, and why bring up something that might pique their interest when the chances of audit are so small."
Beyond verifying compliance, tax returns are supposed to provide a window into how nonprofit groups are being managed. But many can be confusing.
At the same time, nonprofits seem to realize they can take shortcuts on their forms. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, for example, lists no amount in the lines requiring it to itemize various expenditures like telephone services, postage and conference fees. 
When asked in March 2002 why M.I.T. could not itemize those expenses, James L. Morgan, the university's controller, said, "Can't and don't show it are two different things. We bulk it all together to make it consistent with public reports."
Mr. Miller said the I.R.S. was taking steps to address the inconsistencies in the reporting. For starters, it announced that next year it would be examining groups that raise money but report few or no costs associated with fund-raising. That work will be handled by a new compliance unit, which will be charged with keeping an eye on the tax returns.

The Board's Job
The first line of defense against the waste or misuse of charitable dollars is supposed to be the boards of nonprofits and foundations. 
Yet time and again, nonprofit boards have failed to uncover wrongdoing, pulled their punches or turned a collective blind eye.
When two board members of the United Way of the National Capital Area, which serves the Washington area, asked to see various financial statements, they were told they were not entitled to look at them. When they pressed further, they were pushed off the board.
The organization later imploded, brought down by deceptive accounting, high costs and the use of the charity's money to pay for personal expenses of various executives and board members.
More recently, business relationships between Boston University and some trustees have raised questions. In February, Gerald S. J. Cassidy, the university's Washington lobbyist, was named tothe board. From 1999 to 2001, the university paid Mr. Cassidy's firm $2.4 million, and it continued that relationship after Mr. Cassidy became a trustee, paying $400,000 in the first six months of this year.
Examples of boards that have approved questionable compensation have been a favorite topic of the media, ranging from the amount of a retirement package that was granted to Dennis Collins by the board of the James Irvine Foundation in San Francisco at a time when its assets were down sharply, to the Paul and Virginia Cabot Charitable Trust in Boston, which gave its chairman, Mr. Cabot's son, Paul C. Cabot Jr., about $200,000 to cover the costs of his daughter's wedding in Florida.
Lawyers who work with charities, and experts in nonprofit governance, say the volunteer nature of most charity work has contributed to a laxness that has been compounded by the structure of many nonprofit boards. The charismatic leaders who run many nonprofits and a sense that their real role is to be a fund-raiser, not a watchdog, have also contributed to the problems.

Technological Improvements
Regulators and leaders of large philanthropies have become increasingly convinced that accountability needs improving, but little consensus has formed about how to do that.
There has been some tepid discussion of a sort of Securities and Exchange Commission for the nonprofit sector, but the idea has received a heated negative response from most of the sector, which contends that more vigorous self-policing within the existing regulatory structures is adequate.
Regulators and nonprofit leaders predict that continuing developments in technology will improve oversight by making information more readily available.
Guidestar, a national database of nonprofit information, including many tax returns, started asking users of its Web site to register in May. The response was surprising: more than 150,000 registered, about three times what Guidestar had anticipated.
But greater access to information will also increase demand on the regulators, as Mr. Spitzer's charities bureau has discovered. It merged two databases late last year and recently found that one in four of the 48,000 charities it oversees had failed to meet the requirements of annual registration in one way or another.
But Mr. Josephson said the office could not spare the number of employees that were needed to pull 12,000 files, and each of 12,000 letters would have to be separately typed. Never mind the logistics of handling the responses.
He has proposed hiring temporary workers because he thinks the revenues that dunning the delinquents will bring in will more than cover those costs.

HEADLINE: Well-Observed Waiting, And a Fruitful First Play 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Tristine Skyler is intrigued by waiting rooms. Her first film, "Getting to Know You," was set in a bus station waiting room. Her first play, "The Moonlight Room," which opened earlier this month at the TriBeCa Playhouse, takes place in a hospital waiting room.
 "Ilike writing about waiting rooms," Ms. Skyler said in a recent interview. "I like the blank stage that a waiting room can be." 
 The settings have served her well. "Getting to Know You," which she wrote with her older sister, Lisanne, played at the Film Forum in 2000 to enthusiastic reviews. And now "The Moonlight Room," presented by the Worth Street Theater Company and Solecist Productions, has received similarly high praise. The play's run through Nov. 24 sold out, and it has been extended through Dec. 7.
"What immediately distinguishes 'The Moonlight Room' is the quality of the conversation," said Bruce Weber in his review in The New York Times, which also welcomed "the arrival of a precocious talent." In The New York Post, Donald Lyons called the play "beautifully written" with "both heart and mind."
The play focuses on two Manhattan teenagers -- played by Laura Breckenridge and Brendan Sexton III -- who spend the night in a hospital waiting room, having brought a friend in after a drug overdose. Ms. Skyler has been working on the play on and off for nearly five years.
One might expect that a woman with a privileged background who was educated at the Chapin School in Manhattan and Princeton University would have been sheltered from many of the hardships that "The Moonlight Room" unflinchingly explores -- the street drug Special K, buying guns, a teenager locked out of his own home. Although "The Moonlight Room" is not autobiographical, Ms. Skyler, 32, said she drew on her own encounters with dysfunction as a teenager living in the Yorkville section of the Upper East Side. 
"Growing up in New York was a very vivid time in my life, something I'm able to draw on still," she said. "It was an extreme time in the best possible way. The stakes are very high when you're a teenager. Especially when you're a teenager in New York.
"Children are so much more sensitive and receptive than adults, just by nature of being young. It's no surprise some of my friends spun out of control."
Ms. Skyler waged her own small rebellions, she said, "experiencing things I needed to experience, going to nightclubs I shouldn't have been at in the first place."
To be sure, although the playwright has a fresh, youthful face, there is a gravity to Ms. Skyler, a seriousness. At the same time, she appears to have that optimism so many people in theater share, perhaps because it is a survival technique. "I've had really wonderful experiences and really difficult experiences, and they each have their impact," she said. "But this moment right now is really wonderful."
Whether she will be able to make a living as a playwright is something she cannot think about.
"Worry is the flip side of regret," she said. "So I'm not going to regret the mistakes or the difficult times. And I'm going to try not to worry about what lies ahead.
"Otherwise you would go crazy in this business. I've been unemployed since college. I took such a different path from my friends, pursued a line of work that invites instability. So I'm definitely battling self-doubt."
Ms. Skyler's family has helped build her confidence, though she supports herself financially. Her parents -- Rita Skyler, who teaches autistic children at the old Stuyvesant High School, and Martin Skyler, a criminal defense lawyer -- took her to museums, to the theater and to auditions as a child. 
Ms. Skyler has been performing since she was 6. In college, she appeared in plays like "Suddenly Last Summer" and "The Seagull." In 2000 she played the lead in the sequel to "The Blair Witch Project." Though she considered becoming a lawyer, she said, "I guess the urge to create is very hard to suppress."
Ms. Skyler also seems to draw strength from her siblings. She and Lisanne Skyler, a screenwriter in Los Angeles, collaborated on "Getting to Know You," which was adapted from three short stories by Joyce Carol Oates and featured Bebe Neuwirth and Chris Noth.
Her younger brother, Edward Skyler, who is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's press secretary, came to Princeton to see her thesis presentation. He contributed some of his own money to "The Moonlight Room," urged his friends to see it and brought Deputy Mayor Patricia E. Harris and Cultural Affairs Commissioner Kate D. Levin on opening night. "I don't take it lightly," Ms. Skyler said of her brother's efforts. "It means the world to me."
The play started as a reading in August 2001 produced by the New Group Theater in Manhattan. A year later, the Group at Strasberg, a theater company in Los Angeles, staged a workshop of it. Ms. Skyler's boyfriend, Matthew Brown, a writer and director, gave the play to his lawyer, James Adams, who serves on the board of Worth Street. Mr. Adams passed it on to Jeff Cohen, Worth Street's artistic director. "I couldn't put it down," Mr. Cohen said. 
"The underpinning of it was a page turner," he added. "I wanted to know what happened to these people."
The theater company is a scrappy enterprise, one that suffered after Sept. 11 because of its proximity to ground zero. Mr. Cohen, who directed "The Moonlight Room," also takes tickets. Ms. Skyler helped with fund-raising, bought hair dye for the lead actress and vacuumed the theater.
She tries not to dwell on how her work will be received, she said, adding: Nobody knows me, so I'm not trying to live up to any expectations. I'm just working from an internal place."
Ms. Skyler said she didn't want to write just a narratively compelling drama, but one with a larger purpose. "I think it's important for entertainment to at least consider its capacity to affect social and political change," she said. 
The play was informed by her research into youths at risk in the summer of 2001 at a child advocacy center in downtown Brooklyn. She also worked with Public Color, a program in which city teenagers paint their high schools.
Still, Ms. Skyler said she did not presume to be enlightening theatergoers with "The Moonlight Room"; she is merely trying to get them thinking. "I don't think I've taught anybody anything, because the play doesn't answer anything," she said. "It's just asking questions. And I feel comfortable asking questions."

HEADLINE: The Universal Cure 

BYLINE:  By Ezekiel J. Emanuel and Victor R. Fuchs; Ezekiel J. Emanuel, oncologist and bioethicist, is author of "No Margin, No Mission." Victor R. Fuchs, professor emeritus of economics at Stanford, is author of "Who Shall Live?"

 BODY:
The public has good reason to be worried about health coverage. After five years of relative stability, insurance premiums, prescription-drug prices and other costs have soared. This year, premiums went up nearly 14 percent, with those paid by employees increasing nearly 50 percent since 2000. The number of Americans without health insurance increased more than 5 percent just in the last year. And strikes by workers in Los Angeles and elsewhere show that health coverage is the flashpoint of labor discord.
 As a solution, many policymakers are advocating small reforms like a Medicare prescription drug benefit or expansion of the Children's Health Insurance Program. Unfortunately, more services for some groups may increase costs and force reductions in coverage for others. 
 What we need is a fair proposal that is simple, efficient and appealing to disparate constituencies. For more than a decade, as members of the medical and economics communities, we have advocated such an alternative: universal health care vouchers. 
In a morally responsible country, everyone should have health insurance. Each family or individual would be given a voucher to purchase a policy that covered basic services, including doctor visits, hospitalization, pharmacy benefits, some mental health and dental care, and catastrophic coverage. People who want more services, like wider choices of specialists, could pay a premium over the basic voucher. 
This would continue to be a decentralized system with existing health plans contracting with providers, but their insurance would no longer be employment-based. That Americans receive insurance from their employer is a relic of World War II wage controls. It has one advantage -- pooling people to reduce premiums -- but many disadvantages, including locking people into jobs so they can continue to receive health coverage and allowing employers to choose insurance providers. It has also become an albatross for businesses. Without costly insurance worries, companies could compete for workers by offering higher wages and better working conditions. 
A voucher system would also enable the government to end Medicaid and phase out Medicare. Having multiple health care systems squanders resources. All Medicaid recipients would receive vouchers. Each year, those who normally would become eligible for Medicare would be enrolled in the voucher plan instead. Current beneficiaries who preferred traditional coverage would not be forced to switch, although after total Medicare enrollment dropped sufficiently, the program would be amalgamated into the voucher system.
One consistent concern about vouchers is that health plans would have financial incentives to avoid the sick. But requiring each insurance company to offer a basic package with catastrophic coverage would ensure that individuals with greater needs would not be excluded. More important, the voucher system would pay insurers part of their cost as a lump sum and part as a reimbursement fee for actual services rendered, reducing the incentive for insurers to avoid sick patients.
A national health policy board would administer the system, including certifying health plans and insurance companies, managing the vouchers and payments and collecting and disseminating data on the quality of care.
The United States now spends about $1.4 trillion annually on health care. The government already pays about 45 percent of that. In 2003, the average health insurance premium for a family of four is about $9,000. Using that figure and population numbers, a universal health care voucher system would cost about $840 billion, excluding Medicare. That would leave substantial sums for people to pay for out-of-pocket expenses and services not in the basic package.
More important, using an earmarked tax to pay for the vouchers would limit cost increases. The level of the tax would determine the value of the voucher. If the public began demanding an increase in the voucher value, it would be directly linked to higher taxes, moderating these demands and health care inflation.
Obviously, many details need to be elaborated. Nevertheless, vouchers hold the promise of securing wide support. Democrats have long favored the notion of universality, while Republicans instinctively favor voucher plans and have longed for the demise of Medicare and Medicaid. Businesses want to stop providing health insurance, and Americans want guaranteed health coverage with choice.
With the inexorable explosion in health care costs and the increase in the number of uninsured, a crisis is at hand. The universal health care voucher can secure both widespread support and finally establish a fair, functional health care system in the United States.

HEADLINE: Miami Girds For Protests At Trade Talks 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 17 

 BODY:
This city's downtown was nearly deserted on Monday as police and government officials prepared for an international trade meeting that is likely to draw thousands of protesters, some threatening the same violent tactics that crippled a World Trade Association meeting in Seattle in 1999.
 As cruise ships and federal court proceedings were diverted to Fort Lauderdale for the week, some shops and restaurants boarded their windows and office workers navigated closed-off streets and police barricades, trade officials from 34 nations began arriving for the first high-level trade talks held in the United States since the Seattle meeting. 
 The topic is whether, and how, to create a free trade zone stretching from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego. The idea is embraced by many corporate leaders but reviled by labor unions and low-wage workers, who say ending tariffs would eliminate countless American jobs. 
While trade negotiations will not begin in earnest until Thursday, business leaders and civic groups began meeting here on Monday to come up with recommendations for the trade ministers. Law enforcement officers took to the streets on horses, bikes and foot, making final preparations for an event they have been training for all year.
As of late Monday afternoon, the police had arrested five protesters, for blocking a downtown sidewalk. All of the department's roughly 1,000 officers are on 12-hour shifts, a police spokeswoman said, and many more officers, on loan from departments throughout Florida, will join them. City officials say most of the $12 million cost of playing host to the event involves security.
The stakes are high for Miami because it is hoping to be chosen as the headquarters for the Free Trade Association of the Americas, a distinction that would help its economy and give it more international clout. Miami is marketing itself as perfect for the headquarters because of its large Latin American population, the hundreds of daily flights between here and Latin American cities, and Florida's status as one of the top trade partners for most of the 34 nations in the trade pact.
But Miami is competing with eight other cities, including Atlanta; Panama City; Port-of-Spain, Trinidad; and Cancun, Mexico. And Florida's powerful sugar and citrus industries are vehemently opposed to ending trade tariffs, because doing so would threaten their existence by sharply increasing competition from Brazil and other Latin American countries.
At the moment, though, officials fear that the biggest threat to Miami's bid for the headquarters is the potential for violent protests now. Critics of the intense police presence, including the American Civil Liberties Union, say it is an overzealous effort to prove that Miami can keep protesters under control.
Most protest groups, including the A.F.L.-C.I.O., have promised to use only nonviolent tactics.
"The anarchists, do they concern us?" said Fred Frost, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. of South Florida, referring to small, secretive groups that have used violence at other trade meetings. "Yes. But the A.F.L.-C.I.O. will have peacekeepers in the area to try to maintain order. We love this community, and we're here to help protect it."
Civil rights groups are incensed about an ordinance the Miami City Commission passed last week barring a range of potential weapons from public gatherings that some civil liberty experts say violates free-speech rights.
The ordinance prohibits protest groups of more than six people from carrying glass bottles, water guns, pieces of wood more than a quarter-inch thick, guns and "any length of metal, plastic or other similar hard or stiff material."
Lida Rodriguez-Taseff, president of the Miami branch of the American Civil Liberties Union, said the large police presence was a dangerous tool in Miami's quest to win the trade headquarters. "When you use your police force to carry out your political whim," she said, "that is when you have a recipe for disaster."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 20, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the expectation of protests at an international trade meeting in Miami misstated the name of the group that faced violent protests in Seattle in 1999. It is the World Trade Organization, not Association.

HEADLINE: Hepatitis Inquiry Moves Deliberately From Farm to Plate 

BYLINE:  By LYDIA POLGREEN; Sherri Day contributed reporting for this article from New York. 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 

 BODY:
At first, it just seemed like a nasty case of the flu. Jeff Cook, a 38-year-old unemployed auto mechanic, felt achy and nauseated, so he took some over-the-counter pain medicine and got some rest.
 A couple of weeks earlier, about Oct. 6, he had eaten a plate of chicken and beef fajitas with his wife, Christine, and their two daughters, at the Chi-Chi's Restaurant at the Beaver Valley Mall not far from their home in West Aliquippa, about 20 miles northwest of here. There was no reason to suspect any connection. 
 Less than a month after he ate that meal, Mr. Cook was at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center suffering from acute liver failure. Surgeons transplanted a liver flown in from California, Mrs. Cook said in an interview on Monday, but his other organs were shutting down.
"They did everything they could to try and save him," Mrs. Cook said. "But it was too late."
Liver failure brought on by hepatitis A, a usually nonfatal viral infection, killed Mr. Cook on Nov. 7. He became the first person to die in what federal health officials say is the biggest food-borne outbreak of hepatitis A in the United States.
Two others have died since then and more than 500 people have become infected. Health officials are looking at similar but smaller outbreaks in Tennessee, Georgia, North Carolina and Ohio to see if they are related. 
State officials in Pennsylvania and federal officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration are trying to pin down the source of the infection that has struck Beaver County, which includes a string of working-class towns along the Ohio River 20 miles northwest of Pittsburgh. 
"We have not identified any specific food source," Dr. Calvin B. Johnson, secretary of the Pennsylvania Health Department, said at a news conference here on Monday. "We hope to get lab results soon that will identify whether it came from a food source" rather than being passed from a person infected with the virus, which is the most common method of transmission.
Dr. Johnson said that no new cases had been confirmed since Saturday, holding the number of people sickened at 510. State officials said the number of new infections might rise because the incubation period for the virus is about a month, and the restaurant closed on Nov. 2. So far most cases that resulted in illness appear to have involved people who ate at the restaurant in early October. 
Nearly 9,000 people have received immune globulin injections that can prevent infection if administered within 14 days of exposure. Nearly 10,000 have been tested for the virus. 
So far the best guess for what killed Jeff Cook and two others and sickened hundreds is green onions. Investigators suspect the onions could be the culprits because they have been linked to outbreaks of hepatitis A in three other states.
Even if they do conclusively link the Beaver Valley outbreak to scallions, tracking the ultimate source of the infection will not be easy. Agriculture distribution is a complex business that involves many sets of hands, health officials said. 
"It could have happened anywhere between the farm and the person's plate, and there are a lot of steps in that process," said Richard Quartrone, a spokesman for the Georgia Division of Public Health, which contended with a hepatitis A outbreak in September and early October that sickened 250 people who ate green onions. 
As for the outbreak here, officials at Prandium Inc., the California company that owns Chi-Chi's, worked to reassure customers at their hundreds of restaurants across the country that their food is safe. Chi-Chi's, based in Louisville, Ky., is considered one of the first restaurant chains to introduce standardized Mexican fare to the American public.
A spokesman for the company said that Chi-Chi's had taken "extraordinary" measures voluntarily to ensure the safety of its food, including removing green onions from all of its 100 restaurants. The spokesman said that the Beaver Valley Mall location had received scores of 90 percent or higher and one perfect score in its last four health inspections.
Twelve employees of the Chi-Chi's branch in Beaver Valley tested positive for hepatitis A and are being treated, said the spokesman, who would not give his name or provide any other company representative who would allow himself to be quoted by name. 
As the company sought to reassure customers, families like the Cooks wondered how something as simple as a visiting a popular chain restaurant could bring so much pain. The Cooks chose Chi-Chi's because their 10-year-old daughter, Cassandra, liked eating there. 
It was a fateful choice. The couple's 8-year-old daughter, Courtney, does not like Mexican food, Mrs. Cook said, so she had a hot dog and French fries. Cassandra, who had the chicken burrito, also contracted hepatitis A, but she has recovered.
A few weeks after eating at the restaurant Mr. Cook began to feel sick, said Mrs. Cook, who did not become ill. 
"He would have aches, run low-grade fever, then it would go away," said Mrs. Cook, who is an emergency room nurse at a local hospital. But on Nov. 2, his fever spiked to 104 degrees, so Mrs. Cook took him to the emergency room,where he tested positive for hepatitis A. 
Doctors told the Cooks that the disease was not usually fatal and would run its course.
But Mr. Cook got worse. His fever and nausea increased, and by the second day he had become jaundiced and seemed confused. "He was brushing his teeth without toothpaste, stuff like that," Mrs. Cook said.
She took him back to the hospital, where it became clear that he had serious liver problems. Doctors transferred him to the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, a well-known transplant hospital. By Friday, surgeons had given Mr. Cook another liver, but it was too late.
Now the family mourns the sudden death of an energetic father. Because Mr. Cook was laid off from his job at an auto body shop, he had spent much time with his daughters while his wife worked.
"He was so close to the girls, he just lived for them," Mrs. Cook said.
The impact of the hepatitis outbreak on the Chi-Chi's chain is likely to be substantial, restaurant industry experts say.
"It's not like a month later everything is back to being fine again," said Dennis Lombardi, executive vice president of Technomic Inc., a Chicago food service consulting firm. "It doesn't work that way. In a minor case, like salmonella, that's going to have a very minor impact. But when it's a case where there are deaths involved, that's a different story."

HEADLINE: Medicare Compromise Plan Won't Cut Costs, Critics Say 

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON and MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Critics of the Medicare plan devised by Congressional leaders said yesterday that it contained little in the way of mechanisms to slow the runaway costs of drugs and medical services even as it provided tens of billions of dollars for hospitals, health plans, employers, doctors and the drug industry.
 With the full details of the proposal not yet public, some policy analysts also expressed doubt that the compromise, reached over the weekend, would stay within the 10-year, $400 billion cost that Congress allotted to a Medicare overhaul. The legislation would provide a prescription drug benefit for the first time to 40 million disabled and elderly Americans. 
 "There's something here for everybody," said Ira Loss, who follows the health-care industry for Washington Analysis, a service for investors. The legislation, he said, "is a classic election-year giveaway, a year early." 
The legislation would give employers $70 billion or more in subsidies to discourage them from dropping health coverage for their retirees. Private health plans would receive roughly $15 billion to persuade them to assume a much larger role under Medicare, in particular providing the new drug coverage. Hospitals, particularly in rural areas, could expect about $20 billion in added payments, and doctors -- who were facing lower Medicare reimbursements -- would instead receive a small increase. 
Many consumer groups have been critical of the proposed legislation as it worked its way through Congress, complaining that health-care companies are the only clear beneficiaries, and they renewed their criticisms yesterday.
"At the top of the list is the pharmaceutical industry, which seems to have managed to escape any effort to rein in what they charge consumers," said Gail Shearer, a health policy expert at Consumers Union. 
But the plan that emerged from a House-Senate conference committee has won support from many crucial constituents, including employers. "We are bringing the Medicare program into the 21st century," said Helen Darling, the president of the Washington Business Group on Health, a national group of large employers based in Washington, who cautioned that she had not yet seen the details of the proposal. 
On a down day for stocks, indexes of health care stocks were down slightly less than the broader market.
Lawmakers sought to ensure that the bill would not prompt employers to eliminate superior drug benefits now offered to retirees. The subsidies designed to meet that goal appear to have played an important role in persuading AARP, the influential lobbying group for the elderly, to endorse the legislation yesterday. 
The legislation is also designed to push health insurers to provide stand-alone drug coverage that would not include coverage for hospital care and physician services, a product that does not now exist. Health plans have backed away from offering H.M.O.-style coverage under Medicare, complaining that the government's payments have failed to keep pace with their costs. But the legislation would raise their payments even before the drug benefit takes effect in 2006, and the health plans' trade group said the proposal leveled the playing field with traditional Medicare. 
Paul Heldman, an analyst with Charles Schwab Capital Markets, said the industry appeared to win the most attractive provisions from both the House and Senate versions of the bill. 
But some policy experts questioned whether the compromise struck by the conferees -- in hopes of winning votes both from House conservatives who favor robust private competition for Medicare and Senate liberals who want to defend the traditional program -- would spur much competition. 
It entitles health plans to payments roughly equivalent to those under the traditional fee-for-service program. And even if the plans find ways to save money, beneficiaries who choose to stay in traditional Medicare would not face the threat of significantly higher premiums, said Len Nichols, an executive with the Center for Studying Health System Change, a research group in Washington. 
"As an economist, I don't see a great deal of pressure for competition," he said.
Rural hospitals and doctors would also reap significant benefits from the bill, analysts said, with roughly $25 billion earmarked for them. The legislation would also increase payments by about $400 million for teaching hospitals, which often are located in big cities. 
For drug makers, the legislation, by subsidizing drug purchases for Medicare beneficiaries, appears to promise access to new customers without posing a threat of price controls, analysts said. The industry also would duck the threat that drug imports could be legalized, because the compromise measure allows government officials to cite safety concerns as a reason to bar imports.
"It's a net-net positive for the industry," said Jon Fisher, a money manager for Fifth Third Bank. He warned, however, that "overt price controls will continue to be a concern" to drug companies, as prices continue to rise. 
Analysts said there were provisions in the Medicare bill that would hurt some providers. 
Under intense lobbying from hospital trade groups, lawmakers agreed on an 18-month moratorium on construction of specialty hospitals and expansion of existing ones, while Congress studies whether such facilities hurt general hospitals by skimming the most profitable patients. 
Lawmakers also tightened reimbursements in some areas like durable medical equipment and drugs administered in doctors' offices where Medicare has been found to pay much more than other purchasers. And pharmacists worried that the bill would push more business to pharmacy benefit managers' mail-order operations.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
Fewer Airline Passengers, But More-Crowded Planes

BYLINE:  By ALINA TUGEND 

 BODY:
Randy Kabrich, a broadcasting consultant from Tampa who flies more than 250,000 miles a year, has been pulled off a plane twice in the last six months because there were too many passengers and not enough seats.
 Even though he is an Executive Platinum customer with American Airlines, Mr. Kabrich says, he was bumped by the airline in July after boarding a flight in Dallas for Tampa. He was put on a flight two hours later. 
 A few months later, he was bumped again, this time twice in quick succession on a Tampa-to-Dallas flight. First, after waiting more than two hours to board and being upgraded to first class, he was told a family whose confirmed first-class seats had been canceled by mistake had priority. Then, he was told his original coach seat had gone to somebody else. He ended up on the next plane out, which was diverted to Oklahoma City. 
 "The trip finally ended after 13 hours," Mr. Kabrich said. After he complained, the airline offered him "three electronic upgrade units" on his frequent flier card, he said.
 Commercial airlines are suddenly becoming crowded, and never mind that fewer people have been flying since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, with domestic and international traffic down to 640 million passengers in 2002 from 710 million in 2000, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. Their numbers have been picking up as the economy has heated up, but that alone does not explain the increasingly jammed conditions.
 Just as important, cash-short domestic airlines have taken both 747 wide-body jetliners and narrow-body planes like the Boeing 727 out of service since Sept. 11, according to Back Aviation Solutions, an industry consulting company in New Haven, and have replaced them with smaller regional jets that seat about 50 people, if they have replaced them at all.
 As a result, the domestic "load factor" -- the number of passengers actually flying on a plane -- increased to 74.2 percent in the third quarter of this year from 71.4 percent before Sept. 11, meaning that the average number of empty seats on a 150-seat jet has decreased to 39 from 43. Even though that rise may look small, it is not, because "it's very difficult to raise load factors," said John Weber, vice president for sales and services at Back Aviation. "Airlines are becoming much more effective and efficient at matching capacity to demand on flights."
 And so more people are getting bumped off planes -- or in some cases, never getting on. Ask Joseph T. Cestaro, a frequent flier with Delta, Northwest and Alaska Airlines, about that.
 "Seats are often impossible to come by on some routes and we're willing to pay first class," said Mr. Cestaro, chief executive of Debt Reduction Services, a nonprofit money-management firm in Boise, Idaho. About a month ago, he says, he was barely able to catch a flight home from Salt Lake City on a Sunday. "Absolutely every Delta Connection flight was overbooked, as were Horizon and Alaska, and there was not a seat to be had until 10 p.m.," he said.
 Even when he does get a ticket, he often has to stuff himself into a commuter plane, which he likens to flying in a coffin. "The level of discomfort is horrendous on these planes," said Mr. Cestaro, who is 6 feet tall. "You've got to be like a twig."
 The current space squeeze resulted more from the dot.com collapse and subsequent weak economy than anything else, said Mr. Weber of Back Aviation. At the height of the Internet boom, airlines could get away with charging "astronomical" business-class fares, he said, but now they have to cram people in to make flights profitable.
 Even on bigger jets, the days are long gone when a business traveler with frequent flier status can count on an empty middle seat -- a perk that a passenger like Celeste Diaz Ferraro misses. Ms. Diaz Ferraro, a communications director for the Puerto Rico Federal Affairs Administration, splits her time between Washington and Dallas, so she likes to use an airplane for a mobile office. Only she no longer can.
 "I'm not a large person, but all the extra room meant I needed a little extra space to spread out, which was never a problem, despite the fact that I am a government employee and can't fly first class," Ms. Diaz Ferraro said. That is because American Airlines, which she almost always flies, used to block out a middle seat for its elite fliers, she said. 
 An American Airlines spokeswoman said that was true unless the plane was full; she said the policy had changed, and although frequent fliers could request aisle or window seats, empty middle seats were no longer an option. 
 And forget those free upgrades. Ms. Diaz Ferraro said she used to get them all the time from ticket agents at the airport "who remembered my cheerful face from all the bleary-eyed 6 a.m. flights." Now, they are so busy they barely have time to look up and have fewer upgrades to offer anyway, she says.
 With planes more packed, frequent fliers have had to change all sorts of onboard habits. Kathy Sudeikis, who works for the Kansas-based travel agency All About Travel, says she has stopped putting on makeup on board because there is not enough room to maneuver. And Alin Boswell, a flight attendant for 15 years with US Airways, has noticed a lot more silent jousting among passengers. "The fight over the armrest between two grown adults is hysterical," he said. And he has had to increase his vigilance at the bathroom in the first-class compartment to enforce a ban on lines that run back to the cockpit. He says he gets lots of dirty looks and even unpleasant comments from passengers he orders back to their seats.
 Mr. Boswell says he has also witnessed the evaporation of the good will that flourished right after the terrorist attacks. "That lasted for about three weeks," he said. "It used to be, 'God bless you.' Now it's, 'Why did it take you so long?"'
 The problem is not just full planes, it is also thin staffs, said Dawn Deeks, a spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants, which represents 40,000 employees at 26 airlines. 
 "Domestic flights that used to be staffed by 8 are now staffed by 5," she said. "International flights that used to be staffed by 11 or 12 flight attendants are now down to 7 or 8." Consequently, she said, "Safety and security come first and the little niceties aren't there."
 Planes are bursting with luggage as well -- to the consternation of frequent fliers who reminisce about the abundance of storage space in the good old days of just a few months ago. "When a plane is 100 percent full, if I'm in the fifth or sixth row and everyone starts to put their baggage on board wherever, I have to put my stuff all the way in the back," complained Kevin Mitchell, chairman of the Business Travel Coalition. "Then I have to wait until everyone gets off and walk to the back -- then I'm the last to get off. The system wasn't designed to support this kind of load factor."
 The overhead-bin issue can only get worse, as passengers trundle on with heavy coats, hats and scarves. "I've definitely seen people fight over overhead space," Mr. Boswell, the flight attendant, said. "It's the end of the world for some people not getting a space above their seat."

HEADLINE: U.S. Businesses Post Increase In Inventories 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 

 BODY:
The nation's businesses, which have been keeping their inventories fairly lean, increased the supplies of unsold goods in September for the first time in six months, the Commerce Department reported on Monday. 
 The report said that business inventories rose 0.3 percent, a turnaround from a 0.4 percent drop in August. September's increase was the first since March, when businesses also increased their supplies at warehouses and back lots by 0.3 percent. Economists had expected inventories to be flat. 
 "With inventories swinging over to now showing increases, a watershed has been reached," said Ken Mayland, president of ClearView Economics. "Inventories will be a major part of the 2004 economy story, along with a capital spending boom and swelling exports."
 In another encouraging sign, September's increase in inventories came even as business sales rose 0.6 percent, in contrast to a 0.3 percent decline in August.
 Economists hope that business owners will feel more certain about the sustainability of the economic rebound and will continue to increase inventories, a development that can bode well for growth.
 After a long and severe drought in capital investment, some businesses are slowly increasing such spending and adding jobs -- two ingredients that must continue for a recovery to last. Low short-term interest rates, along with the income tax credit, helped provide strength during the summer. Many economists expect the Federal Reserve to maintain its benchmark short-term rate at 1 percent at its last meeting of the year in December, and into part of 2004. 
 In September, wholesalers increased inventories by 0.4 percent and sales rose 0.5 percent. Retailers increased inventories 1 percent as sales dipped 0.3 percent. At factories, inventories dropped 0.4 percent and sales increased 1.4 percent.
 The overall economy grew at an annual pace of 7.2 percent in the third quarter, the best performance in nearly two decades. There is a chance that September's increase in inventories could nudge up the second estimate of that quarter's growth, some economists said. It is to be announced on Nov. 25.
 Economists project that growth is slowing this quarter to an annual pace around 4 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Honolulu; 
The Line To Paradise Begins Here

BYLINE:  By MARK A. STEIN 

 BODY:
More than two-thirds of Hawaii's jobs are clustered around Honolulu. Tourism dominates the economy, but the state is trying to diversify into trade and banking -- promoting its location between the West Coast and Asia -- and also into technology, though that effort is hampered by a lack of venture capital.

AIRPORT
 HONOLULU INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT is busy, and passengers have reported long delays in getting to gates, particularly in the interisland terminal.
The airport is building a new security checkpoint in the overseas terminal to shorten the lines.
 To cut congestion on runways, the federal government recently designated Kalaeloa Airport, the former Barbers Point Naval Air Station, as a "reliever airport." It will receive diverted private aircraft from Honolulu.
 David Frisbie, a speaker and consultant in San Diego, praised airport workers and airline employees as friendly and helpful.
 "Apart from high humidity in the airport and the fact that Northwest's World Club closes too early, we've had good fortune at Honolulu," he said. Cab fare to Waikiki is about $25.

HOTELS
 The IHILANI RESORT AND SPA (808-679-0079, $354 to $549), a Marriott hotel, is considered by many to be the best hotel on the island, with spectacular views and excellent service. But it is a half-hour -- more in rush hour -- west of downtown.
 Close to the convention center downtown and away from honeymooners on the beach, is the ALA MOANA (808-955-4811, $125 to $225). It has set aside seven floors for business travelers, including a separate check-in desk and access to the business center and its computers, printers, fax machine, videocassette player and private meeting room.
 The AQUA BAMBOO (808-922-7777, $145 to $235), a recently renovated boutique hotel, "is a very short distance to International Market, a hop from Waikiki beach," said Dieu-Le Pham, an analyst for the John Deere Company in Moline, Ill.
 "Parking is $10 a night," she added, "the price is very affordable, the rooms are clean and it is a walking distance to the zoo, park and the aquarium."

RESTAURANTS
 ALAN WONG'S (808-949-2526, $120 for dinner for two, including wine and tip), on the top floor of an office building on South King Street, is popular for its elegant dining room and exotic menu -- shrimp pork hash, for example, or Madras kimchee fish curry. Beef and duck are also available.
 "Ask for directions or be sure the cab driver knows where it is," advises Judy Guffey, who retired as a college employment adviser last year. "You can miss it otherwise."
 CHEF MAVRO (808-944-4714, $200) combines Hawaiian and French cuisine, producing dishes like Hawaiian bouillabaisse. "Pricey and worth it," Ms. Guffey said.
 LA MER (808-923-2311, $180), in the Halekulani Hotel, has two dining rooms -- one seats 16 people, the other about 22 -- that open to the ocean and serve a prix fixe menu as well as a la carte seafood and steaks.
 "Sunset cocktails with Hawaiian music," Ms. Guffey said. "Even the staff stops to watch it go down some days." Reservations are essential.

ENTERTAINMENT
 DUKE'S RESTAURANT AND CANOE CLUB (808-922-2268) is a beachfront restaurant that serves burgers and sandwiches, but the real draws are the music and the patio sunsets.
 "Duke's is where you want to go for activities on the beach -- drink, watch football, have dinner with an ocean view, meet people, and have a blast," Ms. Pham said.
 SOCIETY OF SEVEN, in the main showroom of the Outrigger Waikiki Hotel (808-922-6408), is an improvisational revue blending comedy sketches, music and celebrity impersonations. Not to everyone's taste, but fun for people in the right mood.

ON YOUR OWN
 Exhibitions at the BISHOP MUSEUM (808-847-3511), the state cultural museum, range from earnest offerings like "Pohaku: The Art and Architecture of Stonework in Hawaii" to "Scream Machines: The Science of Roller Coasters." 
 At the POLYNESIAN CULTURAL CENTER (808-293-3333), islanders re-enact war dances and wedding ceremonies, carve tiki figures and twirl fire knives. At night, 100 singers and dancers perform an authentic display of Polynesian culture.
 The U.S.S. ARIZONA MEMORIAL (808-422-0561) at Pearl Harbor is free, and very popular. At peak periods in summer, there can be a wait to get in, and tickets to the free movie can be exhausted before noon. It is about 45 minutes from Waikiki by bus or taxi.
 To combine exercise and sightseeing, hike up DIAMOND HEAD, the extinct 760-foot volcano overlooking the city (state parks information: 808-587-0300). 
 The trail, paved almost the entire way, is classified as easy to moderate, though it can be steep in spots. It takes about an hour and a half. There are parking and toilets at the trailhead. Bring a flashlight, water and a camera.

BUSINESS LORE
 Government investigators recently criticized the Pentagon for not doing enough to curb fraud, waste and abuse by employees using government credit cards for travel.
 One of the more egregious examples they found was a civilian Defense Department employee who flew himself and three family members in first and business class when they moved to Honolulu from London.
 The premium-fare tickets, which no one had authorized, cost almost $21,000, compared with $2,500 for comparable coach-class tickets.

This feature about places to stay, eat and visit in leading business destinations appears every Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
WorldMarkets Decline; Fear of More Terrorism a Factor

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
New fears of terrorism sent stock markets tumbling around the world yesterday and extended the sell-off on Wall Street into a second week.
 United States investors reacted to market declines in Japan and Europe after reports that an obscure terrorist group linked to Al Qaeda had claimed responsibility for weekend bombing attacks in Turkey and had named Japan and other United States allies as potential targets. But analysts said some of the market's slide was because of normal profit-taking. 
 The Dow Jones industrials plunged more than 160 points before regaining ground late in the session, despite a better-than-expected report on business inventories and news that several companies were in merger talks. 
 "This market is vulnerable to good news, bad news or no news, so certainly the news of terrorist activity over the weekend and new threats from Al Qaeda will provoke a reaction," said Alfred E. Goldman, chief market strategist at A.G. Edwards & Sons. "But I do not see a serious downside from here; there's too much good going on."
 The Dow ended the day down 57.85 points, or 0.6 percent, at 9,710.83, after a decline last week of 0.4 percent.
 The broader market indexes also fell. The Nasdaq composite index closed down 20.65 points, or 1.1 percent, at 1,909.61, after a weekly drop of 2.1 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 6.72 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 1,043.63, after falling 0.3 percent last week.
 In Tokyo, government leaders shrugged off the latest terrorist threats, but the Nikkei 225-stock average lurched to a three-month low after the reports about Al Qaeda, closing down 3.7 percent.
 European markets followed. The CAC-40 of France lost 2.6 percent, the FTSE 100 of Britain fell 1.3 percent and the DAX index of Germany was down 3.2 percent.
 A Commerce Department report showed America's businesses increased their stockpiles of unsold goods in September for the first time in six months, a sign that companies may be feeling more confident about the recovery. Economists were expecting inventories to be flat in September.
 Financial services companies were under pressure related to the investigation of mutual fund trading practices. Morgan Stanley, which saw earlier declines, gained 9 cents to close at $55.03 after federal regulators said it had agreed to change some trading practices and pay a $50 million penalty to settle charges.
 Several companies were in merger talks but that did little to raise the major indexes.
 Travelers Property Casualty announced that it would combine with the St. Paul Companies in a $16 billion stock deal. St. Paul was up 97 cents at $37.74 on the news. Travelers' Class A shares were unchanged at $16.03; Class B shares fell 2 cents to $16.04.
 Also, the auto parts maker ArvinMeritor said it would increase its hostile takeover bid for Dana. ArvinMeritor lost 12 cents, falling to $17.94; Dana dropped $1.41, or 8.5 percent, to close at $15.24.
 And Sun Microsystems announced that it was planning a partnership with Advanced Micro Devices, an alliance that could help the two smaller companies better compete against larger producers like Intel. Sun lost 2 cents to close at $4.08. AMD fell 50 cents to $17.36, and Intel shed 57 cents to close at $32.23.

Treasury Prices Climb
By Reuters
 Treasury prices rose yesterday as investors fled sliding stocks and sought safety in bonds, pushing benchmark yields down to six-week lows. A round of profit-taking pulled the market back from its best levels, however. Analysts said investors were reluctant to push yields (which move in the opposite direction of bond prices) lower as long as evidence points to a recovery. 
 "It's a pretty straightforward case of weak equities helping bonds, but there's still the feeling that we're running up against some kind of a brick wall and that's why prices were unable to push a whole lot higher," said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at Banc One Capital Markets.
 By late in the day, the benchmark 10-year note gained 7/32, to 100 15/32; its yield fell to 4.19 percent from 4.22 percent on Friday.
