HEADLINE: CHINA SET TO ACT ON FUEL ECONOMY 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: GUANGZHOU, China, Nov. 17 

 BODY:
The Chinese government is preparing to impose minimum fuel economy standards on new cars for the first time, and the rules will be significantly more stringent than those in the United States, according to Chinese experts involved in drafting them.
 The new standards are intended both to save energy and to force automakers to introduce the latest hybrid engines and other technology in China, in hopes of easing the nation's swiftly rising dependence on oil imports from volatile countries in the Middle East. 
 They are the latest and most ambitious in a series of steps to regulate China's rapidly growing auto industry, after moves earlier this year to require that air bags be provided for both front-seat occupants in most new vehicles and that new family vehicles sold in major cities meet air pollution standards nearly as strict as those in Western Europe and the United States. 
 Some popular vehicles now built in China by Western automakers, including the Chevrolet Blazer, do not measure up to the standards the government has drafted, and may have to be modified to get better gas mileage before the first phase of the new rules becomes effective in July 2005. 
 The Chinese initiative comes at a time when Congress is close to completing work on a major energy bill that would make no significant changes in America's fuel economy rules for vehicles. The Chinese standards, in general, call for new cars, vans and sport utility vehicles to get as much as two miles a gallon of fuel more in 2005 than the average required in the United States, and about five miles more in 2008. 
 This country's economy is booming, and a growing upper class in big cities like this one is rapidly buying all the accouterments of a prosperous Western life, including cars. As China burns more fossil fuels, both in factories and in a rapidly growing fleet of motor vehicles, its contribution to global warming is also rising faster than any other country's.
 But Zhang Jianwei, the vice president and top technical official of the Chinese agency that writes vehicle standards, said in a telephone interview on Monday that energy security was the paramount concern in drafting the new automotive fuel economy rules, and that global warming had received little attention.
 "China has become an important importer of oil so it has to have regulations to save energy," said Mr. Zhang, who is also deputy secretary of the 39-member interagency committee that approved the rules at a meeting this month. 
 China was a net oil exporter until a decade ago, but its output has not kept up with soaring demand. It now depends on imports of oil for one-third of its needs, mainly from Saudi Arabia and Angola. Before the war, Iraq was also an important supplier. By comparison, the United States now imports about 55 percent of the oil it uses.
 The International Energy Agency in Paris predicts that by 2030, the volume of China's oil imports will equal American imports now. Chinese strategists have expressed growing worry about depending on a lifeline of oil tankers stretching across the Indian Ocean, through the Strait of Malacca, a waterway plagued by piracy, and across the South China Sea, protected mainly by the United States Navy. 
 Various Chinese government agencies still have three months to review the legal language in the fuel economy rules, giving automakers some time to lobby against them; as yet, there has been no mention of the approval of the new rules in the government-controlled Chinese media.
 But Mr. Zhang said that the rules in draft form were the product of a very strong consensus among government agencies and that "the technical content won't be changed."
 Two executives at Volkswagen, the largest foreign automaker in China, said that representatives of their company and of domestic Chinese automakers attended what they described as the final interagency meeting to approve the rules. Under pressure from the government, these auto industry representatives agreed to the new rules despite misgivings, the executives said. "They had no choice but to agree," one of the Volkswagen executives added. 
 The executive said that Volkswagen's vehicles would meet the first phase of the standards in 2005, while declining to comment on compliance with the second, more rigorous phase, to take effect in July 2008.
 The new standards are based on a vehicle's weight -- lighter vehicles must go the farthest on a gallon -- and on the type of transmission, with manual-shift cars required to go farther than those with less efficient automatic transmissions. 
 In a major departure from American practice, all new sport utility vehicles and minivans in China would be required to meet the same standards as automatic-shift cars of the same weight. In the United States, standards for sport utilities and minivans are much lower than for cars.
 The Chinese rules do not cover pickups or commercial trucks. According to General Motors market research, there is little demand for pickup trucks in China except from businesses, because the affluent urban consumer who can afford a new vehicle regards pickup trucks as unsophisticated and too reminiscent of the horse-drawn carts still used in some rural areas. 
 Typically, heavy vehicles are much harder on fuel than light ones, but the new Chinese standards permit the heavy vehicles to get only slightly worse gas mileage. As a result, they provide an incentive for manufacturers to offer smaller, lighter vehicles, which will be easier to design.
 The new standards would require all small cars sold in China to achieve slightly better gas mileage than the average new small car sold in the United States now gets, according to calculations by An Feng, a transportation consultant who advised the government on the rules. But officials in Beijing would require much better minimum gas mileage for minivans and, especially, S.U.V.'s than the average vehicle of either type now gets in the United States.
 American regulations call for each automaker to produce a fleet of passenger cars with an average fuel economy of 27.5 miles a gallon under a combination of city and highway driving with no traffic; window-sticker values for gas mileage, which include the effects of traffic, are about 15 percent lower. Light trucks, including vans, S.U.V.'s and pickups, are allowed an average of 20.7 miles a gallon without traffic.
 But the Bush administration has raised the standard to 22.2 miles a gallon for the 2007 model year and is reviewing whether to raise light truck limits further for 2008. It is also considering adopting different standards for different weight classes of light trucks, but only Congress can change rules for passenger cars.
 Over all, average fuel economy in the United States has been eroding since the late 1980's as automakers shifted production from cars to light trucks. It fell in the 2002 model year to the lowest level since 1980. Automakers in Europe have accepted European Union demands to increase fuel economy under different rules that could prove at least as stringent as China's minimums.
 The Chinese standards would require the greatest increases for full-size S.U.V.'s like the Ford Expedition, which would have to go as much as 29 percent farther on a gallon of fuel in 2008 than they do now in the United States, Mr. An calculated. Sport utility sales in China have more than doubled so far this year, but are still a much smaller part of the overall market than they are in the United States.
 Because the American standards are fleet averages while the Chinese standards are minimums for each vehicle, the effect of the Chinese rules could be considerably more stringent. A manufacturer can sell vehicles in the United States that are far below average in fuel efficiency if it has others in its product line that offset it by being above average. But under the Chinese rules, the fuel-inefficient models -- especially new ones introduced after the standards take effect -- would be subject to fines no matter how well their siblings do, Mr. Zhang said, and the maker would not be allowed to expand production of the gas-guzzling models. In Garrison Keillor's phrase, China plans to require that every vehicle be above average.
 Mr. An said that at the final meetings on the new rules, the only outspoken objections had come from a representative of the Beijing Automotive Industry Holding Company, which makes Jeeps in a joint venture with DaimlerChrysler.
 According to people who have seen the new standards, many Jeep models sold in China do not now comply with them; neither do the Chevrolet Blazer sport utilities built by a General Motors joint venture in Shenyang. Some of Volkswagen's car models also fall slightly short, these people said. By contrast, Honda's cars, built at a sprawling factory complex here in Guangzhou, the commercial hub of southern China, would comply easily because they use advanced engine technology, these people said.
 Trevor Hale, a DaimlerChrysler spokesman, declined to comment in detail. "DaimlerChrysler complies with local regulations where it does business," Mr. Hale said in an e-mail response to an inquiry. "It continues working to improve fuel economy in the vehicles it develops, builds and sells around the world."
 Bernd Leissner, the president of Volkswagen Asia Pacific, said that his company's cars would comply because "it's just a question of how to adapt the engine -- it's something that could be done quickly."
 The fastest way to improve fuel efficiency is to switch from gasoline to diesel engines, as Volkswagen is starting to do in China. The latest diesel engines are much cleaner than those of a decade ago, but are still more polluting than gasoline engines of similar power. 
 A spokeswoman for General Motors, which is beginning to introduce Cadillac luxury cars in China, said she did not have enough information about the newly drafted rules to comment on them, but that her company's vehicles were comparable in fuel economy to those of rival manufacturers in the same market segments. Executives of G.M. were preparing for an event in Beijing on Tuesday and Wednesday when the company plans to showcase examples of its work on gasoline-saving fuel-cell and hybrid engines for cars. 
 In the United States, G.M. has argued that tighter fuel economy rules are unnecessary because technological improvements will someday improve efficiency anyway. G.M. and other automakers have also contended in the United States that higher gasoline taxes would represent a better policy than higher gas mileage standards, because it would give drivers an economic incentive to choose more efficient vehicles and to drive fewer miles.
 China is still considering its policy on fuel taxes, but has not acted so far, because higher fuel taxes would impose higher costs on many sections of society, Mr. Zhang said.
 Another company that could run into trouble over the Chinese mileage standards is Toyota, which on Nov. 6 began selling a locally produced version of its full-size Land Cruiser sport utility vehicle in China. A spokesman said on Monday that Toyota had not yet heard about the new Chinese fuel economy regulations, which have been prepared with a level of secrecy typical of many Chinese regulatory actions.
 Japan is also phasing in new fuel efficiency rules based on weight that allow heavier vehicles only slightly worse gas mileage than lighter ones. American automakers have complained that the Japanese rules discriminate against them because Japanese automakers tend to produce slightly lighter cars anyway. 
 China has more than 100 automakers, as Detroit did a century ago, but the bulk of its output comes from a small number of joint ventures with multinational companies. Total production has more than doubled in the last three years, to about 3.8 million cars and light trucks in 2002, nearly as many as Germany. The United States builds about 12 million a year, Japan about 10 million. Chinese car output is rising so fast that even with better fuel efficiency per vehicle, oil consumption and emissions of global warming gases will keep rising.
 The cars that Chinese automakers produce on their own tend to be small and lightweight, but the engines are built on older technology and may not have an easy time complying with the fuel economy standards.
 The government has been encouraging the industry to consolidate, and the new rules may hasten that process by forcing investment in engine designs that small companies may not be able to afford on their own.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
China to Impose Standards For Fuel Economy on Cars
The Chinese government is preparing to impose minimum fuel-economy standards on new cars for the first time, and the rules will be significantly more stringent than those in the United States, according to Chinese experts involved in drafting them.
 The new standards are intended both to save energy and to force automakers to introduce the latest hybrid engines and other technology, in hopes of easing China's swiftly rising dependence on oil imports from volatile countries in the Middle East. They are the latest and most ambitious in a series of moves to regulate China's rapidly growing auto industry. Page A1. 

Newspaper Baron Quits Under Fire
Conrad M. Black, the Canadian media baron who sought to build a global collection of newspapers with a conservative bent, is quitting as chief executive and putting his company up for sale after an internal investigation disclosed that he and his partners had received $15.6 million in unauthorized payments. A sale of the company, Hollinger International, either as a whole or in parts, would likely bring to an end Lord Black's big-media ambitions. A1.

AARP Supports Medicare Bill
AARP, the largest and most influential organization of older Americans, threw its weight behind a bill that offers drug benefits to the elderly as part of the biggest transformation of Medicare in its 38-year history. A1.

Shares Fall on Terrorism Fears
New fears of terrorism sent stock markets tumbling around the world and extended the sell-off on Wall Street into a second week. The Dow ended down 57.85 points, or 0.6 percent, at 9,710.83. The Nasdaq composite index closed down 20.65 points, or 1.1 percent, at 1,909.61. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 6.72 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 1,043.63. C12.

New Copier Line From Hewlett
Hewlett-Packard is king in the land of computer printers, but for years it has eyed the nearby office copier as an enticing market to conquer. Today, the company is introducing a line of powerful printers that double as copiers, hoping to capture a sizable slice of the $24-billion-a-year copier market. C10.

Loss Widens at Toys 'R' Us
Toys "R" Us said its third-quarter loss widened because of higher overhead and stagnant sales, and it announced plans to close 182 Kids "R" Us and Imaginarium stores, eliminating up to 3,800 jobs. C4.

ArvinMeritor Raises Bid for Dana
The auto supplier ArvinMeritor made what it indicated would be its final offer for Dana, raising its hostile bid by 20 percent, to $18 a share. Dana's board is reviewing the revised offer, which now values Dana at $2.68 billion. Dana advised shareholders to wait until the board made its decision before they decided. Since the first bid, Dana's shares have consistently traded above $15. Before the offer, they sold at around $10 each. C4.

The Chrysler Group unveiled eight of its nine new or redesigned vehicles due next year, a product wave executives say will revive the company's fortunes. C4.

Europe to Examine Software Deal
The European Commission has opened an investigation into whether Oracle's hostile $7.3 billion bid to take over PeopleSoft would create a company that would dominate markets in Europe. World Business, Section W.

Not-So-User-Friendly Hotels
Some hotels, in their zeal to offer the latest in technology and amenities, have befuddled some guests. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. C9.

HEADLINE: More Action Over Fund Practices 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The oldest mutual fund company in the nation, and one of the largest, has suspended its longtime practice of directing brokerage commissions to securities firms that sell its funds or bring it new clients, according to a brokerage firm executive apprised of the change last week. 
 The move was made by MFS Investment Management, whose funds are sold exclusively by brokers at securities firms or by financial planners. The action suggests that concern is growing among fund companies that this widespread industry practice is attracting regulatory scrutiny for possible conflicts of interest. 
 A spokesman for MFS in Boston declined to comment on its directed brokerage practices. But a securities firm executive who has received directed commissions from MFS in the past said that the company instituted a 90-day moratorium on the practice last week as it tried to sort out how securities regulators' views might be changing. 
 If regulators discourage the practice, fund experts say, mutual funds sold by brokers would lose their biggest backers and be forced to compete for investor dollars on performance alone. Another possible result might be lower commissions by fund managers and a commensurate decline in mutual fund costs. More than two-thirds of funds are sold by brokers or financial advisers. 
 Yesterday, Morgan Stanley settled a suit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission and NASD, which said the firm had set up preferential arrangements with 16 mutual fund companies. Among other things, the complaint said that fund managers paid higher fees and commissions to Morgan Stanley in exchange for the firm's brokers selling those funds.
 The action was the second against Morgan Stanley in the last two months by NASD over mutual fund practices. Morgan Stanley neither admitted nor denied the allegations but agreed to pay $50 million in penalties and surrendered profits. Regulators will distribute the money to certain Morgan Stanley customers.
 "Investors expect and are entitled to informed, objective and untainted recommendations from their brokers and their firms when it comes to which mutual funds to buy," said Mary L. Schapiro, president of NASD Regulatory Policy and Oversight. "Today's enforcement actions send a clear message that those who choose to embrace commissions, higher payouts and extra bonuses over their duty to render conflict-free advice to their customers will be sanctioned in the strongest of terms."
 The suit against Morgan Stanley sheds light on the longstanding mutual fund industry practice known as directed brokerage, which occurs when portfolio managers designate that a specific brokerage firm receive commissions by executing their fund's trades. Critics call it a pay-to-play arrangement. It is similar to the deals that food companies have with supermarkets that place their products on crowded shelves for a fee.
 But such arrangements are coming under regulatory scrutiny as the mutual fund scandal spreads. NASD is conducting more than two dozen investigations involving brokerage firms that received commissions from fund managers in exchange for offering to sell their funds to the firms' clients, according to an official. These investigations include discount brokerage firms and fund distributors.
 Critics of the practice say that by directing commissions to brokers who sell fund shares, fund managers are enriching themselves at their investors' expense. That is because commission dollars paid to execute trades are an asset of the funds' investors and come right out of their pockets. When a manager uses investors' property to increase a fund's size, he or she benefits because management fees are based on the assets overseen by the manager. 
 Those who are critical of the practice also say it is one of the main reasons that mutual fund costs have remained high despite competition in the industry and economies of scale among big fund companies. By directing trades to brokers selling their funds, managers receive something in return and are therefore less likely to push securities firms to execute trades at lower commissions, critics say. 
 "A mutual fund manager is somebody who should not be a Wall Street insider," said Max Rottersman, president of FundExpenses.com, which analyzes fund costs for institutional clients. "What they should be is a representative of the fund shareholder and out to get the best performance and lowest costs possible for their trades. When they're pulling money right out of the portfolio to generate sales, they've sold their souls to the devil." 
 Mutual fund companies that direct commissions to brokers selling their funds disclose the arrangements in filings but may not specify how much money is paid under the deals. For example, a recent MFS filing stated: "Consistent with the advisory agreement and applicable rules and regulations, the adviser may consider sales of the fund and other funds or accounts of the adviser as a factor in the selection of broker-dealers to execute the fund's portfolio transactions."
 MFS is a unit of Sun Life Financial Inc., a financial services company based in Toronto. It is the oldest mutual fund company in the country, having started its first fund, the Massachusetts Investment Trust, in 1924. MFS manages roughly $100 billion for more than six million investors and has about 100 mutual fund portfolios. 
 Mutual fund watchers say that as the brokerage business consolidated in recent years, thousands of funds were pursuing shelf space on fewer and fewer brokers' shelves. This caused pay-to-play practices among funds to become much more heated. 
 "It's all part of the fund industry's attitude of assets at any cost," Mr. Rottersman said.
 NASD says it designed the rule prohibiting firms from favoring particular mutual funds on the basis of brokerage commissions to help eliminate conflicts of interest in fund sales. NASD oversees only its brokerage firm members; many mutual fund companies are not brokerage firms and are regulated by the S.E.C. 
 But even with such a rule on the NASD books, brokerage firms have received commissions in exchange for selling their funds to clients. While the rule prohibits an explicit quid pro quo, where sales of a fund's shares are promised in exchange for directed commissions from the fund, brokerage firm executives say such promises are rarely made in writing between fund companies and the firms that sell their offerings.
 Furthermore, as long as the mutual fund manager can claim that the commissions paid to the securities firm for executing the trades were in line with those charged by other firms, he or she can argue that directing the commissions did not place fund shareholders at a disadvantage.
 But regulators appear to be toughening their stance. In its suit against Morgan Stanley, NASD said that mutual fund companies paid the firm as much as 0.20 percent extra on each fund sale for the preferential treatment they received from the firm's brokers.
 This extra compensation, NASD said, included millions of dollars in commissions paid by the mutual funds to Morgan Stanley. "These commissions were sufficiently large," NASD said, "to pay for the special treatment, as well as the costs of trade execution." 
 From January 2000 until this year, regulators said, Morgan Stanley operated two programs in which it gave favorable treatment to products offered by 16 mutual fund companies. This included placement on a preferred list of funds recommended by Morgan Stanley brokers, better access to the firm's sales force and branch managers, and higher visibility on the firm's workstations compared with nonpaying funds, regulators said. 
 Stephen M. Cutler, who heads the S.E.C.'s enforcement division said: "Unbeknownst to Morgan Stanley's customers, Morgan Stanley received monetary incentives -- in the form of 'shelf space' payments -- to sell particular mutual funds to its customers. When customers purchase mutual funds, they should understand the nature and extent of any conflicts of interest that may affect the transaction." 
 The agency also claimed that Morgan Stanley brokers, in recommending different types of funds to investors, did not disclose that certain share classes carried higher fees and could have a detrimental impact on investor returns. 
 Last September, Morgan Stanley was censured and fined by NASD for promoting the sale of its own mutual funds by sponsoring sales contests among its brokers and managers. Regulators prohibit such contests. In settling that case, Morgan Stanley neither admitted nor denied the allegations.

HEADLINE: If Claude Bebear Speaks, French Companies Listen 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
When outraged shareholders ousted the chairman of the big French chemical company Rhodia last month, accusing him of gross mismanagement, the spotlight focused on a man seen as being behind the shake-up, a man with no official role at the company but with a great deal of influence in French business.
 That man is Claude Bebear, the 68-year-old chairman of the AXA insurance group, who is described alternately as one of France's foremost champions of good corporate governance or as a sinister "godfather" of old-style crony capitalism. As is often the case with companies in the news here, most of Rhodia's management and most executives at its principal shareholder, the drug company Aventis, are associates of his. 
 Mr. Bebear (pronounced bay-bay-ARE) admits to playing some role in the Rhodia shake-up: last spring, the head of a shareholders' association asked him to convey a message to the chairman, Jean-Pierre Tirouflet, and he agreed to do so. Yet he vigorously denies any pivotal role. 
 With equal force he rejects the title of godfather. "When a godfather of the mafia speaks," he said, punctuating a recent conversation with a characteristic hearty laugh, "you follow his counsels."
 (Though no one is saying exactly what the message was, speculation is that Mr. Bebear was to ask Mr. Tirouflet to leave peaceably. Five months later, Mr. Tirouflet was out.)
 In fact, Mr. Bebear's career illustrates both a penchant for cronyism and a bent for breaking with traditions of French corporate coziness. However it is seen, he has great, often behind-the-scenes, power.
 Mr. Bebear, who entertains visitors in his spacious office in the painstakingly restored 17th-century Parisian palace that is his company's headquarters, ran AXA for decades, molding it from a small, regional insurance company into a financial giant. That has given him influence in French business. Though he gave up his chief executive post three years ago, he remains AXA's chairman.
 As a young executive, he founded a discussion club, Enterprises et Cite, that now includes a sampling of the French business elite. Among them are Henri Lachmann, chairman of the big Schneider electrical products group; the chairman of Vivendi Universal, Jean-Rene Fourtou; and Thierry Breton, the France Telecom chairman. The network extends beyond finance to politics, and includes the president of the French Senate, Christian Poncelet. That gave Mr. Bebear an edge in nudging the French banking system toward greater consolidation in the late 1990's.
 Mr. Bebear was also largely responsible for AXA's -- and French finance's -- expansion overseas. In 1991, he stormed the United States with a $1 billion investment in the Equitable Life Assurance group, a business he later turned into an AXA unit. That gave him credibility in international finance and helped him install Mr. Fourtou last year as Vivendi's chairman, to replace Jean-Marie Messier, who was ousted after Vivendi was crushed by debt from an acquisition spree that involved big American deals.
 To his detractors, Mr. Bebear is a corporate puppeteer in the spirit of Ambroise Roux, who was chairman of Compagnie Generale d'Electricite and a giant of French industry in the 1980's. 
 Mr. Bebear, however, casts himself as a kind of Gallic Warren E. Buffett, committed not to capitalism's overthrow but to its improvement. 
 He supports the current drive to improve corporate governance in France, including legislation enacted last year that limits the number of boards that a corporate director can serve on and mandates board committees for auditing and executive pay, to increase corporate accountability. But he warns, "Don't fall into the excess of regulation."
 Mr. Bebear's belief in strong rules for capitalism has long been coupled with a strong sense of opportunity.
 After graduating from the prestigious Ecole Polytechnique, he went to work at a sleepy insurance company in Normandy. That company was the core for the group that would later be named AXA, built by picking up acquisitions at advantageous moments.
 His 1996 acquisition of the Union des Assurances de Paris, or UAP, the big French insurer that successive governments had used to park stakes in privatized companies considered of national interest, gave an important impetus to the dismantling of the cross-shareholdings that characterized French capitalism. At the time, French corporations regularly owned shares in each other and sent executives onto one another's boards -- cozy relationships that were until recently still reflected at Rhodia. But Mr. Bebear sold the stock that UAP owned in big corporations like Suez, the water utility, and ordered AXA executives, himself included, to adhere to strict limits on the number of board seats they accept. 
 "A board membership should cost you a month of work a year," Mr. Bebear said. "A chief executive doesn't have one month to sacrifice."
 Mr. Bebear, a conservative dresser, sports a tiny AXA pin in his lapel, a sign of his fierce loyalty to the company he created. He is also a practicing Roman Catholic and man of strong family convictions, with a wife and five children, two adopted from South Korea. 
 He and Philippe Maniere, a French journalist, wrote a book, published this spring, titled "They're Going to Kill Capitalism", which denounces recent corporate excesses. According to Mr. Maniere, Mr. Bebear is "thoughtful, though he is not an intellectual," yet "he always has good intuitions."
 His preference for action is reflected in his passion for big-game hunting and in his favorite sport, rugby. Still, to fill time after he surrendered the job of chief executive at AXA, he founded a group -- run more as a club -- called the Montaigne Institute, where people do research and give pro-business lectures. 
 Though Mr. Maniere described Mr. Bebear as "not a person to pull strings," he acknowledged that Mr. Bebear "has a network of friends." Mr. Bebear's secret, he said, seems to be not so much financial influence as negotiating change through networking. 
 After Mr. Bebear helped oust Mr. Messier from Vivendi, Mr. Messier denounced his behind-the-scenes maneuvering in his book, "My True Journal," and called Mr. Bebear "a great hunter of big cats, not only in Africa." Some people see what Mr. Bebear calls his minimal role in Rhodia as a further example of this.
 Rhodia was born in 1998, in the heady years of big mergers and acquisitions, when the French chemical giant Rhone-Poulenc, then run by Mr. Bebear's old friend Mr. Fourtou, planned a $23 billion merger of its drug business with Hoechst of Germany to form the drug company Aventis, with Mr. Fourtou as chairman. Rhone-Poulenc bundled its chemical activities into Rhodia, then in 1999 sold a 30 percent stake on the New York and Paris stock exchanges.
 Subsequent stock sales reduced the stake in Rhodia then held by Aventis, to about 15 percent. 
 Under Mr. Tirouflet, a host of factors -- including rising prices for oil, the feedstock for most Rhodia products, and Rhodia's mounting debt from acquisitions -- pushed the company deep into the red and drove down its share price. 
 In the case of Vivendi, after Mr. Bebear intervened on behalf of disgruntled shareholders, Mr. Messier was forced out and replaced by Mr. Fourtou. At Rhodia, shareholders mounted a similar rebellion last spring against Mr. Tirouflet, who for much of his career had been Mr. Fourtou's chief financial officer at Rhone-Poulenc, and minority shareholders asked Mr. Bebear to intervene. But efforts to unseat Mr. Tirouflet were beaten back at a shareholder meeting in May. Moreover, confirmation of a seat on the Rhodia board for an independent director, Edouard Stern, which had been agreed to the previous summer, was refused.
 In late May, Mr. Stern filed suit contending among other things misuse of company information, balance sheet fraud and abuse of company assets.
 Last month, Mr. Tirouflet resigned under pressure. He was replaced as chairman by another former Rhone-Poulenc executive, Yves-Rene Nanot.
 Mr. Tirouflet, who declined to be interviewed, has said that Rhodia did nothing wrong, and that he has no comment about Mr. Bebear's intervention.
 However things play out, the Rhodia story illustrates many of the excesses in the 1990's of corporate executives, their lawyers, investment banks and auditors. And the civil lawsuit set in motion by Mr. Stern, the son-in-law of the Lazard Freres chairman, Michel David-Weill, could afford a glimpse of the dark underside of French capitalism.
 For all his critics, Mr. Bebear has many loyal defenders. Among them is Andre Levy-Lang, who has known Mr. Bebear since they were students at the Polytechnique more than 40 years ago, though he himself lost a job as a result of Mr. Bebear's dealings. In 1999, Mr. Bebear strongly supported an unsuccessful $37 billion hostile bid by Banque Nationale de Paris for two rivals, Societe Generale and Paribas. Ultimately, Banque Nationale took over just Paribas, which Mr. Levy-Lang was running at the time, and Mr. Levy-Lang was muscled out. (Though Mr. Bebear failed in his goal of a three-way merger, BNP Paribas is now Europe's largest bank, by stock market valuation.)
 Mr. Levy-Lang said that Mr. Bebear's influence may be based as much on perception as reality. "You are partly the godfather if people think you're the godfather," he said.
 Over all, he added, Mr. Bebear has "a beneficial influence," stiffening others' resolve. In the case of Vivendi, when banks and other investors opposed Mr. Messier yet feared to face him down, "Basically, Bebear gave them the courage" to act, Mr. Levy-Lang said.
 Mr. Bebear is clearly uncomfortable that he has been linked to Mr. Tirouflet's ouster from Rhodia, where so many friends hold important jobs. And he concedes that filling top jobs at French corporations appears at times like a game of musical chairs. But he insists the game may soon be over, thanks in part to growing numbers of foreign managers and directors, and also because of the dissolution of the old cross-shareholdings.
 While he welcomed France's new laws on corporate governance, describing them as "moderate," he had mixed feelings about the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, the United States Congress's response to corporate financial scandals. In its favor, he said, the bill was tantamount to Congress's "slamming a fist on the table" and declaring, "I, as government, say no." But he called the bill "impracticable," saying it yielded "tons of paper and bureaucracy." The Enron debacle, he added, "would have happened under Sarbanes-Oxley."
 And ever the maverick, he rejects the notion of independent directors. Crises like those at Vivendi and Rhodia, he said, could be averted only if "shareholder meetings are more active, and directors are under pressure."

HEADLINE: Schwarzenegger Takes Oath And Vows End to Divisions 

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER and DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 17 

 BODY:
Arnold Schwarzenegger completed an unlikely odyssey on Monday, taking the oath of office as California's 38th governor after the state's historic recall election.
 Mr. Schwarzenegger, the Austrian-born movie actor and champion bodybuilder, started his new role on the steps of the State Capitol in much the same fashion as he spent the 11-week campaign to oust Gov. Gray Davis, as a bigger-than-life celebrity. 
 The remarkable scene in placid Sacramento melded all of Mr. Schwarzenegger's many worlds: the Hollywood career that he leaves behind; the Kennedy family connections that helped sharpen his political appeal; and his new career as a Republican chief executive facing the same enormous financial problems that doomed his predecessor.
So it was that Jamie Lee Curtis, Danny DeVito and Rob Reiner were in the same crowd as Eunice Shriver and Ted Costa, the antitax crusader who initiated the recall effort that Mr. Schwarzenegger rode to Sacramento.
Mr. Schwarzenegger's every word and move were captured by 130 television cameras, many broadcasting the event around the world. Vanessa Williams, Mr. Schwarzenegger's co-star in "Eraser," sang the national anthem.
As Mr. Schwarzenegger, 56, made his way to the swearing-in with his wife, Maria Shriver, and their four children, he took the hand of his son Christopher, 6, and reminded him to smile for the cameras.
"In the 40 years that I have been associated with government, this was probably the most revolutionary," Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco said when asked to describe the inauguration.
Later, in his first official act as governor, Mr. Schwarzenegger rescinded a threefold increase in the vehicle license fee. That increase, approved by Mr. Davis and the Legislature this year as part of a budget deal, helped fuel the extraordinary resentment toward Mr. Davis that culminated in his being recalled on Oct. 7.
"During the campaign," Mr. Schwarzenegger said in a statement, "I promised on Day 1 to repeal the car tax increase. Today, I am making good on that promise."
He was sworn in with his left hand on a family Bible held by Ms. Shriver, a Kennedy scion. Speaking for just 12 minutes in his inaugural address, Mr. Schwarzenegger vowed to end the partisanship that has virtually paralyzed state government. In a message in keeping with his populist campaign, he also vowed to restore confidence in government.
"This election was not about replacing one man," Mr. Schwarzenegger said before a crowd of 7,000 invited guests. "It was not about replacing one party. It was about changing the entire political climate of our state."
Mr. Schwarzenegger, who moved to the United States from Austria 35 years ago, seized the governor's chair from Mr. Davis, a lifelong politician who was driven from office by anger over Sacramento's inability to deal with fiscal and energy crises.
It was precisely one year ago on Monday that Mr. Costa, the antitax crusader, convened a meeting here to discuss a recall drive against Mr. Davis, who had just won re-election to a second term. Mr. Costa, who has been involved in state politics for 25 years, attended the ceremony on Monday, his first inauguration.
"Now Arnold Schwarzenegger gets the hot rock," Mr. Costa said. "He will have to work long and hard, a lot longer and harder than we worked."
Mr. Costa, like many recall supporters in attendance, spoke glowingly of Mr. Schwarzenegger's remarks.
"He said the magic words," Mr. Costa said. "He said the people are the boss. And he works for the people."
But others in the audience expressed disappointment with the debut. Alex Lightman, an executive from Santa Monica, said the new governor was long on rhetorical flourishes and short on specific solutions about repairing the economy.
"I love Arnold," Mr. Lightman said. "I voted for him. But people have to hold him to a standard. He doesn't get a pass."
In his address, Mr. Schwarzenegger praised Mr. Davis and his aides for a smooth transition, and Mr. Davis's hand was among the first the new governor shook after taking office. 
"With the eyes of the world upon us," Mr. Schwarzenegger said, "we did the dramatic. Now we must put the rancor of the past behind us and do the extraordinary."
Before Mr. Schwarzenegger took his oath of office, Ms. Shriver read from a Maya Angelou poem. 
Several of Mr. Schwarzenegger's Hollywood friends and co-stars were in the crowd, including Tom Arnold, Linda Hamilton and Rob Lowe, as well as Ms. Curtis, Mr. DeVito and Mr. Reiner.
But the star factor over all was quite modest. Mr. Schwarzenegger's speech, indeed the entire ceremony, was deliberately nontriumphal, his aides said. They said self-congratulation was not appropriate in the midst of a fiscal crisis and after a wrenching recall campaign. The transfer of power was officially referred to as a swearing-in, not an inaugural, and apart from three luncheons in the afternoon no celebratory balls or parties were planned.
"Obviously," said David Gilliard, a Republican strategist who helped run a main recall group, "we are all happy to be here. But people understand the gravity of the situation." 
Some Democrats took issue with the suggestion that the events were subdued. An adviser to the state Democratic Party, Bob Mulholland, said the ceremony was "good enough for King Arnold," and he complained that the tone was imperious.
"It was low key, yes," Mr. Mulholland said. "But with 7,500 tickets and V.I.P. parking."
Mr. Schwarzenegger said he was convening a session of the Legislature to address the budget crisis and propose revisions to the costly workers compensation system.
He called on members of both parties in the Democratic-controlled Legislature to work with him to improve the state's fiscal condition and business climate, which he described as the worst in the nation.
Mr. Schwarzenegger referred to his years as a bodybuilder and said training and competition had taught him that there was always a reserve of strength.
"What I learned," he said, "is that we are always stronger than we know. California is like that, too.
"Things may get harder before they get better. But I have never been afraid of the struggle."
Some Democrats predicted that the fractious Legislature would defer to Mr. Schwarzenegger, at least at first. 
"Everyone's going to give him a running start," said Senator Dean Florez, a Democrat from a district that runs from Bakersfield to Fresno. 
Mr. Costa, the recall founder, said that recall advocates were watching closely and that if Mr. Schwarzenegger did not live up to his promise, "then we will be taking him to the woodshed."
But, Mr. Costa added, it was too early for such talk.
"I think he is up to the job," Mr. Costa said. "If we are going to go down 40 miles of bad road, which we are, you want to go down in a Hummer."

Father reminded Christopher to smile for the cameras. (Photo by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For a Day, at Least, Stars Shine on Sacramento 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 17 

 BODY:
This sleepy capital town became the center of the televised world on Monday morning as Hollywood middleweights, political and financial power brokers, and more than 700 reporters from 14 countries converged on the Statehouse lawn to see Arnold Schwarzenegger sworn in as the 38th governor of California.
 There was an unmistakable esprit d'corps among the young in good suits who unashamedly smoked contraband Cuban cigars. 
 "It's O.K. because it's for personal consumption," said one young Republican, explaining that though he might have been in violation of the spirit of the anti-Castro trade embargo, he was not in violation of its letter.
Celebrity friends of Mr. Schwarzenegger, whom reporters just weeks ago disdained behind their backs as empty-headed actors and musclebound bubbleheads, were sought out for their thoughts on the state of the state and on Mr. Schwarzenegger himself, who at 11:22 a.m. became the chief executive of the most populous state in the Union. 
The actress Jamie Lee Curtis called the new governor an honorable and decent man, and offered this thought on how to manage a divided state sinking in a tsunami of red ink: "He needs to listen to his own heart and intuition and his wife. If he just kept to those three things, we'd be better off."
In taking the oath of office, Mr. Schwarzenegger, 56-year-old son of a constable in Thal, Austria, completed what he described three decades ago as his "master plan": to grow rich in the movies, marry a glamorous wife and wield political power.
His glamorous wife, Maria Shriver, a Kennedy family member and television journalist, read a poem by Maya Angelou before her husband was sworn in.
Ms. Shriver wore a long gray jacket, and underneath that a cream-colored skirt and shell from Valentino. Her choice may seem an insignificant detail but was the stuff of great speculation among the international members of the news media in the hours leading up to the ceremony. Mr. Schwarzenegger's aides had treated her sartorial selection like a state secret, reminding reporters that not days after her husband's election-day victory party last month, knockoffs of her Dolce & Gabbana sleeveless white dress with black trim began showing up in Chinatown dress shops and disreputable corners of the nation's metropolises.
"All human beings are more alike than unalike," Ms. Shriver read, and as she did so, one could not help but feel some sympathy for Gray Davis, the governor no more, who had the humiliating task of sitting on the dais and smiling through the most ignominious moment of his professional life.
Neil Kleven, a consultant from Lancaster, just north of Los Angeles, had one of the "regular people" seats -- that is, on the lawn, his view obscured by trees and the risers built to accommodate the media. Mr. Kleven, a Republican, wondered if Mr. Davis was eligible for unemployment insurance.
"I wish that was all he was eligible for," Mr. Kleven said. "But I have a feeling he is going to make a lot of money."
Outside the chain-link fence that kept out the uninvited, a small retinue of protesters shouted the now familiar "gropinator" wisecracks and promised they would not go away until an independent investigation was conducted into accusations that Mr. Schwarzenegger had manhandled women on his movie sets. Fulfilling a campaign promise, he recently hired a private detective to investigate the accusations.
At a cocktail reception at the Sheraton on Sunday night, the television personality Tom Arnold, who appeared slightly on edge as he mingled, vouched for his friend's character. "Arnold is a great guy who will do a great job," Mr. Arnold said. "I'm just glad to be here."
Even the director Rob Reiner, a Democratic activist, attended Sunday night's gathering, explaining that he had been invited not by Mr. Schwarzenegger but by a friend, the new secretary of health, Kim Belshe.
It was just last year, during the final weeks of the tepid governor's race between Mr. Davis and Bill Simon, that the prospect of a 2006 matchup between Mr. Reiner and Mr. Schwarzenegger was making headlines.
Mr. Reiner, who has lost a copious amount of weight over the last few months on a prepackaged, hand-delivered diet, was asked Sunday evening whether he had missed an opportunity to win the governor's office for himself.
"I don't believe in the recall," he said. He was asked if he would challenge Mr. Schwarzenegger in 2006. "I don't know," he said with a tight smile, slipping his arm around his wife and then slipping away into the reception.
At the swearing-in ceremony, Mr. Schwarzenegger wore a charcoal Prada suit, a light blue tie and a white shirt, and held his hands clenched before he was asked by the chief justice of the State Supreme Court to place his left hand on the family Bible, place his right hand in the air and accept his place in history.
Mr. Schwarzenegger gave a 12-minute speech, unusually long for him. He is not a loquacious politician and does not choose his movie roles for their literary value. By some counts, he spoke fewer than 800 words in "Terminator 2," getting paid nearly $20,000 a word.
Standing before 130 television cameras this morning, he acknowledged that he was a newcomer to politics and said he had been elected on faith and hope and people's disgust with the status quo. 
"This election," he said, "was the people's veto for politics as usual."
And Mr. Davis applauded.

HEADLINE: Catholic Center of N.Y.U. May Move to Nearby Parish 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN; Colin Moynihan contributed reporting for this article.

 BODY:
The Catholic Center at New York University may soon move off campus and merge with the nearby parish of St. Joseph-Greenwich Village. The center's director made the announcement during Masses this weekend.
 Moving the center, which has offered Masses and other services to N.Y.U. students for four decades, would be a small step next to the broad reorganization of parishes and priests that the Archdiocese of New York is starting to plan. But the move might be somewhat bittersweet for the university. 
 About eight years ago, N.Y.U. tried to buy the Catholic Center, on Washington Square South, from the archdiocese to make room for a new student center, but the deal fell through, and the student complex was built on an adjacent plot. If the archdiocese decides to move the center, an empty building with 10 floors of air rights on a prime campus location next to the student complex will potentially be available.
A spokesman for the archdiocese, Joseph Zwilling, said that no final decision had been made on a move and that it was far too early to say what might happen to the Catholic Center. The archdiocese is discussing what would be best for the center and the parish, he said.
The N.Y.U. chaplain, the Rev. John P. McGuire, said Cardinal Edward M. Egan seemed to voice second thoughts yesterday during a visit to the center.
Father McGuire said that if the merger took place, he would become the new pastor of St. Joseph's.
In an earlier interview, he sounded as if he were trying to make the best of the possible move. "Our whole bottom line financially is very, very precarious," he said. "At the same time, we're only three minutes' walk from this magnificent, beautiful church, with a small congregation of 400."
The center would add about 1,000 worshipers to St. Joseph's on weekends, as well as the vitality of youth, he said.
But it would lose its location in the middle of the university's student life -- next to the student complex and near the library, he said.
The chaplaincies at N.Y.U. and Columbia University have been troubling issues for Cardinal Egan.
As a bishop in charge of education in New York in the late 1980's, he tried to oust the archdiocesan priest who was chaplain at N.Y.U, the Rev. Raymond M. Rafferty, in favor of a more conservative priest. Cardinal John O'Connor intervened and allowed Father Rafferty to stay.
Paul Dinter, a former priest who was chaplain at Columbia during those years, said he was forced from his post, although it was unclear which bishop was behind the move. "I was too socially liberal," he said.
After Father Rafferty left, the archdiocese handed the N.Y.U. chaplaincy over to the Dominican order. At the archdiocese's invitation, a group of Dominican priests from Poland took charge at Columbia this year.
The potential move of the N.Y.U. center can be seen as sensible from the archdiocese's point of view. The pastor of St. Joseph's retired last month, and if Father McGuire took over, the archdiocese would not have to dip into its scarce supply of priests.
The archdiocese would also be unburdened of the considerable expense of running the Catholic Center, whose $100,000 yearly energy bill alone exceeds total collections and donations, Father McGuire said.
While many N.Y.U. students and staff members and nearby residents who attend Mass at the center's Holy Trinity Chapel said they would follow Father McGuire to St. Joseph's, others expressed worry that the university's Catholics -- as well as its Muslims, Orthodox Jews, Episcopalians and Russian Orthodox who use the center for worship -- would be less well served. Four clubs meet in the space as well.
"To lose that presence, even by shifting it three or four blocks over to St. Joseph's, is really very sad for the presence of the church at N.Y.U. and for the whole area," said Father Rafferty, who is now pastor at Corpus Christi Church in Morningside Heights. 
He lamented the possible loss of the building, one of the few examples of modern Catholic church architecture in Manhattan. Perfectly framed by the arch in Washington Square Park, the center's chapel was dedicated in 1964. It has abstract stained-glass windows and is shaped like an A-frame with a flat top.
"It's a fairly important part of religious art of that period," Father Rafferty said.
Father McGuire's announcement this weekend of the center's possible move stunned many in the pews.
"I'm very torn about it," Professor Evelyn Vitz, a member of the French department, said Sunday. "We've had a very impressive college ministry."
A spokesman for N.Y.U., John Beckman, said the university had received no formal word from the archdiocese. He said it would be a pity if the center were to close.
"Our students love having a parish with an N.Y.U.-centric focus, and it would be greatly missed," he said. But, he said, university officials sympathize with the archdiocese as it faces economic pressures.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Known for Helping Others, Woman Gets Help Herself

BYLINE:  By KATE JACOBS

 BODY:
It was Labor Day 2001, and Doris Ware planned on taking her grandson, Steven, to the West Indian Day Parade in Brooklyn, as she did every year. On their way to the parade, the two stopped at a neighborhood get-together, where Ms. Ware had a couple of drinks with friends. 
 But what was a casual cocktail for everyone else at the party was a much bigger deal for Ms. Ware, who had been dealing with a secret alcoholism that over several years had been getting more and more severe. 
 Ms. Ware's recollection of that day is sketchy. She remembers going to the parade with Steven, saying to him, 'Hold on to me, because Grandma's feeling a little tipsy,' and waking up in her bed the next morning.
It was an abrupt shock to Steven, 13, and Ms. Ware's two daughters, Ayesha, 30, and Chekasa, 27. But Ms. Ware knows that day was a long time coming.
Eleven years earlier, on a December night in 1990, Chekasa was caught in random gunfire while walking home from a night out in the neighborhood. She was shot in the back, became paralyzed from the waist down and spent the next year and a half in a rehabilitation center.
"When it first happened, I was crying all the time," Ms. Ware, 52, said recently, sitting at the living room table of the apartment that she, Chekasa, Ayesha and Steven share. "Everything was crumbling."
In addition to helping Chekasa manage the anger and sadness she felt about her disability, Ms. Ware, a single mother, had practical concerns to deal with. With Chekasa no longer able to climb the three flights of stairs to the Wares' top-floor apartment, the family had to look for a new one. Then there were the logistics of running between work, home and the hospital.
Even so, Ms. Ware, who often speaks of keeping "a happy face," held herself and her family together. She signed a lease for a loft apartment in an elevator building. She also began seeing a psychiatrist.
But in July 1994, it became measurably harder to keep the happy face from slipping. She was laid off from the Federal Reserve Bank, where she had held several positions over 25 years. Ms. Ware's fatigue and anxiety finally surfaced, and she started drinking heavily. 
"The girls would see me go to the kitchen, get a glass of ice and go back into my room," she said. "And this was every night."
Finding a new job at the New York City Board of Education helped, but it didn't eradicate the problem. The $1,000-a-month rent on the family's loft was difficult to pay with Ms. Ware secretly spending much of her own and her daughters' money on vodka. The rent piled up, and they had to find to a cheaper place to live. 
Then, Ms. Ware's mother died.
Then, she had a breast cancer scare (it turned out to be only cysts).
To cope with each new challenge, each new loss, she drank more, until that blackout on Labor Day 2001. After that, Ms. Ware's daughters demanded that she go to the hospital.
"Ayesha was crying, saying, 'I never thought I would take my mother to a place like this,' " Ms. Ware said of that trip. "And I said to myself, 'Doris, it's time for you to get help.' "
One year of group sessions and psychologist appointments later, Ms. Ware was sober. She began to truly enjoy her job, where she helped to place physical, speech and occupational therapists into city schools, and developed a reputation for helping others find employment at the Board of Education (her daughter Ayesha, for one).
But she still owed $8,710.53 in rent, and when Department of Education jobs started to be cut, Ms. Ware had a hunch that she would not have hers much longer. Last December, two weeks before Christmas and the day before her 52nd birthday, the woman known for finding other people jobs was laid off.
Ms. Ware now laughs as she remembers that day. "I thought, what am I going to do now?" she said. "I'm 51 years old!"
What she did was employ an adage her mother had always repeated to her -- when one door closes, another opens -- and get a voucher to enroll in a medical transcribing program. She also used her unemployment benefits and Chekasa's disability subsidy to try to pay off her back rent. Falling short, she turned to the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
In April, Ms. Ware was granted $1,000, paid for by the Neediest Cases Fund, for the balance of the outstanding rent.
Ms. Ware has been interviewing for jobs, but has not yet landed one. She recently started an internship at New York University Downtown Hospital and has been volunteering with the American Cancer Society's Making Strides Against Breast Cancer campaign, but neither of those activities help her make her rent payments, which are close to falling behind again.
Anyone else might have a hard time keeping a happy face under such circumstances, but Ms. Ware's vibrant outlook is apparent even through her worry and stress.
"I have great friends and a family I love," she said, "so I know everything's going to be fine."

HEADLINE: NYC; 
All the Views Unfit to Print On a Billboard

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
THE REV. KRISTOPHER OKWEDY and the New York Civil Liberties Union have so little in common that they would probably have a hard time agreeing on a lunch order.
 But they share at least one idea. Both believe in their right to use billboards to say what they feel needs saying. The problem is that, in delivering their messages, both have run afoul of the authorities, raising serious questions about how far the government may go to monitor speech, including speech that many find objectionable. 
 First up is Mr. Okwedy, born in Nigeria and pastor of Keyword Ministries, a Christian church on Staten Island devoted to what it calls traditional biblical values. Among those values is a belief that homosexuality is sinful.
To bring that point home, Mr. Okwedy bought space on two Staten Island billboards in 2000, filling them with different translations of the same biblical verse, Leviticus 18:22. The King James version says, "Thou shalt not lie with mankind, as with womankind: it is abomination."
There was no call to harm gays, just the quotation from the Bible -- a passage that is, as the minister acknowledges, offensive to many in this city. "Even if people don't like what I said," Mr. Okwedy said the other day, "I have the right to say it."
Among the unconvinced is Guy V. Molinari, who in 2000 was the Staten Island borough president. Days after the Leviticus signs went up, Mr. Molinari faxed a letter to the billboard company, PNE Media of Union, N.J. "This message," he said, "conveys an atmosphere of intolerance which is not welcome in our borough."
He added, "PNE Media owns a number of billboards on Staten Island and derives substantial economic benefits from them."
Lo and behold, PNE announced within hours that the billboards were gone. Interesting how these things work.
Mr. Okwedy went to court, saying his First Amendment rights had been violated. But a federal judge in Brooklyn, Nina Gershon, tossed out his lawsuit, reasoning that the First Amendment is concerned with actions by government, not private business. Mr. Molinari, the judge said, "did not have regulatory authority" over the billboard company.
Not so fast, a federal appeals court now says. Mr. Molinari's reference to PNE's business interests, it recently ruled, "could be found to contain an implicit threat of retaliation" should his wishes be ignored. The appellate judges gave Mr. Okwedy's lawsuit new life.
This case has far to go. But this fundamental question has already been framed: Is New York, for all its vaunted liberalism, often intolerant of views that do not conform to generally accepted wisdom?
Michael DePrimo, Mr. Okwedy's lawyer, believes so. He is with the American Family Association, a nonprofit organization in Tupelo, Miss., that says it "stands for traditional family values."
"The city is tolerant only of views that it feels it should be tolerant of," Mr. DePrimo said by phone.
CHARGES of government interference with free speech also define a lawsuit brought by the New York Civil Liberties Union against the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying.
The civil liberties group posted a billboard message outside an Albany mall where a man had been arrested in March for protesting the impending invasion of Iraq. His offense was to wear a T-shirt that said "Give Peace a Chance." The billboard showed a man with his mouth gagged. "Welcome to the mall," it said. "You have the right to remain silent. Value free speech."
To the state commission, this amounted to a lobbying effort in behalf of a bill in the Legislature to expand free-speech rights in shopping malls. As a lobbyist regulator, it demanded an accounting of the billboard's costs. But to the civil liberties union's way of thinking, the state was trying to regulate First Amendment activities. So the group filed a lawsuit.
Earlier this month, the commission backed off, citing a technical reason to drop its claim to jurisdiction. Nonetheless, the civil libertarians say broad constitutional concerns are on the line, and they are forging ahead with their case.
"There is a chilling effect on free speech at issue here," said Donna Lieberman, the executive director of the group.
Funny, but that is essentially Mr. Okwedy's point.
"I believe the greatest thing about this nation is that people have freedom to express themselves," he said. "I don't think this nation has the right to fight for freedom in Iraq if people here don't have the right to express themselves."

HEADLINE: I Came, I Bought And I Helped 

BYLINE:  By GUY TREBAY

 BODY:
No one blinks anymore when the fashion world tantalizes the public with its design flirtation du jour. People are so inured to 15-second novelties that, by the time one registers broadly, it has typically become a remote blip on the cognoscenti's radar screens. Velour hoodies? Yawn. Ugg boots? Weren't those the weird things Kate Hudson wore with her bikini when she went arugula shopping in Malibu?
 Fads are disposable by definition. So it is surprising that the latest one to affect the industry gives signs of having legs, and not particularly sexy ones at that. Social responsibility may be the sort of phrase one associates less with insider hot spots like the Soho House than with the student quad, but lately it is spoken of in some unexpected quarters. 
 Fashion is built on frivolity. Yet it is nearly impossible these days to flip through a fashion magazine without encountering a plea from some leading light of fashion or beauty favoring social issues. They are as disparate as cancer research, childhood nutrition, animal welfare, environmental protection or medical care for underserved communities. 
Consider some events from the last few months, when Vogue announced a benefit auction for God's Love We Deliver, the nonprofit organization that delivers hot meals to homebound people with AIDS; the Ralph Lauren companies announced the inauguration of G.I.V.E., an initiative to promote youth volunteerism through jean sales; Saks Fifth Avenue joined forces with VH1 on Save the Music, enlisting designers and celebrities like Beyonce Knowles to sell merchandise whose profits help school music programs; and Giorgio Armani created a special edition Armani Barbie,with part of its profits destined to combat youth AIDS.
If corporate social responsibility is not yet a bona fide movement in the United States as it is in Europe, where an initiative begun in 1995 by the former European Commission president Jacques Delors now encompasses scores of name brand companies, it is "where the smart money is going," said Scott Nova, the executive director of the Worker Rights Consortium. 
The existence of the consortium can itself be taken as a signal of generational shifts in taste. Founded in 2000 to centralize a grass roots student movement, it has persuaded 116 colleges to institute codes of conduct among their suppliers that ensure the use of fair labor to produce the goods for the $3 billion a year college logo-wear industry. "The consumer market is very different today even from a few years ago," said Marshall Cohen, a fashion industry analyst for the NPD Group, a market research company. Consumers, Mr. Cohen said, especially young ones, now seek brands that can demonstrate environmental and labor friendliness. 
Although bottom-line figures supporting that assertion are hard to come by, believers in socially conscious business practices are devout. "Being a good citizen translates into good business," said John Demsey, president of MAC cosmetics, which industry analysts say is the fastest-growing cosmetics brand in North America. Since 1994, MAC has raised $31 million for AIDS research and charities like Bailey House solely through the sales of a $14 lipstick. "Social messaging has obviously had a rub-off effect on commercial business," Mr. Demsey said. "Branding and the charity are synonymous with each other and I'm not ashamed of that."
Anecdotal evidence is also strong that appearing socially aware to consumers is de rigueur. "There's a definite hip factor involved" for stores as well as for manufacturers, said Jacqui Lividini, the fashion director of Saks Fifth Avenue. Saks has sponsored a "Gifts That Give Back" promotion for its Save the Music campaign. Supported by newspaper advertising and a ground-floor boutique in its Manhattan store, the merchandise -- French thong sets and designer makeup bags -- is secondary to a message that Saks promotes music programs in schools. "If customers perceive you as socially committed, that is going to affect their loyalty," Ms. Lividini said. 
Saks is one of the most high profile participants in what analysts refer to as "cause-based" marketing. But it is far from alone. "Young people are more likely to buy something from a company that is socially conscious," said David Lauren, a marketing and communications executive for Polo Ralph Lauren, and the founder's son. Ten percent of the profits from a $60 Polo slim-fit low-rise pair of jeans with a leather G.I.V.E. patch go to promote volunteerism. Polo Ralph Lauren also underwrites the Pink Pony campaign, which channels part of the sales of T-shirts, sweat shirts and ponchos bearing a pink polo rider to philanthropy. 
A decade ago, few fashion and beauty companies made much effort to align themselves with social activism. There was MAC (now a division of Estee Lauder), which raised money for AIDS research using celebrities like Mary J. Blige to pitch Viva Glam. There was Anita Roddick, who built the Body Shop chain on a platform of rain forest rescue and sustainable resources. And there was Kenneth Cole, who staked the image of an unexceptional midrange shoe company on advertisements that touted AIDS awareness. 
But in the current and increasingly crowded market, where consumers are at pains to differentiate between one generically tasteful jacket and another, numerous fashion makers seek to distinguish themselves by good citizenship. "A lot of early studies claimed that corporate social responsibility didn't enhance financial performance," said Donald Siegel, a professor of economics at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., and an author of studies on the profitability of corporate responsibility. "Especially for image-based products like celebrity fashion lines, it turns out that the bottom line is affected, because consumers really seem to care about these things." 
One measure of this assertion might be the alacrity with which the Sean John company responded to a recent report by a labor group charging that its $40 sweat shirts were produced by factory workers making pennies a day in Honduras. "We will not tolerate any violation of labor laws at facilities in which our merchandise is manufactured," said Jeff Tweedy, the executive vice president of Sean John, noting that the labor minister of Honduras had later toured the factory and issued a statement claiming that the complaints were unfounded. "We conduct extensive compliance checks with all facilities supplying our company to ensure they are clean and safe," Mr. Tweedy said. 
Poor labor conditions are always a volatile issue with consumers, as anyone knows who remembers the scorn heaped on Kathie Lee Gifford in 1996, when it was found that designs for her Wal-Mart clothing line were sewn by sweatshop workers.
"We are at a major crossroads with the consumer after Enron, Martha Stewart and all the other corporate scandals," Mr. Cohen of the NPD Group said. "The consumer has so much choice today, they want to feel like there's an added benefit" to what to buy. 
Does this mean Vogue readers will start clamoring for features on child labor? Of course they won't. Fashion will probably always have a home for those more concerned with a bell sleeve than unpaid overtime. The one-time darling of Seventh Avenue, Isaac Mizrahi, was hired last year by Target to bring style to shoppers in 47 states. Critics were nearly unanimous in their celebration of Mr. Mizrahi's belted suede jacket and all-American turtlenecks, praising particularly his ability to accomplish so much at an affordable price. 
Few stopped to inquire how it was possible to attain Mizrahi chic for as little as $9.99. Mr. Mizrahi's clothes are manufactured at factories around the world, said Lena Klofstad, a Target spokeswoman, who declined to name specific countries. "We have standards for all our vendors and a compliance area that takes care to enforce them," she explained, "so Isaac is freed up to focus on what he enjoys, the design."
When asked if he knew where his bargain styles were being manufactured, under what circumstances and by whom, Mr. Mizrahi pleaded ignorance. "I don't know," he said. "And I don't want to know."

HEADLINE: Report Finds Few Benefits for Mexico in Nafta 

BYLINE:  By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
As the North American Free Trade Agreement nears its 10th anniversary, a study from the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace concludes that the pact failed to generate substantial job growth in Mexico, hurt hundreds of thousands of subsistence farmers there and had "minuscule" net effects on jobs in the United States.
 The Carnegie Endowment, an independent, Washington-based research institute, issued its report on Tuesday to coincide with new trade negotiations aimed at the adoption of a Nafta-like pact for the entire Western Hemisphere. Trade ministers from 34 countries in the Americas are gathering now in Miami. 
 The report seeks to debunk both the fears of American labor that Nafta would lure large numbers of jobs to low-wage Mexico, as well as the hopes of the trade deal's proponents that it would lead to rising wages, as well as declines in income inequality and illegal immigration. 
Though sorting out the exact causes is complicated, trends are clear. Real wages in Mexico are lower now than they were when the agreement was adopted despite higher productivity, income inequality is greater there and immigration has continued to soar. 
"On balance, Nafta's been rough for rural Mexicans," said John J. Audley, who edited the report. "For the country, it's probably a wash. It takes more than just trade liberalization to improve the quality of life for poor people around the world."
The Carnegie findings strike a much more pessimistic note than those of a World Bank team that concluded in a draft report this year that the trade accord "has brought significant economic and social benefits to the Mexican economy."
The bank's economists argue that Mexico would have been worse off without the agreement as the country struggled to recover from a deep financial crisis in the mid-1990's and that the income gap between Mexico and the United States is smaller than it would have been otherwise.
Luis Serven, research manager for Latin America at the bank, said in an interview that he disagreed with the Carnegie report's contention that the trade agreement had hurt small subsistence farmers. He also said that the higher productivity Mexico had achieved in the Nafta years was ultimately the only route to higher wages there.
The intensity of the debate about the agreement's consequences is likely to grow with the approach of the pact's 10th anniversary in January as pro- and antiglobalization forces marshal arguments to influence negotiations for a Free Trade Area of the Americas and for a new bilateral trade deal between the United States and Central America.
Carnegie's policy experts stop short of contending that Mexico would have been better off without the agreement. "Mexico would have been better off with a better Nafta," said Sandra Polaski, a senior associate at Carnegie who was director of economic research at the Nafta labor secretariat from 1996 to 1999.
The authors of the report say developing countries have much to learn from Mexico's mistakes in the Nafta deal. 
Trade negotiators for Central and South American countries, they said, should bargain for more gradual tariff reductions on corn, rice and beans -- the staples of subsistence farming -- to give peasants time to adjust to tough competition from large, highly efficient and heavily subsidized American farmers.
Carnegie's researchers also say developing countries should push international donors and rich countries to finance transitional assistance for the retraining of workers and farmers displaced by global competition.
Developing countries should also seek greater leeway to promote the use of domestic suppliers in manufacturing over imported components -- a step that would increase job creation, the authors say. 
The Carnegie report argues that the growth in manufacturing resulting from the trade agreement was largely offset by lost employment among rural subsistence farmers, who were adversely affected by falling prices for their crops, especially corn -- a problem intensified by the Mexican government's decision to lower tariff barriers to American-grown corn even more rapidly than the agreement required.
"This is a trade pact which opened the U.S. economy to Mexico very profoundly, including years when the United States experienced its best growth in decades," Ms. Polaski said. "Yet we can't see a clear net increase in jobs in Mexico. You'd expect strong growth. You wouldn't have expected to need a magnifying glass to find it."
The trade agreement also reinforced and magnified changes in Mexico's rural economy -- brought on by a broad array of other policies -- that are damaging the environment, according to Scott Vaughan, an economist who recently left Carnegie to head the environmental unit at the Organization of American States. For example, he contends that the agreement has accelerated the shift to large-scale, export-oriented farms that rely more heavily on water-polluting agro-chemicals and use more irrigated water compared with producers of similar crops for the Mexican market.
