HEADLINE: Married or Not, It's a Full House 

BYLINE:  By FRED A. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
WHEN Steven Lofton, Roger Croteau and Mr. Lofton's five foster children -- who were born to H.I.V.-positive mothers -- prepare Thanksgiving dinner, it will be in a kitchen in Portland, Ore., with cobalt blue walls and fire-engine-red Formica cabinets. Then they will join more than 20 guests in a dining room with an orange tabletop, yellow carpeting and a silver ceiling.
 "Some of us are people of color," Mr. Lofton, 46, said, referring to his interracial family. "And some of us are people who love color." 
 Mr. Lofton's sense of humor is one of the things that has sustained him through 16 years of raising children under laws that can be hostile to gay parents. This week, the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, in ruling that same-sex couples should be allowed to marry, noted that children of such couples deserve the stability that marriage brings. The court wrote that children should not be penalized "because the state disapproves of their parents' sexual orientation." 
But not every state shares that view. Mr. Lofton has been entangled in a legal dispute with Florida (where the family used to live) since the mid-1990's. That's when Bert Sanchez, one of Mr. Lofton's foster sons, tested negative for H.I.V. -- great news, except that it made him eligible for adoption under Florida rules. Mr. Lofton and Mr. Croteau, 48, both pediatric nurses, had taken Bert in when he was 9 weeks old. Mr. Lofton applied to adopt him, so that the boy could remain in their home.
"Moving Bert would be child abuse," Mr. Lofton said flatly.
But Florida refused to allow Mr. Lofton to adopt Bert, now 12 -- because since 1977 it has been illegal for gay men or women to adopt children there. The state hoped to place Bert with a heterosexual couple.
Mr. Lofton and Mr. Croteau, feeling beleaguered by Florida's Department of Children and Families, moved to Oregon in 1998, and eventually took in more foster children: two young H.I.V.-positive brothers. 
Lynn Jenkins, a social services specialist for the Oregon Department of Child Welfare, said, "I saw the wonderful work they were doing with the children they already had."
Although the three older children -- Bert, Frank Alexander, 16, and their one girl, Tracey Frederick, also 16 -- are still under the jurisdiction of Florida, things are calmer for the family now that they are three time zones away, Mr. Lofton said.
In 1999, with the American Civil Liberties Union representing him, Mr. Lofton sued the State of Florida over the refusal to let him become Bert's legal parent. (Ironically, one of Florida's rationales, according to its briefs, is that two men or two women cannot offer children the "stable home environment" that results from heterosexual marriage.) The case, which was taken up by Rosie O'Donnell, is now before the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, and could be decided at any time.
If Mr. Lofton and Mr. Croteau were to marry, it would have no direct effect on the Florida case, said Leslie Cooper, a lawyer from the A.C.L.U., even though same-sex marriage would deprive the state of one of its rationales for banning gay adoption.
"Florida law is clear on the subject," Bill Spann, a spokesman for the state's children and families agency, said by telephone. "Cohabitating same-sex couples are not permitted to adopt. We feel strongly that children's interests are best served by being raised in a home with both a mother and a father present."
Mr. Croteau was born in Bellingham, Mass., on the Rhode Island border. He and Mr. Lofton have not yet discussed returning to Massachusetts to wed. In fact, Mr. Lofton said he is more concerned about making time for school plays, swim meets and camping trips. (He recently chaperoned 95 seventh and eighth graders on a weeklong science trip to the Oregon coast.)
"With five children, especially this time of year, you're totally focused on school," he said. 
Mr. Lofton added, "Roger and I are already more married than most people." The couple have been together for 20 years and have, by their estimate, changed 20,000 diapers.
When Mr. Lofton and Mr. Croteau began taking in babies with AIDS in the late 1980's, nobody expected the children to reach kindergarten. "There were no AIDS drugs at all," Mr. Croteau said. 
One of the foster children, Ginger, died from complications of AIDS in 1995, when she was 6. Three years later, when the couple decided to move, they chose Portland because Mr. Lofton's parents, brother and a sister live there, and, he said, "this way the kids would get to see my family all the time." Mr. Lofton made several scouting trips to Oregon to find a house the couple could afford. (Mr. Lofton, a full-time foster parent, receives payments from Florida for the three older children, and from Oregon for Wayne and Ernie Bethancourt. Mr. Croteau works with pediatric H.I.V. researchers at Oregon Health and Science University Hospital.)
While house hunting, he said, he saw nothing but beige. "That's the predominant color in the Northwest."
Eventually, he found a 1929 Craftsman-style bungalow with leaded-glass windows, brass heating vents, glass doorknobs and lots of original woodwork for $255,000. It is in a neighborhood, Arbor Lodge, that Mr. Lofton calls "Mayberry with S.U.V.'s."
Soon after they arrived, the couple painted their house blue and green. Then they tore their lawn out.
"Lawns are not only boring, but environmentally wasteful," Mr. Lofton said. Instead he has a jungle of windmill palms, New Zealand flax and 18 varieties of ivy.
Four other families on the block -- perhaps inspired by their "queer eye for the straight suburb" attitude -- have also replaced their lawns, he said.
Gretchen Corbett, a neighbor who raised a daughter (now grown) in Arbor Lodge, said, "Sometimes, I wish they'd come over and do my house."
Mr. Lofton and Mr. Croteau spent six months renovating their three-bedroom home with some help from Mr. Lofton's family. His brother, a welder, made a four-foot aluminum Gumby for the stairwell. Mr. Lofton's father, a glass blower, created colorful glass legs for a new mailbox.
To save money, they lived in the house throughout the renovation, closing off one room at a time. (The one requirement was that there always be working washer and dryer. Mr. Lofton said he does 15 loads a week.)
A leather mantelpiece in the living room was an economy measure, Mr. Lofton said -- an easy way to hide wood that had split after the previous owners overwatered their houseplants. When he wanted a colorful fabric for the walls of the master bedroom, he ordered Sunbrella, an acrylic awning fabric. He made a stair rail out of a faux-leather rope -- the idea, he said, came to him while waiting in line at a movie theater.
The State of Oregon supervises the Lofton foster home, under contract with Florida's Department of Children and Families. Three years ago, Oregon's child welfare agency asked Mr. Lofton and Mr. Croteau to take over the care of Ernie, now 7, and Wayne, now 10. 
Mr. Lofton was initially resistant. "I was ready to rejoin the work force," he said. "The last thing we were looking to do was expand our family."
But they made room for the two towheaded boys, who share a room with Frank and Bert. Mr. Lofton said having four boys in one bedroom "frees up more of the house for everyone to play in."
He added: "The last thing I want is to have my teens alone in their bedrooms with the computer on and the door closed."
Despite the riotous decor, the house is impossibly tidy. "We're not in a rut, but we believe in routine," Mr. Croteau said. All five children have chores. Ernie, the youngest, "makes his bed, puts away his toys and is responsible for organizing the shoe rack in the basement," Mr. Croteau said.
"At 7, there's plenty he can do, and he wants to do it."
All five children attend the Metropolitan Learning Center, a K-12 magnet school known for its open-minded attitude. "It's the kind of school that has a float in the gay pride parade," Mr. Lofton said. 
With college approaching for Tracey and Frank, Mr. Lofton is looking to earn more money. He said that his Florida foster parent contract allows him to work from home, so he is setting up business as an interior designer. 
Mr. Lofton's decorating skills include finding ways to defend surfaces from active children. And not just by using washable fabrics and eggshell-finish paint. To keep metal chair legs from scratching wood floors, Mr. Lofton used lime-green tennis balls as feet.
Some days are not easy. But "being frustrated with teenagers is normal," Mr. Lofton said. "And my job is to provide a normal family."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Duty Calls After Sept. 11, Straining Family Finances

BYLINE:  By ARTHUR BOVINO

 BODY:
A kidney on the verge of shutting down. A home on the verge of being lost. For Kenneth and Angelean Thomas, the last few years have been one ordeal after another.
 But after 27 years of marriage, the Thomases are not about to be shaken by failing health, late paychecks, late rent or even a threat of eviction. 
 Mr. Thomas, 48, is a janitor in Harlem for Head Start, a federally funded, community-based child development program, and earns $23,000 a year. Mrs. Thomas, 53, used to work at a temp agency.
Together, they have forged a strong and stable home life. They have lived in the same apartment in the Bronx for 10 years. They have raised six children; Kenneth Jr., 14, still lives at home.
But stability has not always been easy to come by. In 1996, Mrs. Thomas was found to have end-stage renal disease, and she left her job to focus on her health.
Now, she undergoes dialysis three times a week, a process that she says "really drains you." She receives $556 in Social Security disability a month, and Medicare pays for the dialysis.
Characteristically, the Thomases have tried to focus on the positive.
"God has been good to us," Mr. Thomas said. "Because I have a job that has a split shift, during my work break I can take her to the hospital."
Mr. Thomas credits his experience in a youth cadet program for leading him down the right path in life.
"It teaches discipline and respect," he said. "They taught you how to be a man, especially being raised in the ghetto. There are a lot of obstacles that will get you in the street, and they kept you clean and out of trouble."
The experience inspired him to join the New York Guard in 1993; he is now a staff sergeant. "I've always wanted to give back to my community and my country," he said.
But a call to serve after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack gave rise to the Thomases' other major challenge: keeping a roof over their heads. On that day, Mr. Thomas was activated, and he worked 12-hour shifts four to five days a week at the 369th Armory in Harlem, checking trucks and verifying identifications of military personnel.
"When you're called, you have to go, so I left the job," he said. "I thought at the time that I would still be getting paid from the job. Most people do when you're in the service."
But Mr. Thomas was a temporary employee. Three weeks into his seven-week service, he learned that he would not be getting his regular paychecks. He was making $100 a day as a staff sergeant, but, he said, "the military pay was sort of late."
Such a complication was something he knew he had to expect with the chaos of Sept. 11.
But then it was compounded by a turn in Mrs. Thomas's health about the same time. She needed surgery to inflate the veins that had been stressed by the dialysis over the years. With the delay in the military pay, the Thomases soon found themselves three months behind on their rent.
"We could ask our children for money," Mr. Thomas said. "But they have their own families. I felt I'd struggle until I could get it myself."
One weekend in November 2001, Mr. Thomas was watching television and saw David R. Jones, the president and chief executive of the Community Service Society, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Mr. Jones was speaking about the economy in the aftermath of the terrorist attack.
"He was saying working people were having trouble paying bills," Mr. Thomas said.
So he called the society hoping that he and his family might find some help. They met their caseworker, Billy Carmon.
"He was in the process of being evicted," Mr. Carmon said. "I felt I had to do what I could to help him move on with his life."
Mr. Carmon secured $1,888.05 of Neediest Cases money to pay the back rent and fend off an eviction.
"I can tell you it was a godsend," Mr. Thomas said. "We call it a miracle. We didn't know what to do or how we were going to do it."
In fact, the Thomases' luck may be changing, and there may be another miracle around the bend. Recently, all of the couple's children had their blood tested for compatibility with their mother's. The oldest daughter, Daphne, 34, volunteered to give her mother a kidney. They hope to do the operation soon.
Meanwhile, for all their setbacks, the family continues to hold fast to the dream of one day buying their own house.
But Mr. Thomas said they would not forget the help they received from the Neediest Cases Fund. "When I get back on my feet," he said, "I will contribute to the Community Service Society."

HEADLINE: THE GROUND ZERO MEMORIAL: THE COMPETITION; 
Presenting Several Versions of the Shape of Grief and Recollection

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Eight possible memorials at the World Trade Center site, each deferring in some way to the ghosts of the twin towers, were shown to the nation yesterday.
 The plans, chosen by a 13-member jury for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, did not come from the hands of celebrated architects but rather a diverse group of designers, many of them young, who live in and work in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Chicago, Houston, Paris, Ithaca, N.Y., and Oakland, Calif. 
 Most designs followed the lead of Daniel Libeskind's overall plan by depressing some or all of the memorial area that has been set aside at the southwest corner of the trade center site. Some expressed the presence of the towers as voids. Others turned the building footprints into islands, waterfalls, pavilions, sanctuaries and even small prairies. 
As one of the most keenly anticipated events in the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan, the unveiling drew dozens of victims' relatives and firefighters in their bunker coats. They mingled with officials, civic leaders, architects and reporters among eight models set up on pedestals in a semicircular gallery at the Winter Garden in Battery Park City.
The unveiling also drew Vartan Gregorian, the chairman of the jury and president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York. He broke a long public silence to introduce the eight plans that the panel culled from 5,201 submissions in the hope of finding "a design that will begin to repair both the wounded cityscape and our wounded souls."
Until now, the process had been kept secret, in part to insulate jurors from politics, pressure groups and public relations. The entrants were not present yesterday and are still barred from talkingto reporters.
The jury must narrow the choice to first- , second- and third-place finalists, which could happen by the end of the year. Under the competition guidelines, if the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the winners are "unable to reach an agreement" about development details, the corporation will open negotiations with the other finalists.
Even the winning design is likely to change before construction is begun. Dr. Gregorian said the jury would seek refinements in "how the names of each of the victims should be recognized, how to respect the tower footprints and keep them unencumbered, how to provide access to bedrock, and what the relationship of the memorial will be to the site's interpretive museum."
Until a winner is chosen, the finalists will be on display at the Winter Garden, the glass-roofed centerpiece of the World Financial Center, directly across West Street from the trade center site. It is open from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily. The plans are also at www.wtcsitememorial.org. Eventually, all 5,201 submissions will go on public display, at the jurors' request.
There will be no formal public comment period, although the Municipal Art Society and the Civic Alliance to Rebuild Downtown New York are conducting three public meetings today, tomorrow and Saturday (www.imaginenewyork.org). The results of those meetings will be summarized and presented to jury members.
In any case, such a well-connected jury -- it includes the designer Maya Lin and Deputy Mayor Patricia E. Harris -- cannot possibly avoid hearing what will certainly be a lively, if not stormy, civic debate.
On first impression, the plans all seem to have been shaped by the implicit impression of the twin towers, whose absence is still the most remarkable thing about the Lower Manhattan skyline. Their outlines are seen in every design.
As such, the designs tend to look downward, some as far as bedrock. Many are organized around subterranean or covered spaces and chambers. There are few elements in any plan much higher above sidewalk level than a treetop.
"They strive neither to overwhelm the visitor nor their immediate surroundings," Dr. Gregorian said. "They aspire to soar -- not by competing with the soaring skyline of New York but rather by creating spaces that strive to reconcile vertical and horizontal, green and concrete, contemplation and inspiration.
"They allow for the change of seasons, passage of years and evolution over time. They emphasize the process of memorialization over their own grandeur and present themselves as living landscapes of living memory that both connect us to our past and carry us forward into the decades ahead."
The memorial is intended to remember the people and events of Feb. 26, 1993, when the trade center was bombed, and Sept. 11, 2001, when the twin towers were destroyed and the Pentagon badly damaged by three hijacked jetliners, as a fourth hijacked airplane crashed in Pennsylvania.
Six plans closely follow Mr. Libeskind's architectural outline, which calls for a museum wing bridging over the footprint of the north tower and another wing cantilevered over the footprint of the south tower.
Asked yesterday whether any or all of the designs fit his own vision of the site, Mr. Libeskind answered diplomatically, "I think the jury will have to make that decision."
It was Mr. Libeskind's Memory Foundations plan of December 2002 that awakened the possibility of setting the memorial on bedrock, 70 feet below ground, framed in part by the surviving foundation walls of the trade center. He has since modified his plan to a 30-foot depression.
But the issue of connecting the memorial to bedrock is potent and emotional.
Although the guidelines instructed the designers only to "make visible the footprints," Kevin M. Rampe, the president of the development corporation, seemed to go further than that yesterday when he said that "no matter which plan is chosen, the L.M.D.C. will ensure that bedrock can be accessed at each of the tower footprints."
Some access has been designed into Passages of Light: The Memorial Cloud, which leaves the footprints empty and creates an enclosed space between them with an undulating roof made of translucent tubes.
The footprints would become enclosed sanctuaries in the plan Votives in Suspension, punctuated by a light for each victim, suspended by cable over a reflecting pool. In Lower Waters, a granite-clad memorial space would fill the north footprint, with a grove of trees in the south.
Sugar maples would fill the south tower footprint in Dual Memory, with a pavilion in the north. Garden of Lights would establish an orchard in the space between the footprints, which would be set aside as small prairies.
Inversion of Light would include perhaps the most literal recollection of the twin towers by reproducing a floor plan based on those of the 94th and 95th floors in the north footprint. In the south footprint would be a pond.
In Reflecting Absence, both footprints would be turned into 30-foot-deep reflective pools, edged with curtains of falling water. This proposal offers the most radical departure from Mr. Libeskind's plan by proposing to situate the cultural building along West Street as a barrier to the highway.
Reversing that arrangement, Suspending Memory would make a pool out of the entire site except the footprints, which would become garden islands, joined by a bridge, with small glass columns representing each life lost.
While almost everyone around him was dissecting individual plans, Albert Capsouto, the proprietor of the restaurant Capsouto Freres in TriBeCa, took a moment to discuss the impact of the competition on the Lower Manhattan community.
"Our biggest enemy is inaction," he said. "When you have a presentation that tries to pull it together -- and they have pulled it together -- that gives us optimism. And optimism is fuel for healing.
"There's going to be something there again."

Silverstein, left, the commercial leaseholder of the site, examining models for the ground zero memorial designs yesterday. HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
Delay in YankeeNets Breakup Makes Bidders for Nets Wait

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
A meeting of the YankeeNets board, at which four bids to acquire the Nets were to be presented, was postponed yesterday because a long-awaited agreement to split up the YankeeNets was not completed in time, two officials involved in the transactions said.
 The meeting could be rescheduled quickly upon the resolution of outstanding issues in the separation. Completion of the corporate divorce was believed to be close, the officials said. 
 It has become a priority within YankeeNets to separate the Yankees and the Nets cleanly, through a stock swap, before the basketball team is sold. The sale of the Nets and the breakup of the holding company created by the teams in 1999 have moved on parallel tracks recently.
Leading to the breakup is friction between the teams' owners, hefty losses incurred by the Nets and the belief that the chief reason they merged (the creation of the YES Network) had been achieved.
Whenever the board meeting does take place, the YankeeNets' investment bankers will recommend which of the four offers should be singled out for further negotiations.
The roster of potential buyers has been set for more than a week. But the lineup has changed because the developer Charles Kushner and Senator Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey raised their offer on Tuesday to $267.5 million from $250 million, leapfrogging bids by Stuart D. Feldman, a venture capitalist ($257.5 million), and Charles B. Wang, the co-owner of the Islanders ($265 million).
The increase in the Corzine-Kushner bid indicated that the partners felt they had to be more competitive, and it could prompt others to raise their offers to become one of the top two suitors before the YankeeNets board meets. The leading bidder remains Bruce C. Ratner, at $275 million, who wants to move the team to an arena that would be designed by Frank Gehry in Ratner's downtown Brooklyn development.
Ratner and Wang are the only bidders who are known to want to relocate the Nets from New Jersey. (Feldman's intentions are unknown.) In each case, local governments are contemplating using new or additional revenue they would receive from arena parking, taxes on tickets, sales and income, naming rights and other sources to help pay the debt on bonds.
Daniel L. Doctoroff, New York City's deputy mayor for economic development, said the city and state had held what he described as encouraging discussions with Ratner about using some or all of the revenue to finance a "modest percentage" of the cost of an arena, which is likely to be $400 million or more.
"The standard is that we have to believe that it will be a net positive for the city," Doctoroff said.
Peter Sylver, deputy county executive for economic development in Nassau County, said it was studying the financing of a new arena to replace Nassau Coliseum and house the Islanders and the Nets, if Wang were to be the winning bidder.
"But right now, to be honest, we don't have a construction budget," Sylver said.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Art Fairs

ART OF THE 20TH CENTURY, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, (212) 777-5218, through Monday. After its uncertain start last year, it will be interesting to see how this new art fair, devoted to the recently completed century, matures. Some 60 dealers from Europe and the Americas are presenting 20th-century paintings, drawings, sculpture, photographs and prints. Promised highlights include works by Arshile Gorky, Alice Neel, Jean Arp and Lyonel Feininger, and there are sure, as well, to be works by Picasso, Matisse, Romare Beardon and many other textbook names. Hours: today, noon to 7 p.m.; tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 7 p.m.; Monday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $15 (Ken Johnson).

"CONNOISSEUR'S ANTIQUES FAIR," Gramercy Park Armory, Lexington Avenue at 26th Street, (212) 532-1516, through Sunday. This new arrival on the antiques fair scene, now in its second year, will bring 51 dealers, mostly from New York and Connecticut, to New York City's most intimate armory. Expect to see plenty of American, English and Continental furniture, Asian art, textiles, porcelains and ceramics. Keep an eye out for a booth featuring 10 Chippendale chairs. An added attraction is "The New Face of Academic Art," an exhibition of 22 works from the collection of the Dahesh Museum. Hours: today, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $15 (Roberta Smith).

Museums

* LOTHAR BAUMGARTEN, "Origin of the Night: Amazon Cosmos," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Nov. 30. The first New York screening of this overlong but mesmerizing film from the late 1970's offers another piece of the expanding puzzle of post-Minimalism. Up close and impersonal, it explores a busy day in the life of an Amazon tributary, offering close-ups of flora, fauna and shimmering water accompanied by written and spoken words and a marvelous musical soundtrack. Inspired by an ancient creation narrative, it is mostly a lyrical meditation on the facts of film, nature and language and the erosion of the wilderness by industrial progress. And as its setting is really a trashy swamp somewhere in Germany, it establishes Mr. Baumgarten's importance to 1980's setup photography. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 62+, $9.50 (Smith).

* "TRISHA BROWN: DANCE AND ART IN DIALOGUE, 1961-2001," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, between Prince and Houston Streets, SoHo, (212) 219-1222, through Jan. 25. Ms. Brown's 40-odd years of innovative dance creation and performance brought about some memorable collaborations with painters, sculptors and musicians, among them Robert Rauschenberg, Donald Judd, Nancy Graves, Fujiko Nakaya, John Cage and Laurie Anderson. The dance pieces are vividly conveyed here by means of video and sound installations, still photographs, costumes, props, music, diagrams, sculptures, paintings and drawings that graphically demonstrate how Ms. Brown's boldly eccentric choreography has been enhanced by her friends from other disciplines. She has contributed a pair of intricate drawings recently made by putting charcoal between her toes as she danced on large sheets of paper. It's not easy to translate the dynamics of dance into a museum environment, but this vibrant show works diligently to revivify the experience. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; students, artists and 65+, $3 (Grace Glueck).

"THE DRAWINGS OF FRANCOIS BOUCHER," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700, through Dec. 14. One of the three giants of the French Rococo (with Watteau and Fragonard), Boucher is known for his sweetly erotic fantasy painting. This selection of about 75 drawings includes some sexy nudes, but its main purpose is to document the artist's extraordinary virtuosity in various drawing media and in diverse kinds of picture-making: landscape, architectural rendering, genre scenes, pastoral idylls, mythic extravaganzas, portraits and more. Boucher had a conventional imagination and not much interest in the real world, but he was a formidable technician. It was the activity of drawing itself that most turned him on. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, and Saturdays, 10 a.m to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 62+, $5 (Johnson)

* "EL GRECO," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 11. The world is full of second-class El Grecos, but they are not in this first-class show. The portraits are fresh, true to life and understated. Elsewhere, El Greco emotes. The pitch hardly varies or drops. It's no wonder people tend to fall in love with him when they are young. Modern artists especially love him, as if he were a protomodernist. As the Belgian painter Luc Tuymans says of El Greco's work: "Everything goes upward. That's its mystical meaning. It's about the evaporation of material life." The show is also gorgeously installed. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Michael Kimmelman).

* "PHILIP GUSTON," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 4. A handsome, eloquent retrospective. Even now the late pictures, from the 1970's, have a shock value nearly unsurpassed in recent art. Guston let loose the demons and out they tumbled, like clowns from a Volkswagen. But in crucial ways, as this show demonstrates, Guston's work didn't change as much as people first thought. The transitional decade leading up to the late work may be Guston's most fascinating and underrated: soulful abstractions that have the rough, barely muffled anger of raised voices approaching from the other side of a closed door. Then the door bursts open. Just before he died in 1980, Guston painted a sweet, pathetic head, like a bandaged Olmec rock, gazing dubiously up a rubbly hill. It is his self-portrait as Sisyphus: the artist, an eternal pessimist, hoping against hope, awaits the avalanche that we can't yet see tumbling toward him. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "HUNT FOR PARADISE: COURT ARTS OF IRAN, 1501-1576," Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400, through Jan. 18. Islam is constantly in the news now, but exhibitions of Islamic art are rare. This international loan show, of exceptional beauty, features objects from the Safavid dynasty, which began as a Sufi order and ended up ruling an empire. In the process, it developed an exquisite court art, which is sampled here. Included are pages from the great Book of Kings painted for Shah Tahmasp, a famous carpet from the Poldi Pezzoli Museum in Milan and an even more beautiful one from Boston. The piece de resistance is a glorious mint-condition silk applique hanging, hidden away in Hungary and being exhibited for the first time in nearly a century. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; students and 65+, $5 (Holland Cotter).

* PIERRE HUYGHE, "Streamside Day Follies," Dia:Chelsea, 548 West 22nd Street, (212) 989-5566, through Jan. 11. From an often brilliant French artist, a flawed installation piece involving moving walls that gently herd visitors into a makeshift theater (the good part) to watch a video (not so good) about the homey, slightly forlorn celebration of a new housing development. The piece exemplifies the way that the political correctness of the early 1990's has adopted a sheep's clothing that combines pop-culture seductiveness, of-the-people folksiness and amorphous sociological musings while remaining essentially arcane, controlling and even puritanical. But the dance of the walls, which can bring to mind circus elephants, is worth seeing. Consider it a metaphor for destruction of the white cube of modernism by the postmodernist black box of video-viewing. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, children, students and 60+ (Smith).

* "THE JEWISH JOURNEY: FREDERIC BRENNER'S PHOTOGRAPHIC ODYSSEY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, through Jan. 11. Following the tangled trails of the Jewish diaspora over 25 years in more than 40 countries, the French photographer Frederic Brenner has photographed factory workers in Birobidzhan, Russia; sellers of Christian souvenirs in St. Peter's Square; village women in the mountains of Ethiopia; a wealthy merchant of Calcutta; and countless other examples of Jews who have developed roots in countries around the world. His intent, he writes, was "to document these permutations of survival in exile before they disappeared," and what he found inevitably poses the questions, what is a Jew and who are "the Jews"? Stereotypes tend to be dispelled by those who pass before his camera. The superb quality of his photographs, not only in their conception and composition but also in their technical finish, makes this a show that demands a visit. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; students and 62+, $3 (Glueck).

* "JAMES ROSENQUIST: A RETROSPECTIVE," Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, (212) 423-3500, through Jan. 25. Notwithstanding the enormous size of many of his paintings, Mr. Rosenquist is a haiku master of the American psyche. Intermittently great, his show is spaciously installed but too big. He is an uneven genius. The early works look as good as ever. His lesser-known forays into sculpture and mixed media, a selling point for the show, don't serve him well here. Invaluable are the collages on which he based many paintings, tools of his trade that demonstrate his process of constructing a work, which, contrary to what you might think, is not mechanical but intuitive. Some of the recent works, with their confetti entanglements of cosmic scenery, fish and flowers, technically adept and erratically magnificent, have something of the psychedelic look of 60's commercial art. They can seem dated in a way the classic paintings refuse to be. A different possibility is that, as before, it will take time to catch up with Mr. Rosenquist, who still has a restless imagination, huge energy and an uncanny knack for spotting how two unlikely things go together. Hours: Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $8 (Kimmelman).

* SCHOENBERG, KANDINSKY AND THE BLUE RIDER, Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200, through Feb. 12. Did Arnold Schoenberg's controversial atonal music help Wassily Kandinsky break through to what he called "pure painting" in works like "Sketch for Composition V" from 1911? Perhaps. With paintings, musical scores, concert programs and photographs, this exhibition explores the mostly long-distance friendship between two giants of the early 20th-century avant-garde, and also includes works by other painters in Kandinsky's art collective, the Blue Rider (a fabulous landscape by Gabriele Munter, for example). But its visual coherence comes mostly from Schoenberg's aberrant lugubrious little paintings -- mostly self-portraits that are variously outsiderish, semiabstract or conventionally representational. They flit in and out of the more stringently Modernist efforts like double agents, lagging behind, then zooming ahead, and have an inadvertent radicality that still astounds. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m.; Fridays, to 3 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 65+, $7.50 (Smith).

* "STRANGERS: THE FIRST I.C.P. TRIENNIAL OF PHOTOGRAPHY AND VIDEO," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0090, through Nov. 30. Not that anyone except the curators felt there was a pressing need for yet another art survey, but the center's first triennial is that rare case: an instructive, topical show. The theme, strangers, is nebulous enough to be a catchall for different brands of photography and video (works by Luc Delahaye, Rineke Dijkstra, Collier Schorr and Susan Meiselas, among others). Not many of these are discoveries, but the range is wide enough to accommodate the dissimilar tastes of the four curators and the diversity of photographic work being made today. The title is also specific enough to mean something. After 9/11 the subject of strangers has gained traction, and most of what's here expresses a cautionary view that the world is full of people who are strangers to one another. You might say that after years of navel-gazing, the climate of photo-based art, as this show presents it, has gradually shifted from me to them. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 62+, $7 (Kimmelman).

* "TURNING POINT: ORIBE AND THE ARTS OF 16TH-CENTURY JAPAN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 11. A tsunami in a tea bowl; that was Japan in the late 16th century. The social and political tempests were very real. So were the tea bowls, funky, wild-style, fanatically valued little things that distilled the self-image of the Momoyama (1573-1615) period. This carefully shaped show of modest-size objects focuses on one of the era's most dynamic figures, the warrior and cultural arbiter Furuta Oribe, who directly or indirectly had a catalytic effect on art, particularly art associated with that most sacramental of all intimate social events, the tea ceremony. The show has dozens of funky-beautiful ceramic tea vessels in the squashed, pulled and racked Oribe style, along with resplendent genre paintings and textiles. Several objects will be rotated out, and new ones added, on Dec. 3. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "UNREPENTANT EGO: THE SELF-PORTRAITS OF LUCAS SAMARAS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Feb. 8. The alternately dark and ecstatic, mostly flaming rainbow coalition of personae that Mr. Samaras has pulled out of himself over the last 45 years is everywhere apparent in this sprawling yet sharply focused show. It pays tribute to his prodigious, highly disciplined self-absorption with some 300 works: dozens of his glittering, menacing box sculptures; his velvety early pastels; his still astounding Polaroids. Also on view is a little-seen film, "Self" from 1969; it displays in close-up his obsessive, home-alone artistic process and his continuous sifting and mixing of motifs and mediums. He is an alchemist of the first order, a claustrophiliac with a genius for filling small spaces with psychic and visual refractions. He was also making the new gay art before there was such a thing. From just about every angle -- identity, craft, performance -- this is an engrossing, timely show. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

Galleries: 57th Street

GARY BASEMAN, "Happy Idiot: And Other Paintings About Unattainable Beauty," Earl McGrath, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 956-3366, through Nov. 29. Mr. Baseman's funky cartoon paintings are funny, weird, touching and made with economical panache. In desolate, often flooded landscapes, mermaids, skeletons, snowmen, snakes, animated ice cream cones and all sorts of unidentifiable demons act out manic dramas of sexual longing, bemusement, abjection, terror and mystic revelation (Johnson).

ERIC FISCHL, "Krefeld Project: Studies," Mary Boone, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 752-2929, through Dec. 20. The digitally processed photographs in this show were the basis for a recent series of paintings: images of a man and a woman, apparently prosperous art collectors, lounging around their luxurious modern home in various states of undress. In fact, the photographs were staged using models and a Mies van der Rohe house that is now a museum in Krefeld, Germany. The photographs exude a creepy cinematic allure (Johnson).

DONALD JUDD, Anthony Grant, 37 West 57th Street, (212) 755-0434, through Jan. 10. This small gem of a show presents five sculptures dating from 1964 to 1989 and a series of working drawings for various sculptures. Judd didn't like being called a Minimalist and rightfully so: his geometrical permutations and his surfaces of rusted or polished metal and richly colored lacquers add up to objects of riveting abstract complexity, sensuous beauty and iconic mystery (Johnson).

* "AD REINHARDT AND CONTEMPORARIES: 1940-50," Barbara Mathes, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 725-5135, through Dec. 20. Gallery shows of Reinhardt are not an everyday event, which is reason enough to put this one on your things-to-do list. The paintings, most of them from the 1940's, are evidence of an artist in the throes of experimentation. The beautiful little "Yellow Variations" (1941) finds him working in a gestural, turgid Cubist-Expressionist vein. Two years later, this turns into a cool, crisp, gloom-free Stuart Davisesque composition in bleached beiges and pinks. The style-hopping is still in progress in the 1950's tangle of colors reminiscent of Guston's abstract paintings. As a bonus, there is brace of works by contemporaries, including Davis, Gorky and de Kooning (Cotter).

AKIO TAKAMORI, "Omnipotent," Garth Clark, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 246-2205, through Dec. 6. East meets West in ceramic figurative sculpture by an artist who was born in Japan but has lived in the United States for almost 30 years. Loosely painted in dry blacks and grays, the large stoneware sculptures of women, based on traditional Tang figures, are voluptuously rounded and graceful; the sculptures of women in elaborate dresses, derived from paintings by Velazquez and Goya, look stiff and curiously anxious (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

PHILIP GUSTON, BRUCE NAUMAN, RAYMOND PETTIBON, Brooke Alexander, 59 Wooster Street, (212) 925-4338, through Dec. 21. Converging from three directions -- Abstract Expressionism, Process Art and California Pop -- three artists arrive at a zone of mordant existentialism. Consisting almost entirely of black-and-white prints, the exhibition sets up an absorbing, triangular conversation among Guston's studio nightmares, Mr. Nauman's harsh wordplay and Mr. Pettibon's mix of hare-brained erudition and comic-book illustration (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

MARK DI SUVERO, Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105, through Nov. 29. This show features two sculptures by the heavy-metal Constructivist, one huge and one moderately massive. The giant one, titled "XV," is a 1971 assemblage of six enormous, rusty I-beams leaning together in a precarious-looking structure that tops off at almost 22 feet. "Hopesoup," from 1990, is an assemblage of salvaged industrial parts, some of which ponderously revolve on spindles if you give them a push (Johnson).

VINCENT GEYSKENS, "Intrusion and Separation," Thomas Erben, 516 West 20th Street, (212) 645-8701, through Dec. 6. This young Belgian artist makes suavely dissonant paintings with a philosophical edge. The imagery -- exotic dancers, still lifes, dark, empty interiors and pure abstractions -- is vaguely dreadful. But the way he shifts stylistic gears from one picture to another, from crusty Cubism to viscous Expressionism to dry Minimalism, makes his project mainly an inquiry into the nature of painting itself (Johnson).

HOWARD HODGKIN, Gagosian, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111, through Dec. 20. The much venerated British artist paints with wide brushes and colors that range from muddy greens to gaudy pinks, oranges and turquoise. As usual he paints over old frames and panels, working from laptop to Abstract Expressionist scale. Boxed in by wide strokes that simultaneously obliterate and emphasize the frame, interior parts read as broadly abstracted landscapes, sunsets or rooms. Mr. Hodgkin's romantic exuberance is infectious (Johnson).

ISAAC JULIEN, "Baltimore," Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, (212) 206-7100, through Dec. 14. "Baltimore," a short film projected on three adjoining screens, is partly a pastiche of 1970's blaxpoitation cinema and partly a surrealistic allegory about race, class and history. It follows a man -- played by the actor and director Melvin Van Peebles -- and a woman in a mysterious cat-and-mouse game that takes them through a variety of museum galleries. There are moments of lyrical beauty, but the whole is weighed down by academic didacticism (Johnson).

TRACY MILLER and "FRIGHTWIG," Feature, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 675-7772, through Dec. 19. Ms. Miller paints crusty, all-over cornucopias of food imagery -- lobsters, beer cans, pies, cakes, fruit and so on -- with a connective tissue of playful, more or less abstract painterly mark-making. In the backroom, "Frightwig," a belated Halloween show, includes a scary paper wraith by Tom Friedman; a magical pipe-cleaner floor sculpture by Lucky DeBellevue; a small, mysterious boy's face drawn by Jerry Phillips; and what looks like a brain on stilts, painted by Kevin Wolff (Johnson).

CHUCK NANNEY, "More Songs About Sex and Death," Debs & Co., 525 West 26th Street, (212) 643-2070, through Nov. 29. "Old Sparky," a child-size electric chair neatly made of corrugated cardboard; a Russian doll in a Mexican wrestling mask; Manson-murders graffiti spelled out in the typeface used on suburban mailboxes; layered word drawings; cheerful abstract watercolors; and a colorful lineup of 101 painted wooden dowels: all this bespeaks a mind uncommonly alive to the aesthetic and sociological vicissitudes of modern American culture (Johnson).

Other Galleries

SARAH BRAMAN AND BRIAN BELOTT, Canada, 55 Chrystie Street, Lower East Side, (212) 925-4631, through Nov. 30. These artists were made for each other and for this moment of psychedelically flavored, busywork formalism in art. Ms. Braman's abstract geometric sculpures are like giant crystals in formation, one constructed from painted cardboard, the other from plexiglass. Mr. Bellot's collages fill the gallery walls. Most are paper-on-paper using clips from magazines, food wrappers, cartoons and children's books, with the occasional addition of paint, fabric and kitty litter. The ingredients join to create dreamlike landscapes, part fairy tale, part science fiction, though a little too weird to be utopian (Cotter).

* "EVERYTHING MATTERS: PAUL KOS, A RETROSPECTIVE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through Dec. 6. Mr. Kos's name rings too few bells here. He helped germinate the Bay Area Conceptual movement that pioneered video, performance and installation art in the late 1960's and early 70's. The spirit of his work is lighthearted and sly. One of his best early videos, from 1974, was shot in Wyoming: "Pilot Butte/Pilot Light" switches back and forth between that butte and Mr. Kos fashioning a lens out of a block of ice (you see him spinning the block on the inside of the lid of a pot to get the proper curvature), then focusing sunlight through the ice to spark kindling. The constant is Mr. Kos's catholic approach to materials. He balances a candle and a bell on the tip of a broomstick, which he discovered one day would stand up on its own if he jammed the business end of the broom against the floor just right. Better late than never to remind New Yorkers that some of what we take to be fresh has been going on for a long time elsewhere (Kimmelman).

* "THE INVISIBLE THREAD: BUDDHIST SPIRIT IN CONTEMPORARY ART," Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art at Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Staten Island, (718) 448-2500, through Feb. 29. "Everyone Gets Lighter" is the good-news message on a billboard across the street from the Snug Harbor Cultural Center. The words, by the New York poet John Giorno, serve as introduction to "The Invisible Thread," and after seeing the show, you may indeed feel a bit lifted up. Conceived as the centerpiece of a yearlong multi-institutional series of events called "The Buddhism Project," it brings together 50 contemporary artists, some practicing Buddhists, some not, to distill the Buddhist spirit of the title, an essence as elusive, but as complex and distinctive, as the scent of incense (Cotter).

"MEMORY AND DISAPPEARANCE: RECENT THAI ART," Momenta Art, 72 Berry Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 218-8058, through Dec. 1. New art from Thailand, where a very interesting contemporary art scene is bubbling away, has been the subject of a few New York shows recently. This one does its modest share to further fill out the picture, with a quartet of artists, each caught in a double-bind position of resisting traditional culture and deeply mistrusting what is replacing it (Cotter).

Last Chance

VINCENT LONGO, "Reflections on Abstraction," Hunter College Times Square Gallery, 450 West 41st Street, (212) 772-4991, through tomorrow. A five-decade 160-painting retrospective celebrates Mr. Longo's retirement after 35 years of teaching at Hunter College. Starting out under the influence of Abstract Expressionism, Mr. Longo turned to the grid and never looked back. His evolutionary exploration of the tactile, optical and spiritual possibilities is consistently engaging all the way through (Johnson).

* JIM NUTT, Nolan/Eckman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 925-6190, through Wednesday. The dean of Chicago Imagism delivers once again. This exhibition includes three beautiful laptop-scale paintings of imaginary women who seem, despite Cubist distortions, uncannily alive. Painted with exquisite care in tiny brush strokes, the women exude a haunting maternal warmth but also seem a little crazy. Each of a dozen graphite portraits is a marvel of linear delicacy, exactitude and invention (Johnson).

GABRIEL OROZCO, Marian Goodman, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160, through tomorrow. As usual, this sly Mexican artist achieves maximum visual elegance with a minimum of effort and not much in the way of material, while also rifling through the conventions of Process Art and Arte Povera. Polyurethane foam and wire screening are the materials here, and the opening gambit -- a large gallery that resembles an aquarium full of large, slightly abstracted fish -- is magical, even if it also creates the feeling of having time-traveled back to Lynda Benglis's studio in 1969. The rest mostly offers too much work too casually made (Smith).

JOHN WILLENBECHER, "Finding the Given," exhibition hallway of Mina Rees Library, Graduate Center, City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street, (212) 817-7177, through tomorrow. Since the 1980's Mr. Willenbecher has devoted himself to paintings rather than sculpture, and the more than 50 abstract acrylics on wooden panels here exemplify his successful search for a takeoff point that he calls a "given," a more or less happenstance situation like flipping paint from a loaded brush onto a surface. These marbleized compositions of dots, splotches, veins, pools, bursts and trickles of variegated color, are quite lovely. Despite the partial "chance" derivation, their delicate tonal balances seem well planned. Especially appealing is a small group whose colors are confined to black, gray and white (Glueck).

GRAPHIC: Photos: An untitled 1948 painting by Ad Reinhardt, at the Barbara Mathes Gallery on East 57th Street. (Photo by Barbara Mathes Gallery); Guggenheim: James Rosenquist's "Welcome to the Water Planet." (Photo by James Rosenquist)

HEADLINE: Home for the Holidays? Thanks but No Thanks 

BYLINE:  By SARAH ROBERTSON 

 BODY:
FOR the last 30 years, James and Luise Pace have cooked Thanksgiving dinner for their family of eight at their Somers, Conn., home. So what are they doing this year? Flying to Prague for four days to hear classical music. "I get tired of having everyone over and then cleaning up afterward," said Mr. Pace, 57, who owns an auto-leasing company. "The way it's going, I might just leave on Christmas."
 Going to Grandma's house for Thanksgiving? Not unless she lives on St. Bart's, thanks. According to travel agencies and resorts, more and more people are going away for the Thanksgiving holiday -- and leaving the family behind. At British Airways, late-November bookings to London from Los Angeles are running almost twice last year's (and they are up 28 percent from New York), while resorts like the adults-only Auberge du Soleil in Rutherford, Calif., say that holiday reservations are up as much as 20 percent. 
 Gate 1 Travel, a travel agency that started offering Thanksgiving packages to places like Prague and Rio de Janeiro two years ago, has sold 7,000 of them this season, up from 2,000 last year. "This is one of those holidays that caught me by surprise," said Dani Pipano, the owner of Gate 1, which is based in Glenside, Pa. "It's been a huge product for us."
While some people may be taking the whole family with them for the holiday, hotels and travel consultants say that some of the strongest growth has come from people who are traveling without their loved ones. Two years after 9/11, "everyone has reconnected," said John Fareed, a senior vice president at Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell, a travel marketing and research firm. "There's a lot less pressure to do the family thing." 
Indeed, the adults-only Canoe Bay resort in northwest Wisconsin has "a lot of people who call and say they need to get away from the kids," according to Dan Dobrowolski, an owner of the hotel, whose rooms start at $290 a night. "They say, 'If I spend another minute with my mother-in-law I might get violent.' "
But skipping out on the family celebration is not always as easy as getting a good deal on a package to the Caribbean. Some people, like Rochelle Santiago, 36, an information technology analyst in Foster City, Calif., are so worried about offending their families that they move the celebration to a different date. She said she would be taking her parents out to dinner tomorrow -- and was still looking for a restaurant where they could have turkey -- so that she could spend the actual holiday in Paris with her boyfriend, guilt free. 
Then there are the people who take an even simpler route: lying. This Thanksgiving, Charla Caponi, a 29-year-old event manager in New York, is planning to go to Italy with a friend instead of to her family's annual get-together, which is in Toronto this year. But as far as her parents are concerned, she will be hard at work at her office. "I didn't want to have to deal with the guilt," Ms. Caponi said. "I'd rather go play hooky and have fun." (She said that she would visit her parents at Christmas, though.)
IN fact, the etiquette expert Peggy Post advises, all the angst may not be necessary. Bowing out of a family gathering is fine, as long as it is done thoughtfully and with as much advance warning as possible. "Change is hard for a lot of people," she said. "Do it early and talk it through. Sometimes it's good to broach the idea and see how it flies."
Besides, it may turn out that Mom and Dad are only too happy to hear you won't be making it back to the nest -- since traveling somewhere other than home on Thanksgiving can mean finding cheap airfares and hotel rooms, empty museums and easy-to-get tables at usually packed restaurants. After Bob and Kitty Davis's children told them they could not get home this year, the couple booked a week in Paris. "This was a week that unexpectedly opened up," said Mr. Davis, a lawyer in Washington. 
The Thanksgiving exodus is part of an uptick in the travel market, which has been hard hit by both 9/11 and the sluggish economy. According to a recent AAA survey, an estimated 36 million Americans will travel 50 miles or more from home this Thanksgiving, up 2.4 percent from last year; 4.6 million of them will travel by plane, up about 1 percent from 2002. The number of people leaving the children at home when they travel is growing, too. In 2003, 68 percent of leisure travelers said they had taken one or more trips in the previous year without their children, up four percentage points from the 2002 results, according to a survey done jointly by Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell and Yankelovich Partners, another research company.
Not surprisingly, resorts and travel Web sites are hoping to encourage the trend, with special offers for travelers who skip the holiday at home, from a Thanksgiving red-lentil loaf at Kripalu, a Lenox, Mass., yoga center, to a fiesta at the Esperanza Resort in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico. The St. James's Club, an all-inclusive resort on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia, is promoting a "Ditch the In-Laws" package, with free meals for children and a second room at half price on stays starting at three days. And this year, for the first time, Site59, a travel packager, is offering "Just Skip Town This Thanksgiving" deals for long weekends in places like Miami and the Bahamas. As the Web site notes, "going home for the holidays for canned cranberry sauce and green bean casserole may not be everyone's ideal use of a four-day weekend."
Heather Whiles, 27, a Palm Beach, Fla., financial advisor, said that she thought skipping her family's elaborate Thanksgiving -- usually 50 people in attendance -- and going to London would be the perfect way to spend her holiday this year. She bought her ticket and made plans to stay with friends in England. Then she started thinking about the deep-fried turkey, mashed potatoes and lemon meringue pie being served at her cousin's house and, last week, she postponed her London plans and got a ticket for Boston. "I just decided I actually, really want to go home," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: NO FAMILY FEAST THIS YEAR -- Luise and James Pace of Somers, Conn., looked at Prague-related Web sites as they prepared for their Thanksgiving trip. Right, Charla Caponi of New York got ready for her holiday trip to Italy. (Photo by George Gutierrez for The New York Times); (Photo by George Ruhe for The New York Times)(pg. F3) Drawing (Drawing by Christophe Niemann)(pg. F1)

COMPANY: YPARTNERSHIP (65%); BRITISH AIRWAYS PLC (56%)

HEADLINE: McGreevey Tells Local Officials There Are Too Many of Them 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 19 

 BODY:
Warning that escalating property taxes threaten to strangle New Jersey's economy and undermine its quality of life, Gov. James E. McGreevey challenged the state's municipal leaders on Thursday to reduce the size of local government by consolidating services and merging some small school districts.
 Speaking to a convention of local municipal officials, Mr. McGreevey said New Jersey had more local governments per capita than any other state and also spent more on school bureaucracy than any other state. The governor also bemoaned the state's bloated educational system, which has 172 school districts that have only one building and 23 that paidadministrators who operated no buildings. "This is ludicrous," he said. "It is wasteful and it is driving up property taxes every year." 
 For decades, elected officials, academics and government watchdogs have blamed New Jersey's labyrinth of local governments for the state's onerous property taxes and high cost of living, saying that the inefficient bureaucracy acted as a kind of welfare system for the politically connected. But it came as something of a surprise that Mr. McGreevey would raise the issue, quite bluntly, during his keynote address at the New Jersey League of Municipalities annual convention, attended by hundreds of local officials from across the state.
The governor's remarks included few specific proposals for combining the services of local governments or eliminating unnecessary school boards or municipalities, and even his supporters acknowledged that any such effort would meet with bitter political resistance in the communities and in the State Legislature. But he pledged to make the issue a major focus of the coming legislative session and signaled an attempt to insulate himself from Republican attacks on property taxes as his re-election campaign for 2005 draws closer.
In the years before Mr. McGreevey took power, Republicans enacted a series of property tax rebates, which the governor now blames for fueling the state's high debt and budget deficit. But Mr. McGreevey said that he would not seek to lower property taxes by increasing borrowing or by raising other taxes, and instead wanted to cut the waste from the various local bureaucracies.
The speech seemed to surprise many members of the audience, whose jobs in local government were the kind of positions the governor seemed to be describing as wasteful.

HEADLINE: Latest Merger Makes It Clearer Than Ever: Hartford Is No Longer the Insurance Capital 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
Tucked into this week's announcement of a merger between two insurance companies, the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation and the St. Paul Companies, was the news that the consolidated company will move its headquarters to Minnesota, removing another chess piece from Hartford's already diminished board. Within two years, the city once known as the insurance capital of the world will be the home office of just two major insurance corporations.
 "The insurance capital? I don't even think it's an insurance capital anymore," said Richard L. Huber, chief executive of Aetna from 1997 to 2000 and now a private investor with homes in Hartford and Manhattan. 
 There will still be plenty of insurance-business jobs in Hartford. But what the shift means to the culture of a place that traditionally looked to the giants of the insurance industry for leadership is less clear.
No one knows how many jobs will be gained or lost because of the merger between Travelers and St. Paul. "The ink is barely dry on the deal," said Keith Anderson, chief communications officer for Travelers, who estimated that about 8 percent of the companies' $350 million expenses would be saved in the deal, some of it in jobs. But the deal marks another landmark in Hartford's evolution from the days when "the bishops," as the chairmen of Hartford's leading insurance companies were known, sat on charity boards and served as the city's financial and political patrons. 
Today, Hartford is the home of the Phoenix Companies and the Hartford Financial Services Group, both founded in the 19th century. But their colleagues have moved on.
Although Aetna retained its health care division in Hartford, its financial services division was sold to ING Groep, a Dutch company, in 2000. After the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company merged with MassMutual in 1996, the company's headquarters moved to Springfield, Mass. When the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company merged with the INA Corporation to become Cigna in 1983, the home office became Philadelphia.
On Monday, Prudential Financial announced that it was buying Cigna's Hartford-based retirement investment business; Cigna's health care division will remain in the nearby suburb Bloomfield.
To be sure, insurance remains a vital source of jobs in Hartford; 17 percent of all jobs in the city are with insurance carriers, compared with 3.2 percent statewide, according to the Connecticut Labor Department.
But the departure of the home office, its chief executives and its attendant upper management means the loss not only of money for cultural and charity organizations, but also of civic leaders in a city long on urban ills, said Nancy Roberts, president of the Connecticut Council for Philanthropy.
According to the 2000 census, 30.6 percent of Hartford's 125,000 residents live below the poverty line. Forty percent of the adult population is functionally illiterate, and more than half the city's students drop out of high school. The per capita income is $13,428. 
Tom Baker, a professor at the University of Connecticut School of Law and director of its insurance law center, said the changing dynamic is a positive. "You get people leaving one company to start another," he said. "These smaller, related businesses make Hartford the Silicon Valley of the insurance industry."
But Hartford is banking on continued corporate support. By the summer of 2005, $2 billion of development is expected to be completed, including Adriaen's Landing, a hotel and conference center championed by Gov. John G. Rowland as a new beginning for the city.
In the old Hartford, the social, economic, and political fabric was enmeshed with the insurance giants. Its chairmen and top executives were among Hartford's first families, whose names grace the city's buildings and bridges. For example, Morgan Gardner Bulkeley was chairman of Aetna Life & Casualty from 1879 to 1922 and served as mayor of Hartford, governor of Connecticut and United States senator.
Ellsworth Grant, a historian whose books include "The Miracle of Connecticut," said that Travelers financed Hartford's first urban renewal project, Constitution Plaza, in 1960, and Aetna built the Civic Center in 1974.
John H. Motley, the president of the Travelers Foundation, said the tradition of commitment and giving to the city endures. The foundation gave $5 million to city cultural institutions and charities last year. 
Mr. Motley, who on Wednesday was named chairman of the board of Hartford's Wadsworth Atheneum, the nation's oldest public art museum, said that while Hartford is not the insurance capital of the country anymore, the trend toward consolidation means that neither is any other city. In 1993, Travelers had 8,000 employees in Hartford. Today, the three Hartford divisions of the company employ 8,200.
"What happens in Hartford, regardless of the cosmetic issue of the headquarter locations, is the insurance and financial services presence in Hartford is about the same as it was 10 years ago," Mr. Motley said. 
But Mr. Huber, the former Aetna executive, maintains that a city that is both headquarters and home to its chairman will reap the benefits.
"When the C.E.O. lives elsewhere, you don't see your staff members in a social situation," he said. "The cultural institutions are not the ones in your neighborhood. You end up with a remote-controlled operation."

A TIMELINE
Hartford's Vanishing Insurers

THE CIGNA CORPORATION, a company created in 1982 by the merger of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company (founded in Hartford in 1865) and INA, moved its headquarters from Bloomfield, a Hartford suburb, to Philadelphia in 1983. Prudential Financial announced on Monday that it was buying Cigna's retirement investment business. Cigna's health care division has its headquarters in Hartford.

THE CONNECTICUT MUTUAL LIFE INSURANCE COMPANY, established in 1846, merged with MassMutual in 1996. MassMutual has its headquarters in Springfield, Mass.

THE AETNA LIFE INSURANCE COMPANY, established in 1853, sold its property casualty division to Travelers in 1996 and its financial services division to ING Groep, a Dutch company, in 2000. Aetna maintains its health division in Hartford.

HARTFORD STEAM BOILER, founded in 1866, became a subsidiary of the New York-based American Insurance Group in 2001.

THE TRAVELERS PROPERTY CASUALTY CORPORATION, established in 1864 as the Travelers Insurance Company and independent after being spun off from Citigroup in 2002, announced on Monday that it will merge with the St. Paul Companies. The St. Paul Travelers Companies will have headquarters in St. Paul.

THE HARTFORD FINANCIAL SERVICES GROUP, founded in 1810 as the Hartford Fire Insurance Company, has its headquarters in Hartford.

THE PHOENIX COMPANIES, established in 1851, has its headquarters in Hartford.

HEADLINE: Hearing Splits on Public Help For a Proposed Office Tower 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
The prospect of another skyscraper sets off a hue and cry in many Manhattan neighborhoods, but rarely in the glass-and-steel canyons along the Avenue of the Americas or 42nd Street.
 But a local landlord, a local civic group and some politicians railed at a public hearing yesterday about a proposed 51-story, $1 billion skyscraper that would serve as a headquarters for Bank of America on the block between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas, from 42nd to 43rd Streets. Critics opposed not so much the tower but public subsidies for the 2.1-million-square-foot project and the state's use of condemnation to gain control of the land. 
 Bank of America and its partner, the developer Douglas Durst, marshaled supporters, including the Real Estate Board, city and state officials, theater groups, the construction industry and an environmental group. The hearing was sponsored by the Empire State Development Corporation.
Mr. Durst, whose family owns all but three parcels on the block, has asked the state to condemn the site so that the project can go forward quickly, a move opposed by one landowner on the block.
"They're using the power of eminent domain to benefit private corporations, not for a public purpose," said the landowner, Joseph Bernstein, who is part of a group that owns two parcels on the block. Mr. Bernstein said the project would destroy new retail shops and override landmark laws while using $650 million in tax-free Liberty Bonds intended to revive Lower Manhattan.
Mr. Durst said yesterday that the building was an important project for the city and would generate $30 million a year in tax revenue.
In a letter submitted for the hearing, Andrew Alper, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said the project underlined New York's position as a financial capital. In defending the subsidies -- $650 million in bonds and $56.4 million in tax breaks -- Mr. Alper has said Bank of America is moving two of its four major divisions to New York.
But Tara Burke, a spokeswoman for Bank of America, said the bank's global corporate investment banking division and its asset management group were already in New York.
Wall Street analysts said Bank of America, based in North Carolina, wanted to move to a signature building in a prominent location to show it was a contender in investment banking. If the bank wanted a less expensive deal, real estate brokers said, it could move downtown, where rents are 30 percent lower than uptown.
Bettina Damiani, director of Good Jobs New York, and other critics of subsidy deals pointed out that there was no guarantee a corporation would make good on its promise to "grow jobs in New York." Bank of America, for instance, got more than $15 million in tax breaks and cash grants in 1993 to move to the World Trade Center instead of the suburbs. But the city terminated the benefit package in 1998 after the bank's payroll fell to 800, well below the 1,700 envisioned in the deal.

HEADLINE: Watching Over Freddie and Fannie 

 BODY:
Our political system can be rather nimble at reacting to financial crises, but when it comes to preventing them, well, that's another matter. Issues that seem more urgent can get in the way of reforms that can stave off the next crisis, as can bureaucratic inertia and the fact that the status quo benefits powerful interests.
 Efforts in Washington to strengthen financial oversight of the government-chartered mortgage giants, Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, are a case in point. Accounting irregularities at both companies in recent months, though not in themselves catastrophic, have served as a warning that it no longer makes any sense to have these institutions regulated by an obscure office within the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
 The Bush administration is rightly pushing for the Treasury Department to regulate the two giants, along with the network of federal home loan banks. Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae provide financing to lenders by creating a secondary market for mortgages. All told, these two institutions' debt portfolio exceeds more than $1.5 trillion. Their current regulator is ill equipped to keep tabs on Freddie's and Fannie's sophisticated hedging strategies and the other financial moves they use to manage their huge investments.
Lax regulatory oversight of these companies is made more worrisome by confusion over the extent to which Uncle Sam backs them up. An "implied guarantee" gives Freddie and Fannie a competitive advantage in the marketplace, part of which is passed on to home buyers. But there is a danger (remember the savings and loan crisis?) in having the marketplace complacently assume that normal risk assessments need not apply to these players.
Even without signs of an imminent calamity, it is hard to argue that these financial enterprises -- essentially two huge hedge funds -- should continue to evade the type of rigorous oversight that banks face on issues like capital requirements and new lines of business. Yet it looks as if Freddie and Fannie, along with the home builders' lobby, may succeed in blocking legislation to transfer regulatory oversight to the Treasury. 
The two mortgage enterprises have helped to add liquidity to the housing market and put more working families in new homes. That mission need not be threatened by stronger oversight of their finances. Indeed, it will be protected.
