HEADLINE: ON THE JOB; 
Foiling the Office Bully (With Sand in Your Face)

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
The topic of workplace bullying clearly exposed a raw nerve, bringing mail with many accounts. Some had a touch of humor, but many were despairing, filled with recollections of bullies who lied to their superiors when challenged, companies that turned their backs on the problem and victims reduced to nightmarish lives.
 "Bullies?" asks A.C. Willment, an editor for a publisher of legal treatises in Manhattan. "In a quarter-century in the work force, in both nonprofit and profit and both large and small organizations, I've assembled quite a menagerie." 
 But at the top of her list is the passive-aggressive bully, a type she likens to Herman Melville's main character in "Bartleby the Scrivener." Ms. Willment notes that literary critics do not usually describe Bartleby as a bully, but she says she thinks they might want to reconsider. 
"He exercises his power by establishing your impotence; malice sets him apart from the standard procrastinator. A Bartleby -- often but not always a superior -- can torpedo your projects, blow your deadlines, make you look incompetent and waste massive amounts of your time.
"I tangled with a Bartleby who was responsible for generating a particular document for me. Days turned into weeks, deadlines drew nigh and I couldn't get it out of him with the 'jaws of life.' I couldn't even get a good excuse.
"My supervisor (roughly Bartleby's equal in the pecking order) came by my desk, and I confessed I was stymied. She smiled, picked up my phone and buzzed Bartleby. Our phones had a display feature similar to caller ID.
"Bartleby answered the phone with a weary 'Oh-Gawd-it's-you-again' drawl. My supervisor identified herself as calling from my phone and inquired about the document, which got drafted and delivered with a speed that implied the question, 'Why wasn't this possible two weeks ago?"'
"The most outrageous example of workplace bullying occurred at a company I was asked to consult to," writes Joseph R. Weintraub, a professor of management and organizational behavior at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass. At the company, he encountered a senior executive who liked to talk about "cracking the whip if people were not performing to his satisfaction."
The executive, Dr. Weintraub notes, was not just talking.
"To play out his threat, he had a real cowboy bullwhip on his wall, which he would use from time to time and actually crack it in the hall outside his office to show his ire," Dr. Weintraub writes.
"Employees expressed their apprehension about even coming to work while this person was on the loose and were fearful about reporting him since he had recently been hired in a key managerial position.
"His whipping days, however, came to an abrupt halt when he accidentally hit a senior executive as she was walking to her office." 
He was fired.
"It is time to expose workplace bullying for what it really is -- a form of harassment that should not be tolerated in any work environment," writes Julie Juliano Acerra of Long Branch, N.J.
"As both a victim and a witness, I was so tired and depressed hearing complaints from other employees and experiencing the behavior myself, I felt that because of my position (the personnel officer), I had to be the one to go on the record," Ms. Acerra writes. "I did extensive research and learned that the reason this type of behavior is allowed is because it is not illegal, under present standards.
"I asked for and received a revised, written harassment policy with the idea that maybe the bullies would get the hint and retreat, but that was to no avail. The policy was carefully worded to address sexual harassment only, and I was not at all surprised.
"I attended a seminar hosted by my state's Civil Rights Commission and asked a simple question: 'Isn't everyday harassment in the workplace illegal?' Four lawyers and two moderators were stumped.
"Their answer was: not unless you are in a protected class; in other words, the harassment had to be proven to relate specifically to gender, age, ethnicity, etc. This legal loophole in the law is the size of the Grand Canyon."
In the end, Ms. Acerra says, after five years of "enduring threats, foul language, ridicule and unfounded criticism," she received help from her union. She turned over her documentation in the form of a journal, as well as letters and memos from former employees. "An investigation ensued, others came forward and finally the bullies backed off. Suddenly I had a life again and did not dread going to work on Monday morning."
Emphasizing the importance of documentation in building a case, Ms. Acerra writes: "I wrote on scraps of paper, Post-its and in binders, relaying as much information as I could about being threatened and/or verbally attacked. I wrote down dates, time of day and who was in the room at the time."
Her final words: "Bullies are not really all that smart. They are self-involved and self-important to their own peril. In they end, they expose themselves."
Arnold Lippin of Brooklyn was working for a small biopharmaceutical company when a new chief executive was brought in to prepare it for its transition from nonprofit status to that of a publicly held corporation. 
The tone was set with the first meeting, which, he says, "began with a vicious harangue that alluded to our having a nonprofit mentality and stating that we had better start toeing the line of the for-profit world or we would not make it."
Mr. Lippin, not about to be bullied by someone who had arrived with a clear reluctance to accept the staff, immediately pointed out the competence of his colleagues. Matters were not about to improve, and Mr. Lippin was not about to defer to the new boss's tyranny.
"When he arbitrarily changed all the office furniture to blue, I stopped the guys from taking my favorite peach chair," he writes. "I was told with a sense of anxiety that the 'boss' had said to do it.
"I told them if they were confronted to say I wanted to be spoken to directly. I never heard from him on this or any other issue." Mr. Lippin encouraged his colleagues to use tit for tat in their dealings with the bully, taking the position that if he cooperated, they would cooperate; if he confronted, they would confront -- but to start with cooperation.
In the end, Mr. Lippin's job was not cut any earlier than anyone else's.
"With hindsight, I realize I did not acknowledge his authority simply as a result of his position, and he knew it," Mr. Lippin writes. "He also knew that I would not interact with him solely within the system that protected him. Rather than engage me in a productive manner that would earn my trust and loyalty, he avoided me because he could not bully me." 
Gregory Alford has a few words about bullies who are their own ultimate victims. 
"When I was a journalist working at daily newspapers, I served under several editors who desperately needed anger management training," writes Mr. Alford, now a communications manager at OSF St. Anthony Medical Center in Rockford, Ill. 
"The worst of the lot," he said, was the managing editor of a daily newspaper published in the afternoon, which meant that most of the deadlines were before 9 a.m. Unfortunately for Mr. Alford and his colleagues, the editor in question was not a morning person.
"Working in a large open room with the entire editorial staff (20 or so at any given time), he seemed to enjoy having an audience for his frequent temper tantrums," he said. "If someone called him on the phone while he was laying out or proofing a page, he slammed the phone with contempt after the conversation ended. He often slammed the receiver onto the body of the phone several times, just for emphasis.
"Once, he slammed the receiver down so hard that he shattered the base of the phone. He thought it was hilarious and immediately hung the phone on the wall of the newsroom to remind all of us of his power and contempt of interruptions. An additional sign of his masculinity was a metal garbage can with a large dent caused by his foot, which he proudly displayed at his newsroom desk.
That wasn't all, Mr. Alford said. . "If you began looking for another job while still at that paper, you had to tell him or you would be fired. Of course, when anyone told him they were looking for work in a less psychotic environment, he would pout and either stop talking to that person or begin a demeaning vocal campaign to speed their departure."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Don't Be Lulled: Interest Rates Could Be Poised to Leap

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
WHEN thinking of interest rates, think of a coiled spring. That tells you how quickly Treasury yields could rise, driving down prices across the fixed-income market.
 Rates have risen well above the 45-year lows they reached in June, when the Treasury's 10-year note was at 3.11 percent. But they haven't gone up as much as might be expected. Now at 4.16 percent, the yield is well below the 2003 high of 4.60 percent, reached on Sept. 2. Some forecasters had predicted that the yield would reach 5 percent when the economy got back on track. 
 Well, the economy is expanding rapidly. It grew at a 7.2 percent annual rate in the third quarter and is forecast to move ahead at a pace of 4 to 5 percent this quarter. 
Rising expectations of inflation should also be pushing rates higher. Since the end of August, the expected inflation rate derived from the Treasury's 10-year inflation-protected security has climbed to 2.25 percent, from 1.98 percent.
Why have interest-rate increases been slow? One reason is the current "deal of the day" in the Treasury market. But because traders' inclinations can change suddenly -- and the economic forces for higher rates are already in place -- the rate spring is coiled tightly.
The deal of the day is called a carry trade. It is simple. Institutional investors, like banks, borrow money for the short term at a very low interest rate and use the cash to buy a longer-term security paying a higher interest rate. Then they pocket the difference.
For example, banks can borrow at the federal funds rate, about 1 percent, and use the money to buy two-year Treasury notes, which yield 1.82 percent, or three-year notes, which yield 2.35 percent. 
In normal circumstances, this would be a risky strategy, because a sudden upturn in short-term interest rates could quickly produce a loss. But Federal Reserve policy makers have reduced the risk by promising to keep their target for the federal funds rate at 1 percent for some time.
The fact that shorter-term rates have been held back -- the 1.85 percent yield on the two-year note is below its September high of 2.04 percent -- has also helped restrain the rise in the Treasury's 10-year note, analysts said.
"Short-term rates act as an anchor for longer-term rates," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research in Princeton, N.J. Rates had been rising, he said, "until we got reassurances from Fed officials that they would not pull the trigger quickly" on a rate increase.
Futures contracts on the federal funds rate now show that many investors don't expect a Fed rate increase until early May, and some forecasters say the Fed will hold fire even longer.
George Strickland of Thornburg Investment Management, which manages about $3.6 billion in fixed-income assets, argues that a ladder strategy -- holding bonds in a carefully planned series of maturities -- is a good defense against a spring back in interest rates.
Generally, Thornburg's portfolios are divided equally into maturities from 1 to 10 years. Those of relatively short terms suffer less of a price loss as rates climb. And after the first year, if rates have leveled off, one-tenth of the portfolio turns back into cash that can be reinvested at higher rates.
THIS is a conservative approach, and it can be a loser in the first year if rates are rising, but it can result in a moderate positive return if rates then level off. Mr. Strickland is being even more cautious in the $1.4 billion Limited Term Municipal Fund National Portfolio which he runs, by shortening his ladder to about eight years. The fund's total return, year to date through Thursday, is 2.99 percent, about three-quarters of a percentage point better than his competitors, according to Morningstar. 
"The coils are compressed," he said, referring to interest rates. "So it's a good time to be cautious."

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Balance aCheckbook? How 20th Century!

BYLINE:  By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
A minibyte of silence, please, for all the skills left in the digital dust by technology's fierce march forward: Wielding a buggy whip. Driving a stick shift. 
Writing a letter (you know, the kind in an envelope).
 Will balancing a checkbook -- a pesky irrelevance to some, a sacred duty to others -- be joining that list soon? A firm called eMarketer, which tallies e-business statistics, reports that the number of American households that do their banking online has more than doubled in just three years, to 27.8 million. It projects that the number will hit 36.3 million by 2005. 
 Why do people want to bank online? To gain better control of their finances, 52 percent say. But remember: a computer screen can be just as messy as a pile of buggy whips. HUBERT B. HERRING

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
The Unnamed Resume

BYLINE:  By Vivian Marino

 BODY:
In the tight employment market, each online job posting can often elicit a flood of electronic resumes. Some come from people who are well qualified for the advertised position, but many resumes may be lacking one important detail: the name of the job seeker in the document file name. 
 ResumeDoctor.com, a resume consulting service, said it recently studied more than 10,000 resumes from a diverse set of industries. It found that nearly 55 percent of the document file names did not contain the job seeker's name. About 24 percent were named some minor variation of "Resume.doc." 
 Brad Fredericks, a spokesman for ResumeDoctor.com, of South Burlington, Vt., says job recruiters compare the sorting of all those unnamed resumes to "looking in a cupboard full of soup cans with their labels torn off." Vivian Marino

HEADLINE: To the Rebuilt Station 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: LOWER MANHATTAN 

 BODY:
IT was all eerily familiar, but different too, this PATH station for New Jersey commuters. Where there had been a solid wall of tiles separating the station from a parking garage, there was now a wall of thick glass, providing a view of a sunlit chasm at the base of what once was the World Trade Center. The stairways and escalators were justas steep as they rose to the street. The stairs even wound past a newsstand rising in the same place where the old one once stood. But the station felt a lot less hermetic than before, largely because of the light streaming into this new underground space through that wall of glass.
 Those were among the cross-grained images gained in a tour last week of the rebuilt PATH station that is to open today, connecting Lower Manhattan to New Jersey by rail for the first time in more than two years. With its opening by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, it will restore direct PATH service to New York City's financial hub for an estimated 60,000 commuters who daily rumbled into and out of the station below the trade center before the Sept. 11, 2001, attack that brought the twin towers crashing down. 
 On the tour last week, Governor McGreevey shook his head in amazement at what had been accomplished in the $550 million rebuilding effort in just 16 months.
 "It represents a tremendous psychological boost," he said, noting that the reopening of the station would restore a link between New Jersey and New York that had helped sustain both states economically. "And this process of rebuilding has been part of the grieving process for what happened here."
 Adding to the eeriness of it all, the rebuilt station occupies the same footprint as the former station. The tracks for the PATH trains come in the same way, and the rebuilt platforms are atop the same imprint as the old ones. Louis Menno, chief engineer for PATH, said that some of the same support columns were being reused after being reinforced. The authority even decided to keep the station name, World Trade Center.
 Mr. Menno and Governor McGreevey said that the decision to keep the name was tied up in the symbols of rebirth and mourning that all those involved with the rebuilding of the trade center site have been juggling.
 The governor conceded that the station was a place forever changed even amid all the self-conscious efforts to make it seem almost the same.
 Port Authority officials said that the PATH line had lost one-third of its riders into Manhattan since trains were rerouted to 34th Street after the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. Menno said the agency had calculated that New Jerseyans who used the line have had to spend as much as $100 more a month each for alternative transportation like cars, buses, ferries and New Jersey Transit trains into Pennsylvania Station. The lure of the cheaper, more direct commute is expected to bring many of those riders back, he said.
 But Anthony Coscia, chairman of the Port Authority, said the agency did not expect a return to the line's previous ridership levels for some time. This was reflected in the decision to construct the new station's track area to accommodate 8-car trains rather than the 10-car trains that were used before the attack.
 Both Mr. Menno and Governor McGreevey sidestepped questions about whether some commuters would find a return to the station too emotional and too tied to the trauma of the days of the terrorist attack. The governor said that many of the workers who were part of the rebuilding had found the process to be a "catharsis," and he suggested that those commuters returning to the station might experience the same kind of relief of anxieties and the quieting of disturbing memories.
 "This is a testimony that we are rebuilding," Governor McGreevey said.
 While the access to the old World Trade Center station was crowned with a retail concourse and the towers themselves, the rebuilt station empties commuters out to the corner of Church Street and Vesey Street under a steel and glass canopy that is capped with the station's name.
 Plans call for extending the station's underground promenade several blocks east to Fulton Street and a new transportation hub that is expected for the first time to allow PATH riders to connect easily with a number of East Side subway lines.
 So, the station will change yet again by the time those elements are in place, by 2006. 
 In the meantime, Mr. Menno said, wall art in the rebuilt station that depicts the outlines of the Lower Manhattan skyline with the twin towers and grainy, aerial photographs of the area was put there "because we wanted people to have a sense of where they were."

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Sorting Out Star Systems

BYLINE:  By SUSAN STELLIN; SUSAN STELLIN writes regularly for the Travel section.

 BODY:
IF you pick up a copy of Mobil's 2004 guide to the best hotels and restaurants in America, you'll find just three five-star hotels listed in New York City.
 Mobil's main competitor in the expanding world of hospitality ratings, the Automobile Association of America, is almost as discriminating: AAA gave its highest award -- five diamonds -- to just five New York City hotels when the company announced its 2004 winners last week. 
 Tough critics, those old-timers, who have been rating American hotels for decades (Mobil since 1958, AAA since 1977). Because as more and more companies get into the business of rating room service, bath towels and bed linens, the stars -- and diamonds and even smiley faces -- have been proliferating like crazy.
 Most of the leading travel Web sites now offer their own ratings for hotels, adding a whole new set of rankings to the cacophony of opinions offered by guidebook publishers, industry associations and travel magazines. And just as the number of rating systems has multiplied, so too have the awards at the upper end of the spectrum, suggesting that a creeping wave of grade inflation may be washing away the boundaries of exclusivity. 
 In a recent search for hotels at Expedia, for instance, the online travel service displayed a whopping 16 five-star properties in New York City. Orbitz wasn't far behind, listing 13 five-star hotels in Manhattan. (Fans of the other boroughs will have to settle for lower thread counts and less attentive service: the city's highest-rated hotels are generally between Central Park and Wall Street.)

The Room Service Test
 So how can travelers be sure what's described by some sources as a five-star hotel will really deliver a five-star experience -- and what exactly do these distinctions mean?
 "The bottom line is one person's five-star hotel is another person's four-star hotel," said Vivian Deuschl, vice president for public relations at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company, whose Central Park South hotel got a high five from both Mobil and AAA this year. With so many rankings out there, Ms. Deuschl said: 
 "It's not easy for the guest to understand what each of them means. But I think within the hotel industry, probably the gold standard in terms of what we aspire to are the Mobil and the AAA highest ratings."
 Shane O'Flaherty, who oversees Mobil's ratings program, said the company had a two-step process to determine a hotel's rank: first, one of Mobil's 50 inspectors evaluates the establishment on various criteria, like whether room service is available around the clock or if the hotel has a pool.
 "Then we move to the incognito service evaluation," he said, which apparently does not mean demanding extraordinary treatment. 
 "We're not really out to trick anyone," Mr. O'Flaherty said. "We're just doing the standard things guests do. Like asking, 'Can you tell me a nice Italian restaurant in the city?"' 
 In this example, he said, three-star service is being given a couple names, while four-star service includes directions and an offer to make a reservation. The five-star treatment? Reservations, written confirmation and calling a car service to take you there.
 Other factors inspectors look at include things like how they're treated when making the reservation, how long the check-in process takes and how quickly their luggage is delivered to the room. It's a job that Mr. O'Flaherty said "gets to be grueling."
 "When you order room service, for example," he said, "you have to order everything from the salad to the dinner to the dessert -- to make sure your ice cream is still standing when you're done with your dinner." 
 Grueling, indeed. Pass the spoon.
 AAA follows a similar process: an unannounced inspection followed by a service evaluation for the candidates for the four- and five-diamond tiers. Both AAA and Mobil do more rigorous evaluations of properties at the upper end of the spectrum; accommodations at the lower end are rated more on cleanliness and amenities.
 According to Michael Petrone, AAA's director of tourism information development, the company has 65 full-time tourism editors who each evaluate at least 650 hotels a year. "We see more properties than anyone else," Mr. Petrone said. 
 As for the proliferation of other arbiters of hospitality, he did not seem to have a high opinion of the competition.
 "If you're asking, do I think any of the others are reliable, the answer is no," he said. "It goes back to who you trust."
 At least one online travel agency has decided its customers trust outside reviews more than its own: Travelocity began publishing AAA's diamond ratings with its hotel listings last spring (though for hotels AAA hasn't rated, Travelocity uses its own stars, which are clearly distinguished from AAA's diamond ratings).
 "Whether it's a well-founded assumption or not, we definitely found a certain level of skepticism with customers as to where the reviews were coming from," said Josh Feuerstein, vice president of hotels for Travelocity. "We wanted to address that by having an independent source."
 Travelocity also lets customers post their own hotel reviews and ratings, on a scale of 1 to 5 smiley faces. (Tripadvisor.com is another source for customer reviews of hotels.) 

Who Are These People?
 Though often amusing to read, such feedback can leave you wondering if the writers all stayed at the same hotel. For instance, the first customer review I found at Tripadvisor recently for what it describes as "the most popular hotel in New York City" (the Benjamin, according to the site's formula for popularity) was titled, "Disappointing" -- and rated two out of five circles. The second review: "Outstanding!" (five circles). 
 Another problem is that many of the reviews are anonymous, raising questions about the sources. 
 The Zagat Survey company, best known for collecting customer feedback for its popular restaurant guides, uses the same system to publish guidebooks rating American and international hotels. Zagat's system rates each hotel's room quality, service, dining and public facilities with a score of 0 to 30 -- but unlike most customer reviews posted online, the Zagat ratings are based on analysis of all the responses.
 On at least one site, hotels themselves have been involved in determining their own ratings. 
 Until this year, Hotels.com "worked with hotels to determine their rating," said Bob Diener, the company's president. "But we changed to our own independent rating system." 
 Like other online travel agencies, Hotels.com posts descriptions of its rating system on its Web site, mostly describing what types of amenities can be expected in each category.
 In interviews, representatives from Hotels.com, Priceline, Expedia, Orbitz and Travelocity said they not only took into account Mobil and AAA ratings when coming up with their rankings but also did their own inspections (at least in major cities) and considered customer feedback.
 But for the most part, these ratings systems rely on lists of amenities hotels must have to qualify for a certain ranking, a practice some foreign governments, particularly in Europe, use to assign star ratings to hotels. For more subjective ratings of hotels in Europe, the Michelin Guides are the gold standard.
 In fact, for travelers skeptical about ratings given by companies that have a financial relationship with the hotels -- even AAA and Mobil sell properties the right to promote their logos -- guidebooks often offer their own rating systems for hotels.
 "We're not in the business of selling anything," said Michael Spring, publisher of Frommer's travel guides, which rate hotels from one to three stars. Frommer's adopted its rating system about two years ago, Mr. Spring said, mostly to provide readers with a visual shorthand to compare hotels.
 "I think people are desperate for somebody to play favorites -- to weed through all the information and help them make an informed decision," he said. "That's what the star system is all about."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 14, 2003

 CORRECTION:
The Practical Traveler column on Nov. 23, about hotel rating systems, misstated the operation of the Mobil Travel Guide. It does not sell hotels the right to promote its rankings; they may do so at no charge.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Demand Continues to Be Strong for Retail Properties

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
LAST year, as interest rates dropped toward record lows and the office market went limp, New Jersey real estate investors pursued retailing properties with intense interest. Now, with the end of 2003 near, that zeal has shown no sign of abating.
 Jeff Dunne, a vice chairman of CB Richard Ellis, said more than half the total sales volume of retail property his company brokered in the Northeast over the last 16 months involved New Jersey properties. "Retail is the driving force behind the increase in commercial real estate investment," Mr. Dunne said. 
 Jonathan Schultz, president and chief executive of Schultz Organization/TCN Worldwide, called New Jersey's retail property its "fair-haired asset," adding that "an almost astounding amount of investment capital," coming from all sorts of sources, continues to chase it. Mr. Schultz said all types of retail properties are appealing to investors, including shopping malls, strip centers and so-called power centers, which feature several brand-name stores. 
Cushman & Wakefield's Andrew J. Merin, whose 10-member team, the Metropolitan Financial Services Group, brokered $1.2 billion of retail real estate sales last year -- more than twice its usual annual total -- said, "2003 looks like another record year."
By year's end, Mr. Merin said, the group will have closed on the sales of 11 shopping centers -- all but one in New Jersey -- and it is handling three others in the state that will close early next year. Mr. Merin, an executive vice president with Cushman, helped found Metropolitan six years ago to advise owners, developers, corporations, banks and other investors on acquisitions, sales and financing. The team is headquartered in East Rutherford and operates in Fairfield County, Long Island and Westchester County in addition to New Jersey.
Earlier this year, the Cushman team brokered the sale of the Starwood Heller portfolio of six shopping centers in New Jersey for $131.4 million and received more than 30 bids, Mr. Merin said. Within a few weeks, it will close on the sales of the 190,000-square-foot Promenade in Edgewater and the 190,000-square-foot Linden Shopping Center in Linden, he said.
CB Richard Ellis brokered the sale of four shopping centers this year, including Quakerbridge Mall in Lawrenceville, which sold for $100 million, and Monmouth Mall in Eatontown, which went for $164.7 million. It also handled the sale of Riverside Square in Hackensack, at a price of $86.5 million, and Aviation Plaza in Linden, which sold for $54.5 million.
Because New Jersey is so built up, especially in the northern part of the state, and new sites for retail developments are so limited, existing shopping centers are expected to increase in value continually, market specialists say. "Retail is still the darling of buyer interest," Mr. Merin said.
MEANWHILE, property owners are in the mood to sell. "Partly as a reaction to investor appetite, we seem to see more and more retail hitting the market," he said. "We actually have a lot of clients looking at their 'net lease' properties -- those that have terms left on tenants' leases -- to see if it's a good time to sell.
"It's a flight to safety. Because it's possible to take a nice profit now, a lot of people don't want to take the risk of waiting." Mr. Merin said that owners are evaluating even properties that they only recently acquired.
Jeffrey Dash, vice president for leasing and marketing of the Lightstone Group, described the New Jersey market as "running rampant -- far exceeding investors' expectations on return."
Focusing on acquiring retail properties that have long-term leases, Mr. Dash said, Lightstone has been getting "fantastic value, and superb return -- 10 percent plus" and is closing on several properties each week, many of them in New Jersey.
Several months ago, Lightstone acquired the late Saul Cantor's $20 million retail portfolio. including three shopping centers -- all fully leased -- with 84 tenants. The acquired centers were Millburn Mall in Vauxhall, anchored by a Drug Fair; Browntown Shopping Center in Old Bridge, which also has Drug Fair as a lead tenant, along with New York Sports Club; and Newbridge Shopping Plaza in Bergenfield, anchored by a Rite Aid drugstore. 
Lightstone, based in Lakewood, owns and manages an 8.7-million-square-foot portfolio that -- until recently -- mainly comprised nonretail properties. Lightstone owns 15,000 apartments and office and industrial properties in 16 states and Puerto Rico.
The Gale Company of Florham Park recently purchased retail property at Princeton Forrestal Village in Princeton. But Gale will go a bit against the tide, said its president and chief investment officer, Mark Yeager, by converting some store space to offices. 
In a partnership with GE Partners, a unit of General Electric, Gale acquired the 500,000-square-foot mixed-use commercial center last summer. Gale had been involved for more than a decade in managing the property, which is off Route 1, behind a 294-room Westin hotel and conference center.
Now, Gale is "repositioning" 100,000 of the 175,000 existing square feet of retail space and has begun to market it for use as medical, professional, health and fitness, education and personal service businesses -- in general, the type of businesses that might draw repeated visits to the shops that remain. The retail "core identity" of Princeton Forrestal Village will not be abandoned, Mr. Yeager said.
The Village was built in 1987 on land owned by Princeton University, in accordance with the city planners' dictates for bringing life to the area near its boundary with the town of Plainsboro. The Village was designed as a center for high-end specialty boutiques -- featuring its own Main Street with gaslight streetlights and cobblestone walkways, a courtyard, fountain and landscaped grounds. It includes a two-story food court with both indoor and outdoor seating and a child-care center.
"But from the outset," Mr. Yeager said, "the upscale mall was the wrong concept, the wrong design, in the wrong place. Plus, it opened at a bad time -- the beginning of a recession."
Mr. Yeager added, "Princeton Forrestal's site is kind of isolated, back behind the hotel on the infamous Route 1" -- a notoriously congested road. He added that "the project got a bad reputation early on, and the stigma stayed with it for quite some time."
IN 1991, the Bank of New York foreclosed on the project and brought in Gale as the managing and leasing agent. Gale subsequently converted the retail part of the Village to an outlet shopping center, which has been more successful, Mr. Yeager said. In 1997, Gale orchestrated the bank's sale of the property -- subdividing it and selling the hotel to Starwood Heller. Praedium, an investment fund associated with Credit Suisse First Boston, bought the rest of the property and Gale continued to manage it.
Gale decided to begin bolstering the office sector at that point, Mr. Yeager said, and it built a new 75,000-square-foot building, which was quickly leased.
When Praedium moved to sell the property this year, Gale stepped up to buy it, declaring itself ready and willing to work with Princeton city and university officials to maintain retailing at the site, despite its spotty history, Mr. Yeager said. And many retail tenants -- which include Bass Shoe, Famous Footwear, Nine West, Izod, Van Heusen, Dansk, OshKosh B'Gosh, Carter's children's wear, Dress Barn, Casual Corner, Ben & Jerry's and Subway -- said they want to stay, too. "A number of them have requested lease extensions," said the Gale president.
"This is New Jersey," he added. "We have the high population density that makes retail thrive. The challenge with this particular property is to draw people in, and we believe we now have the right plan to do that."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 14, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article in New Jersey copies on Nov. 23 about demand for retail properties referred imprecisely to the relationship between Credit Suisse First Boston and the Praedium investment fund, which recently sold the Princeton Forrestal Village shopping center. While Praedium was associated with Credit Suisse First Boston when Praedium acquired the property in 1997, the investment fund became independent of Credit Suisse in 1999. The article also misidentified the 1997 purchaser of a hotel on the property. It was the Starwood Corporation, not Starwood Heller.

HEADLINE: Business; 
When Nations Need A Little Marketing

BYLINE:  By JIM RENDON

 BODY:
SIMON ANHOLT, a British branding expert, spent a career developing international campaigns for Coca-Cola and Nestle. Now he is trying to put his image-making skills to work for a very different kind of client: countries with struggling economies, like Croatia and Slovenia.
 "I was getting bored with spending my life making already rich companies a little bit richer," said Mr. Anholt, who is 43 and based in London. So, earlier this year, he opened his own agency, Placebrands, with one clear goal: to help countries develop themselves as brands, with a carefully managed international identity, as recognizable as any consumer product. He has worked with Germany, Britain and New Zealand, in addition to Croatia and Slovenia, and is now in negotiations with Mongolia. 
 "When it comes to economic development, everyone talks about transportation, technology and civil service," Mr. Anholt said. "No one talks about marketing, which is bizarre. Marketing is at the heart of what makes rich countries rich." 
Mr. Anholt said he believed that helping countries develop and communicate strong brand identities could help speed up development by attracting foreign investors and tourists. That, in turn, could increase political influence and help a country's corporations grow. 
Mr. Anholt is not alone in seeing the possibilities in nation branding. The idea has been generating more interest in recent years as countries including the United States, Germany, France, Portugal, Estonia and Poland have brought in experts to help them tinker with their identities.
Next year, Finland will start a campaign to enhance its image as a center of high-tech innovation, with the hope of helping its technology companies fare better in the United States. Branding is also seen as crucial to many Central European countries that have realized that their timelines for acceptance into the European Union, and their ability to compete against their neighbors for investment, depend in part on how they are perceived by more developed European countries like France and Germany. 
Changing the image of a country is no easier than changing the image of a company or an individual. While branding may be able to help a country improve its communication with the world, it won't work if the country sends out lies or hype, said Erich Joachimsthaler, chief executive of Vivaldi Partners, a four-year-old agency that specializes in branding. Mr. Joachimsthaler said that when working with Germany, he had run into a perception gap that is common in such work. His German clients wanted to portray themselves as a passionate, emotional, flexible people, an image that he said was "a whole bunch of baloney." 
Charlotte Beers, the former chief executive of the advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather, served for a year and a half as President Bush's under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs -- and part of the job was the task of selling America to the Middle East.
Jennifer L. Aaker, an associate professor of marketing at Stanford's Graduate School of Business, said that task was almost impossible. "One of the reasons that effort failed was because of the underlying product -- our policies were not perceived as pro-Middle East. We failed to understand the media, the culture, even the language in that region. It is difficult to garner favorable perceptions of the American brand in that context." 
While most countries have complicated identities, Croatia, one of Mr. Anholt's clients, is a particularly vexing case. To the extent that people in Western Europe think of the country at all, they associate it with Nazi complicity in World War II, Mr. Anholt said, or with the bloody conflicts in the 1990's between the Serbs and the Croats. Stjepo Martinovic, editor of Croatia's national heritage magazine, Matica, and a former adviser to the Croatian government on European integration, said that because Croatia is scheduled to join the European Union as early as 2007, it was particularly important that the country project a positive image.
"We are trying to present Croatia as a normal country, a market economy, a democratic society, a Mediterranean country," Mr. Martinovic said. He argues that Croatia can be made attractive to the rest of the world by letting people know about its inexpensive work force, its livable cities and its schools that offer classes in English -- as well as its ballet, theater and contemporary artists. 
Mr. Anholt's job is to assess these qualities, understand what outsiders may think about the country and then work to coordinate the messages from various ministries, private industry, cultural institutions and even sports teams. But Croatia cannot focus only on its assets and pretend that there are no negative associations, Mr. Anholt said. He is in the early stages of his work for Croatia but has come up with a one-liner for the country: "We're trying hard and developing quickly." 
Slovenia, another country that Mr. Anholt has advised, presents a different set of problems. The country is small, largely unknown and often confused with Slovakia.
"We're a country that recently got its independence," said Rok Klancnik, the former director of communications for Slovenia's tourism board and now the director of communications at the World Tourism Organization in Madrid. "We're striving to reach higher levels of economic, social and cultural development. Branding is not only useful, it's necessary." 
For Slovenia, sending musicians and artists abroad is one way to communicate. If someone enjoys a performance of the Ljubljana Symphony Orchestra in, say, Chicago, that will reflect well on Slovenia, Mr. Anholt said, and may encourage people to visit it or buy its products.
Because he regards branding as something that can take 10 or 20 years to achieve, Mr. Anholt does not recommend advertising as a solution. In the case of Slovenia, he argues that schools there should teach English, Italian and German. In 15 years, when some of those students are working in hotels and can greet visitors in their native languages, those visitors will be more likely to leave with a positive impression of the country. 
Wally Olins, a visiting fellow at the Said Business School at Oxford University and a founder of the branding firm Wolff-Olins, said a country's brand involved messages from dozens of agencies and private companies. Everything from its Web site design and trade show materials to its stance on complex issues like international trade agreements can give clues about a country's identity.
For example, Mexico's decision to sign the North American Free Trade Agreement did more to signal its readiness for foreign investment than any other single event could have, according to Robert Z. Lawrence, a professor of international trade and investment at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. Similarly, Mr. Anholt said, Slovenia's generosity in foreign aid -- it is a donor to countries in its region -- sends the message that the country is both stable and economically prosperous.
WORKING with countries can be exasperating. Corporations have top-down structures that require employees to get behind new projects and often have chief executives with long tenures. Nations have political factions, sudden leadership changes and vast bureaucracies. Branding programs may be seen as superfluous. Advertising firms and corporations may have different goals than government agencies. 
Mr. Anholt said he had started and stopped work with Slovenia many times. "Every time I get involved, I make friends, create a good impression, some of my advice is taken, some is not, and then I have to start all over again," he said. 
Whether branding is as useful as Mr. Anholt believes, however, is the subject of some debate, at least if the goal is to help a country's corporations expand internationally.
Many branding experts point to the success of Japan and Japanese corporations as an example of how national and corporate identities can benefit each other. After World War II, Japan became associated with poor-quality products, but in the 1980's, with the emergence of successful Japanese corporations like Toyota and Sony and Honda, the name Japan became synonymous with quality and technology. 
But to think that Mr. Anholt's branding efforts can do the same for Slovenia's companies may be wishful thinking, said Desmond Lachman, an economist and resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization. Japan had high regulatory standards and a relatively large domestic market that helped its corporations develop, Mr. Lachman said. Slovenia, on the other hand, has a tiny domestic market. It will not become another Japan no matter how it is branded, he said. 
The most efficient way for Eastern European countries with emerging economies to promote growth is to pursue policies that encourage investment from companies in France, Germany and other European Union countries to help develop a manufacturing base, Mr. Lachman said. 
Although Mr. Anholt says a better international image can have long-term international benefits, he does not argue that it's the right thing for every country. "Money should not be taken away from essential nation-building activity to do branding," he said. "If the roads need fixing, they are probably better off using their money to fix the roads."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Simon Anholt of Placebrands, with representatives of Mongolia at a dinner in London this month. Placebrands helps countries manage their images. (Photo by Nicole Nodland)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
How to Make The Deficit Look Smaller Than It Is

BYLINE:  By DANIEL GROSS; Daniel Gross writes the Moneybox column for Slate.com.

 BODY:
THE news on the federal budget deficit for fiscal 2003 was encouraging, wasn't it? In July 2003, the Office of Management and Budget projected a record deficit of $455 billion. But when the fiscal year ended in October, the shortfall was only $374 billion, equivalent to 3.5 percent of gross domestic product.
 "As a percentage of gross domestic product, the deficits are below the historical peaks that we've seen in the past," says J.T. Young, a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget. In 1983, for example, the deficit was 6 percent of gross domestic product; in 1992, it was 4.7 percent. 
 Congratulating the administration for such an achievement, however, would be like raising the allowance of a high school student who brought home a D-minus in math instead of an F. 
If we factor out the so-called Social Security surplus -- payroll taxes collected by the government but not paid out in benefits -- the deficit in fiscal 2003 was actually far larger: $531 billion, or 4.9 percent of gross domestic product. For the current fiscal year, the administration expects that this figure, also called the on-budget deficit, will be even higher: $639 billion, or a whopping 5.4 percent of gross domestic product.
Every year since 1983, workers have paid more in Social Security payroll taxes than Social Security has paid out to beneficiaries. The surplus was supposed to be used to pay down the national debt. "That way, when the baby boomers are retired, our other debt will be lower and we'll be in a better position to borrow funds to pay for benefits," said Richard Kogan, senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning group in Washington.
To ensure the proper use of the Social Security surplus, Vice President Al Gore in 2000 proposed segregating the funds into a sort of lockbox. George W. Bush, then the Texas governor, also supported this concept, although his understanding of Social Security was revealed to be something less than complete. (In November 2000, during a campaign speech, he famously accused opponents of wanting "the federal government controlling the Social Security like it's some kind of federal program.") 
In the last three years, President Bush and Congress have viewed the Social Security surplus more as a cookie jar than a lockbox. The three budgets that Congress proposed, and Mr. Bush signed -- for the fiscal years 2002, 2003 and 2004 -- used $480 billion in excess Social Security payroll taxes to pay for government programs. According to the budget office, administration policies call for an additional $849 billion of excess Social Security funds to support government operations over the next four years.
Using excess payroll taxes for unintended purposes masks the true size of the operating deficit. The budget office predicts that the net deficit will shrink from $475 billion in fiscal 2004 to $226 billion, or 1.7 percent of gross domestic product, in 2008. Take away the ever-larger Social Security surpluses used in each of those years, however, and the on-budget deficit will stand at $464 billion in 2008.
The reality will likely be far worse, especially if you factor in costs that the White House doesn't include in its projections -- like the $87 billion recently appropriated for the war, or the extension of recently enacted tax cuts. In doing so, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, the business-oriented Committee for Economic Development and the anti-deficit Concord Coalition have concluded that next year's on-budget deficit will be $687 billion -- not $639 billion, as the administration suggests. In 2008, the groups say, the on-budget deficit will be $692 billion and the net deficit will be $457 billion, or twice the Bush administration's projection. 
THE figures show that the personal and corporate income taxes that are supposed to fund government operations no longer come within shouting distance of doing so. And the refusal of the administration or its Congressional allies to acknowledge this reality has left normally mild-mannered deficit hawks on the verge of apoplexy. 
"The last time the situation reached this point, in the early 1990's, we had bipartisan agreement that we were reaching a fiscal crisis," said Maya MacGuineas, executive director of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget in Washington.
The response then was an unpalatable, but ultimately successful, mix of spending restraints and tax increases. But in the last few years -- with the sums involved far greater than they were in the early 1990's, and with the baby boomers nearing retirement -- Washington has raised spending sharply and cut taxes even more sharply. 
It's a fiscal Bizarro world.
