HEADLINE: A Struggle to Keep the Recycling Bin Full 

BYLINE:  By DAVID WINZELBERG

 BODY:
THOSE colorful plastic bins on neighborhood curbs have become part of the local landscape and filling them part of the weekly routine. Long Islanders don't usually give much thought to recycling. And in the last few years, statistics show that many may be giving it even less thought, throwing out more trash while recycling less.
 Overall, Long Island towns report recycling rates much lower than the goal set by the state Department of Environmental Conservation, which is to recycle at least 42 percent of all solid waste. Many towns also report recycling less than the 29.7 percent of solid waste the federal Environmental Protection Agency said was recovered nationally in 2001. The Town of North Hempstead's recycling rate has dropped sharply in recent years, and rates in Oyster Bay, Huntington and Islip have also decreased. 
 The North Hempstead supervisor, May Newburger, was at a loss to explain the dropoff in her town's recycling rate, which plunged from 37 percent in 1999 to 20 percent in 2002. "I really don't know why that is," she said. "We regularly send out reminders and advertise recycling. I think we're doing everything we can." 
But in Hempstead, where the recycling rate rose from 25 percent in 2000 to 30 percent last year, officials credited education efforts. Richard Ronan, the sanitation commissioner, said the town had been conducting surveys of town garbage routes to see which homes are not putting out the green plastic buckets at least once a month. Those who don't will receive new buckets, to remind them to participate in the town's recycling program. The town also runs television commercials to promote its hazardous waste disposal initiative.
Maureen Wren, a D.E.C. spokeswoman, discounted the declining recycling rates reported by the Long Island towns and said that "according to the information reported by municipalities and private firms to D.E.C., the amount of materials recycled statewide continues to be stable."
Lawrence Swanson, director of the Waste Reduction and Management Institute at Stony Brook University, said images of the infamous garbage barge and the unwanted New York City trash that floated on it have long faded from people's minds, making recycling seem less urgent. "People are tired of it," he said. "You need a crisis to keep people inspired." 
Although there is no state mandate for towns to recycle at a certain rate, in the 1988 Solid Waste Management Act, the D.E.C. outlined goals for municipalities to recycle between 42 and 50 percent of their garbage by the year 2000. Some Long Island town officials think that was a stretch and complain that the state and federal governments are not doing enough to create markets for recycled materials. But Dr. Swanson put the onus on local government. "The towns would like to see a continuing source for their recyclables, but sometimes they have to eat a little bit of the cost," he said.
Residents who try to sneak tuna cans into their regular trash could be fined, but almost none are. And going after individuals who fail to recycle is not the answer anyway, according to Gordon Gibson of Huntington, executive director of Citizens for a Livable Environment and Recycling.
"We are not what counts," he said. "It is the organizations in the community that counts. Every government office should recycle every scrap of office paper, because once they get their house in order, the whole thing follows. They should account for trash the same way they account for money."
There are other reasons why recycling has slowed here. Markets for recycled products like paper and scrap metal have become saturated by the increase in supply from municipalities who have jumped on the recycling bandwagon in recent years. With the smaller demand for some recyclables, it costs towns more for disposal. This was the reason New York City suspended its plastic and glass recycling program last year. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said ending this type of recycling would save the city about $40 million.
Of course, not recycling puts that much more trash into the waste stream. With most incinerators already burning as much as they can and local landfills closed, the garbage has to go somewhere. Much of New York City's trash goes to landfills in Virginia. Over a million tons of Long Island's trash is burned at the four waste-to-energy incinerators located in Babylon, East Garden City, Huntington and Islip.
Officials of American Ref-Fuel, which operates the incinerator in East Garden City, have proposed a a similar incinerator on the site of the former Shoreham nuclear plant. But the Brookhaven supervisor, John Jay LaValle, has said he opposes the plan. Currently, Brookhaven trucks its garbage to the Nassau incinerator.
Some recycling advocates contend that too much waste that could be used again is going up in smoke, posing a health risk.
"Mass incinerators generate extensive pollution, and it's usually very dangerous pollution, fine particulates like zinc, arsenic cadmium and lead," Mr. Gibson said. "Virtually everything put in a mass incinerator can be recycled." 
Kent Burton, a senior vice president with Covanta Energy, a company that operates two incinerators on Long Island, dismissed the accusation that incinerators are big polluters. "As the E.P.A. recently expressed, waste-to-energy plants throughout the country 'produce 2,800 megawatts of electricity with less environmental impact than almost any other sources of electricity,"' he said. He added that incinerators "save land otherwise used for disposal, destroy dangerous pathogens that threaten public health, decrease groundwater degradation, reduce greenhouse gases, significantly reduce the release of hazardous air pollutants, eliminate the release of methane from trash and control litter, noise and odor associated with burying trash in the ground." 
Mr. Gibson complained that his town's recycling rate has fallen over the last few years, from 37.6 percent in 1999 to 33.8 percent in 2002. Still, among the seven largest towns on the Island, also including Hempstead, North Hempstead, Oyster Bay, Babylon, Islip and Brookhaven, Huntington had the highest rate of solid waste recovery. 
Howard Zeis, a Huntington town employee, has been working in garbage for the last 19 years, most recently at the town's walk-in recycling center on New York Avenue, where residents can dispose of things like car batteries and motor oil. "People think it's easier to toss it out than to do anything with it," Mr. Zeis said. "We need to make people more aware and make it as easy as possible for people to do the right thing."
In the towns of Southampton, Southold and Shelter Island, residents are given a choice about what to do with their garbage; hire a private carter or dispose of it themselves at pay-as-you-throw waste and recycling centers. In Southampton, about half the residents use carters and half bring their trash and recyclables to the town's four centers, according to Judith McCleery, Southampton's recycling coordinator. 
"It's a free market system," Ms. McCleery said. "They can get the best price from the carters. If they don't like those prices, they can do it themselves."
After a 25 percent bump in recyclables collected in 1995, the first year of the program, the town's recycling rate has remained about the same, Ms. McCleery said.
Southampton also offers its residents a do-it-yourself composting device for about $40, to reduce yard waste, the single largest component in Long Island's recycled garbage. The Town of North Hempstead recovered nearly 24,000 tons of yard waste last year, more than double the amount of newspaper, bottles and cans combined. In 1994, the Town of East Hampton built an indoor composting plant to process its yard waste. 
"It doesn't make any sense to landfill yard waste when you've got thousands of gardeners who can never get enough compost," said Peter Garnham, a former recycling information officer for the Town of East Hampton.
But who needs old tires, leaky batteries or oil-soaked rags? These items are not as easily recycled as yard waste, and it costs money to collect, sort and transport them as well. "We spend millions of dollars a year on solid waste management," said Phil Nolan, director of environmental waste for the Town of Huntington. "We get about $370 per year from each property to pay for all this."
Dr. Swanson said that over the long term, recycling will have a positive effect by not depleting natural resources. But he said the idea that recycling can turn garbage into gold is unrealistic, given the costs of collection and the volatility of markets.
"The economic argument for recycling has been very detrimental to the cause," Dr. Swanson said. "I don't think it will ever be a money maker, but it might offset the cost of disposal."
Ms. McCleery agreed. "Recycling is still a cost avoidance for us," she said. "Even when the markets are down, we think it pays."

HEADLINE: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS 

BYLINE:  By Michelle Falkenstein

 BODY:
'A Feeling About People'
 Donald Williams was 12 when he attended a lecture and demonstration by the Dance Theater of Harlem in his hometown of Chicago. Afterward, he went backstage and met Arthur Mitchell, the company's founder and director. 
 "He asked me if I had been studying dance," recalled Mr. Williams, who had been studying ballet for a year and a half on a scholarship. "Then he asked me to take my shoe off because he wanted to see my foot." 
 Mr. Williams removed his shoe and was promptly offered a scholarship in New York for the summer. This was a tryout? "He had a feeling about people," Mr. Williams said.
 But Mr. Williams's mother was not so sure he should leave home. Finally, he got her permission. He ended up staying in New York for three years. 
 After high school, he considered becoming a civil engineer, but the pull of dance was too great. He joined the Harlem company as an apprentice in 1977, and has been a principal dancer since 1983.
 "I think this is what I was destined to do," said Mr. Williams, 44, who has lived in Hackensack for seven years.
 Mr. Williams will dance in "St. Louis Woman: A Blues Ballet," with music by Harold Arlen and Johnny Mercer, when his company visits the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark on Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 3 p.m. Also on the program is George Balanchine's "Serenade." Information: (888) 466-5722.

Two Commissions
 The sculptors Nikolai Melnikov and Robert Pfitzenmeier have been commissioned to create outdoor artworks for Newport, an office and residential development in Jersey City. The sculptures should be completed next spring.
 Both artists work in Jersey City. Mr. Melnikov, originally from Chisinau, Moldova, has created sculptural portraits of celebrities and business leaders, and earlier this year a show of his work toured Russia. Mr. Pfitzenmeier has produced many large public sculptures, including one for the Anchorage Museum in Alaska and another for the General Aviation Terminal at John F. Kennedy International Airport. The model for his Newport sculpture, above, incorporates sail-like parts that will move in the wind.

Making Money Your Friend
 New Jersey's youth can raise its economic awareness by visiting "Once Upon a Dime: The World of Money," at the Newark Museum at 49 Washington Street. The show runs through June 19, and features an interactive exhibition, as well as programs for families and school groups. The goal is to teach children the history of money, how to manage it and the forces that affect it. Information: (973)596-6550.

Money for Morris County
 For the third consecutive year, the Arts Council of the Morris Area has made 14 grants through a partnership with the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation. The grants are worth between $3,000 and $5,000, and support theater, music, visual arts and other art-related organizations in Morris County.
 Among the recipients are the Chatham Community Players, for their theater program for the disabled and disadvantaged.
 Mrs. Dodge lived in Morris County, in Madison, from 1916 until she died in 1973, and made supporting the county one of her foundation's missions.

New Jersey Opera in New York
 On Tuesday, Alfredo Silipigni, artistic director of the New Jersey State Opera, is to conduct the New York-based opera company Teatro Grattacielo in the North American premiere of Pietro Mascagni's "Guglielmo Ratcliff." The performance is at 8 p.m. at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall.
 Mascagni, best known for his opera "Cavalleria Rusticana," wrote "Guglielmo Ratcliff" in 1890, when he was nearly destitute, Mr. Silipigni said, and on the advice of his friend, Puccini, decided to write something that would be popular. Since Scottish ghost stories were then in fashion, Mascagni based his opera on such a Scottish tale.
 When he conducts the piece, Mr. Silipigni will use an original, handwritten score from 1895. "There are lots of scratches, but it's the real thing," Mr. Silipigni said. 
 Information: (212)875-5050. Michelle Falkenstein

HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION; 
Sprawl and Aviation

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
WHERE planes once took off from an airport in Manahawkin, people now push shopping carts down the aisles of a giant Wal-Mart. Over in Marlboro, the airport closed last year and developers are seeking to build a housing complex there for the elderly.
 The number of airports like these has declined almost 50 percent in New Jersey since World War II and the onset of suburban sprawl. They are known as general aviation, or public-use, airports. Oddly, their demise comes as the demand for plane use by individuals and corporations has grown, especially since regular airline service was reduced at the state's large commercial airports in Newark, Trenton and Atlantic City and stricter security screening was added after the terrorist attacks of 2001. 
The newest public-use airport in the state, the Spitfire Aerodrome, in Salem County, was built two decades ago, in 1983. Since then, 13 have closed. Since 1950, 37 have closed, dropping the total to 45, according to the State Department of Transportation. The reasons include high operating costs, community hostility and soaring land values as developers scramble for sizable tracts of land on which to build housing, shopping malls and office buildings. 
 "The highest bidders for the properties are developers because this is prime real estate for construction of housing or commercial use or big-box type stores," said the state transportation commissioner, Jack Lettiere. "The prices they pay are extraordinary, and there's tremendous economic pressure on the owner to go that way." 
 Nationally, the number has declined over the last decade by only about 10 percent, to 5,148, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. But, as in New Jersey, most of the public-use airports that closed were owned privately rather than by government entities like counties and municipalities. And Warren Morningstar, vice president for communications at the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, a trade group in Frederick, Md., said that in 1994 public-use airports were closing at the rate of one a week.
 "Fortunately, that trend has slowed down," Mr. Morningstar said. "We now lose about 15 a year nationwide."
 To stop the decline, many states have begun trying to save the airports by buying them or their development rights. 
 "The solution is to acquire the airports; that's fairly common," said Philip Brito, manager of the New York district office of the F.A.A. "One of our highest priorities is to fund the purchase of an airport by a local community or by the state."
 New Jersey is no exception, but Mr. Lettiere says that here the idea is also to prevent sprawl. In recent years the state has acquired, or helped municipalities and counties to acquire, five airports, and it is acquiring eight more, in part with federal funds. 
 "I think there is a core number of airports -- 17 general aviation airports -- that we believe are a must to preserve and that we have to have in our system, no matter how we do it," Mr. Lettiere said.
 As the state's public-use airports have declined, the number of airstrips and helipads for private use has increased. The F.A.A. lists more than 300. They can be found at corporate office complexes, industrial sites, banks, pharmaceutical companies, nuclear generating stations, hospitals, universities, military installations, farms, golf courses and parks. Even the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has one. 
 But it is the fate of the public-use airports that so concerns the aviation industry and state officials, especially since 30 of the 45 airports of this type are privately owned -- so-called mom-and-pop operations that the state sees as especially vulnerable to sale and non-aviation development because they operate on small profit margins. 
 "New Jersey is a special case," said Mr. Morningstar of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association. "Unlike other states, the majority are privately owned. No other state has such a high percentage of privately owned public-use airports." 
 The loss of more airports could seriously hinder the state's economy and the national transportation network, experts say. State officials say that 70,000 jobs in the state are linked to civil aviation and that these airports generate more than $4.6 billion a year, according to a 1996 study by the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission. Most licensed pilots -- New Jersey has some 15,000 -- learn to fly at schools based at the public-use airports.
 "It's going to be difficult for general aviation to operate and develop the pilots in the future," Mr. Brito of the F.A.A. said. "And as airports close, there will be pressure on other airports to handle their activities." 
 In addition, 13 of the state's general aviation airports, including the biggest one, Teterboro, are considered "reliever" airports, which serve smaller craft that otherwise might tie up the larger commercial airports, said Jim Peters, a spokesman for the F.A.A. 
 In one case, the state bought the development rights of the 125-acre Central Jersey Regional Airport in Somerset County last March for $4.2 million after residents opposed a plan to update it. The previous owners continue to operate it, but the state hopes to ease the community opposition by keeping the airport going without enlarging it.
 Similarly, in Sussex County, the fear of a plan by Trinca Airport to expand prompted Green Township to buy it and keep it operating. 
 "Generally speaking," Mr. Lettiere said, "I don't think anyone wants to see airports expand around their communities; it's not our intent to expand them." The intent, he said, is "to preserve the existing footprint at each airport."
 New Jersey also bought development rights at Lincoln Park Airport in Morris County for $4.3 million in 2002. The first acquisition after the state began its airport preservation program was Greenwood Lake Airport in Passaic County, for $1.8 million, in 2000. Other airports that have been saved in the program are South Jersey Regional Airport in Burlington County and the Princeton Airport, said a spokeswoman for the Transportation Department. 
 The state is currently trying to help Monmouth County acquire Allaire Airport, and it is looking to acquire Solberg Airport in Hunterdon County, which Readington Township tried to condemn to stop an expansion plan. The state is also working to acquire Alexandria Airport and Sky Manor Airport, also in Hunterdon County; Blairstown Airport in Warren County; Camden County Airport; Spitfire Aerodrome; and Sussex Airport in Sussex County. 
 Manahawkin Airport closed in 1992, long before the state started its preservation program.
 Marlboro Airport had financial difficulties for years and was closed by new owners in November 2002. But state officials said they did not try to save it because the airport was close to a school and transmission lines and thus was not considered a core operation. Now, the proposal for building housing on the site is at a standstill as debate continues over zoning amendments.
 Hugh McElroy, chairman of the New Jersey Aviation Association, a trade group of aviation professionals, said the state's program to save airports was "a step in the right direction."
 "But it's far from a panacea," he added. "From an economic standpoint, it would be prohibitive. There need to be other activities to augment the state's effort and it needs to be done on a case-by-case basis." 
 Governor McGreevey had such issues in mind last month when he established a commission to study the state's general aviation airport system and report back in a year. 
 The commission is to take an inventory of all airports, review their finances and identify their role based on location and user demand. It is also to consider preservation efforts beyond public acquisition of privately owned airports and recommend ways to rehabilitate and preserve the airports.
 Mr. Lettiere said the commission would try to ensure that whatever development occurs in and around airports does not create more sprawl. "We can't separate transportation, even aviation, from smart growth," he said.

HEADLINE: Wanted: More Campus Housing 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM

 BODY:
LAST April, Montclair State University held a lottery for students interested in the Village at Little Falls -- a new 850-bed dormitory complex -- with four students to a unit sharing a living room, a kitchen, two bathrooms and three or four bedrooms. In a matter of hours, the complex was filled and a waiting list was started.
 The phenomenon was hardly surprising. At colleges around New Jersey, campus housing fills up as quickly as it can be built -- all in the hopes of keeping the best and the brightest in the state from attending colleges and universities in Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware. 
 Not only are more high school graduates in New Jersey going to college these days, but while students were once content to head home after class each afternoon, today they are looking for college life. "Students want a campus experience," said Dr. Susan A. Cole, president of Montclair State University. "They want to go away to college, to have the experience of living on a campus." 
 Yet as the number of college-age students continues to rise, campus housing remains in short supply -- even though there has been a building frenzy at Rowan University and Ramapo College as well as Montclair State.
 Dr. Cole noted that in terms of percentages, New Jersey ranked 45th of the 50 states as far as the number of undergraduate and graduate students it can educate at its public colleges and universities -- about 140,000 places in a state of more than 8.5 million people. 
 One solution, she said, was a change in policy at the state level that would make it easier for private developers to build housing on college campuses. "We are trying to develop more creative mechanisms," Dr. Cole said. "Then we don't have to be in the housing construction business. We're not developers; we're educational institutions."
 The fact is, New Jersey loses about 20,000 college students a year to other states, exporting about 55 percent of the students who want to earn an undergraduate degree, Dr. Cole said. "One of the things New Jersey has not done over the last few decades," she said, "is build the type of campuses other schools have built."
 Over the past several years, many of New Jersey's colleges and universities have evolved from commuter schools to suitcase colleges -- where students flee on Friday and return on Monday -- to campuses in which students live and stick around on the weekends. But New Jersey's schools are struggling to build fast enough for the new live-in student. 
 In addition, the lagging economy combined with the allure of smaller tuition payments has led to higher enrollments in the state's public colleges and universities. "In-state tuition definitely keeps a lot of people here," said Bob Quarteroni, a spokesman at Montclair State, "especially with everybody losing jobs these days."
 In 1998, there were 42,637 undergraduates at the state's public universities and 66,707 students at the colleges. By 2002, those numbers had grown to 45,094 at the universities and 71,001 at the colleges. At the same time, the number of full-time students jumped from 34,578 at the universities to 38,147 and from 42,848 in 1998 at the colleges to 48,085, according to the state's Commission on Higher Education. 
 "We have heard that more students want the residential opportunity," said Jeanne Oswald, deputy executive director of the commission, which does not involve itself in housing issues. "But it is left up to the individual campuses to decide how much housing they want to provide for students."
 Colleges, well aware of the demand for more housing, have been chipping away at the shortage, but there is a long way to go. 
 For instance, at Rutgers-Camden, where enrollment has increased to 5,800 students today from 4,750 in 1996, there are only 500 beds on campus. Mark Rozewski, associate provost for administration and finance, said the university was planning to build housing for about 500 more students over the next two years. "We're in the same boat as almost every other school in New Jersey," Mr. Rozewski said. "We are actively putting together a public and private partnership to build 500 more beds and another 500 after that."
 Part of the problem is the changing nature of the student population. At Rowan in nearby Glassboro, one in three students was part time only 10 years ago, as against one in six today. Dr. Donald Farish, who has been president of the university since 1998, said that when he arrived at Rowan, two-thirds of the students were from South Jersey. Now, Dr. Farish said, about half of the school's 9,600 undergraduate and graduate students are from other parts of the state, and 5 percent are from outside New Jersey.
 "There was a time you could set off a cannon on a weekend and not hit anybody," he said. "But that has changed. At any given moment, there is vibrant activity going on here."
 Dr. Farish explained that in 2001, 900 of the 1,200 freshmen asked to live in dormitories on campus and that the following year more than than 1,100 of the 1,250 freshmen wanted dorm rooms.
 "They think living on campus is part of the educational process, and I tend to agree," he said. "We have seen this gradual growth, and suddenly it was a crisis."
 For now, Rowan, which has about 5,600 full-time undergraduates, is short about 450 beds, said Joe Cardona, director of university relations. About 350 students are the third person in what were intended to be double rooms. In an effort to keep up with demand, Mr. Cardona said, the university plans to break ground on a 450-student townhouse complex before the end of the year. 
 "We've been tripling students who want to live on campus for the past four years," he said. "We are transforming ourselves to meet the needs of the students. There's been a shift in the type of students."
 At Ramapo College in Mahwah, where more than 5,600 undergraduate and graduate students are enrolled, new housing was built in 1999, 2000 and 2002, said Bonnie Franklin, a spokeswoman for the college, who added that students were "clamoring to stay on campus." 
 "We do have a housing crunch," Ms. Franklin said. "We've had a housing crunch for several years now. We are growing because of demographics and demand."
 Eight years ago, enrollment at Ramapo was about 4,800 students, with about 1,100 of them living on campus. Three years ago, she said, the college was leasing rooms at a Holiday Inn in nearby Suffern, N.Y., to house some of the overflow. Today, 2,400 students live in campus housing.
 One reason for the housing crunch, Ms. Franklin explained, is that students are staying for all four years rather than transferring after a year or two. For instance, in 2002, 87.1 percent of the freshman class stayed for sophomore year, while in 1994 that number was only 72.9 percent.
 "Students want the whole college experience," she said. "They want to participate in the extracurricular activities. That's what happens when you have a critical mass on campus. It means you have to provide facilities to develop the whole student."
 In addition to adding dormitory space, Ms. Franklin said, in the spring Ramapo plans to open a sports and recreation center with workout rooms, a climbing wall, juice bars and places to eat.
 Ramapo was not the only school to recognize the need for student facilities in addition to more living space. Dr. Karen Pennington, vice president for student development and campus life at Montclair State, said she and her staff tried to challenge the notion that students would go home on weekends because there was not enough to do on campus. Two years ago, the university opened a 24-hour diner on campus with activities like karaoke nights. 
 "Students seek a place where they can belong," Dr. Pennington said.
 While the College of New Jersey in Ewing, with a student enrollment of 5,400, is not facing as much of a shortage as other campuses, said Patrice Coleman-Boatwright, director of college and community relations, housing is filled to capacity and it is often difficult for transfer students to find on-campus housing. Currently, Ms. Coleman-Boatwright said, there are 3,500 beds on campus, about 95 percent of which are filled by freshmen and sophomores. "Our niche is that this is a residential experience," she said.
 As Ms. Coleman-Boatwright explained, the school began changing from a commuter college to a residential campus in the late 1980's. "We realized we could really strengthen our educational experience that way," she said. "Our students are telling us that they want to live on campus."
 Indeed, she said the school's is able to retain 95 percent of its freshmen partly because of its ability to provide a life on the campus.
 Then there is the main campus of Rutgers in New Brunswick, the state's largest university campus with about 35,000 students -- 13,800 of whom live in campus housing.
 Kyu-Jung Whang, the university's vice present for facilities and capital planning, said that with the exception of this school year, there has in recent times been a waiting list for campus housing. 
 While Rutgers may not need additional units at the moment, Mr. Whang said, "we do need to upgrade the quality of our dorms." In addition, he said, the university is working with a development agency in New Brunswick on plans for two more dormitories -- one on the main campus and another at Douglass, the women's college of Rutgers.
 Yet with cutbacks in state financing and the number of students increasing on most state campuses, universities and colleges must also wrestle with some hard choices like whether to spend limited funds on housing or on academic buildings.
 "We cannot increase our capacity without extra support from Trenton," said Mr. Cardona of Rowan.
 At Montclair State, where the student population is now at 11,375 undergraduates and 3,829 graduate students -- up 3,000 students in the past five years -- Dr. Cole has become a leading spokeswoman on the issue of under-building at the state's colleges and universities.
 "The challenge facing New Jersey is whether or not the political will can be created to address the state's benign neglect of its public colleges and universities and whether or not a truly comprehensive and far-sighted plan for meeting the state'sbroad higher education needs can emerge from the current deliberations," she wrote last April in New Jersey Reporter, a magazine that focuses on public issues. "It would be an error to think that New Jersey does not have to educate its own workforce. It would be an error to think that New Jersey can continue to off-load the costs of higher education onto individual families. It would be an error to think that New Jerseyans will accept a situation in which an increasing number of young people will be turned away from state colleges and universities because there simply is no room for them."
 In the meantime, students at schools like Rowan and Montclair will bunk up with three in a room.
 Jennifer Savitsky of Oradell rooms with two other freshmen at Rowan. Ms. Savitsky knew all summer that she would be living with Natalie Gericke of Deptford, but she did not know until a week before classes started that Meggan Haig of Ocean View would also be moving in. "Everybody made it work," she said. "When we first got here, things were a little tense between us, but after the first week it all melted away. Everyone is on different schedules."
 The three freshmen have managed to get beds and desks for everyone along with a microwave, a television and two computers in their room in Evergreen Hall. In addition, they will each be getting at least a $300 refund because they are living three in a room.
 For Ms. Haig, one of 11 children at home in Cape May County, living with two other women is not a challenge. She does much of her studying in the library and goes home most weekends to work as a waitress.
 "It's actually fairly easy for me," she said. "At home, I share a room with three of my sisters. I actually have more room here."

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT; 
Spano Budget Bears Few Good Tidings

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS

 BODY:
WHEN the Westchester County budget proposal for 2004 was made public not long ago, it bore few glad tidings. And one of the worst pieces of news for many people was that the budget plan relies on an increase in the sales tax in the county, where residents may already feel that they are being taxed within an inch of their lives.
 The prospects for the sales tax increase are not clear. The $1.4 billion budget proposal by County Executive Andrew J. Spano relies on a nearly $100 million revenue stream from a sales tax increase. But sales tax increases can be passed only in a cumbersome process that requires both local and state approval. And though some Democrats and Republicans in both Albany and Westchester are voicing a small degree of encouragement to the sales tax increase, the outlook is still murky. 
 The same tax was rejected by the State Legislature earlier this year, when Mr. Spano tried to get it for his 2003 budget. Mr. Spano says this year things will be different.
 Mr. Spano is contrite about his previous loss, saying that he failed in his quest because he criticized the state too strongly. 
 "We've built up relationships with State Legislatures during the year," he said. "We didn't have that last time." Mr. Spano, a Democrat in his second term as county executive, put the odds of the sales tax passage this go round at 60/40 in his favor.
 Nicholas Spano, a Republican state senator from Yonkers and no relation to the county executive, said it was too early to gauge the prospects. He added: "The county executive has started the debate on a constructive and positive note. We want to help." 
 Any sales tax increase would not apply to the county's four largest cities, Yonkers, White Plains, Mount Vernon and New Rochelle, where the sales tax is already at the legal limit. Elsewhere in the county, the proposed sales tax increase will amount to 1 cent on every taxable dollar spent, bringing the total percentage people will pay at the check-out counter (which includes others taxes like state sales tax) to eight percent, from the current seven percent. 
 If the sales tax increase does not pass, Mr. Spano will have to seek either corresponding services cuts or an increase in Westchester's already high property tax burden. 
 As the current budget proposal stands, factoring in the sales tax revenue, roughly 250 jobs would be cut from the county' s Department of Social Services and Health Department. Additional jobs that aren't currently filled will be eliminated. There will also be a two percent increase in county property taxes. Despite these trims, spending in 2004 will still be up about five percent. Mr. Spano, the county executive, said the discretionary portion of the budget has been "cut to the bone." He attributes the increase to state mandates for items like Medicaid. 
 Others, like George Oros, a Republican and the minority whip in the County Legislature, also blame the still-growing budget on profligate spending locally on items like golf courses. 
 Westchester still receives an Aaa bond rating from Moody's, the rating agency, which is an indicator of Moody's faith in the county's fiscal health. With or without a sales tax increase, the county has received a warning from Moody's that the rating may change. 
 Westchester is not alone in its financial woe. The effects of extravagant spending back when times were flush, state mandates and a national economy that has, until recently, been weak have conspired toput many counties in a difficult financial position. 
 In the usual process, to provide political cover for the state, the county board of legislators will usually call for introduction of a state bill allowing for a local sales tax increase. This step was skipped last year. If the State Assembly introduces the bill, it then is endorsed by the County Legislature. The state then votes, and only after it passes that stage can the county can enact it on a majority vote. Mr. Spano said he is certain he has the nine votes needed for final passage from the County Legislature. 
 Whatever ultimately happens in Albany, the County Legislature must pass a budget by the end of the year. The sales tax approval process, however, will most probably stretch into 2004, with the State Assembly currently in recess until January. As a result, said County Executive Spano, the county will probably have to pass two budgets--one with the sales tax and another contingency budget. This will help maintain the bond rating, he said. 
 Some tax experts criticize sales taxes, saying they punish the poor, but the county executive disagrees. He points to the fact that sales tax in the four cities, where many of the county's poor live, are already higher.

HEADLINE: Tech Workers Struggle To Answer Overseas Threat 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL

 BODY:
STOCKING shelves and hauling boxes on the graveyard shift at Target was something Ed Marx never imagined he would be doing. After 27 years as a computer programmer, Mr. Marx said, he thought his technology skills ensured he would be employed in that field for many years. 
 It has not turned out that way. In August 2002, Mr. Marx, 49, lost his job at the Computer Sciences Corporation, a technology contractor and services company in Moorestown, N.J. Mr. Marx and his company say he was a victim of offshore outsourcing, known as offshoring. Unable, so far, to find a full-time job in his field, he has been working at Target since September. 
 Seeing examples like Mr. Marx, many technology workers have become increasingly concerned and angry about offshore contracts, which can cause certain jobs or whole departments to be moved to countries like India and China, where technology workers are paid lower wages. 
Information technology industries have "led the initial overseas exodus," according to a study by Forrester Research, published in November 2002. In a survey of 400 hiring managers in May, the Information Technology Association found that 12 percent of the information technology companies in the survey had moved jobs offshore, compared with 6 percent of the nontechnology companies. 
"I feel to some extent the train has already left, and I'm not sure how it can be reversed," Mr. Marx said. "The layoff has had a profound effect on me. It's difficult walking away from something you've been doing for 27 years. There used to be two pages of tech jobs in the classified section. Now there's maybe one column." 
Many American technology workers whose jobs have not been moved offshore say that they are being offered lower salaries than in the past. "It's a total deflation period" for information technology workers, said John C. McCarthy, a Forrester Research group director who led the firm's offshoring study. Many technology workers "can expect to make at least 20 percent less than they did during the boom," he said.
Many experts are stressing that technology workers must upgrade their skills and are advising them to shift their sights to sectors that are still hiring.
Wireless technology, broadband and security technology are all growing fields, according to John Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an international outplacement consulting firm. Mr. Challenger also recommends that tech workers consider looking into government and military technology, health care and pharmaceuticals. 
"When the dot-com bubble burst it was the end of skyrocketing I.T. salaries," Mr. Challenger said. "It's important for I.T. workers to make sure their skills are not outdated."
The proponents of offshoring see it as an effective solution to rapidly rising costs. An August report by the McKinsey Global Institute, a research group that is part of McKinsey & Company, called offshoring a win-win situation for the global economy and asserted that it allowed American companies to not only reduce their costs but also reap larger profits by investing in new businesses at home.
That study said that an Indian software developer could make as little as $6 an hour, compared with $60 an hour for an American. 
Atul Vashistha, the chief executive of neoIT, a California-based company that specializes in advising companies on moving work overseas, and whose clients include Siemens and Lucent Technologies, said that most of the jobs being outsourced overseas are "lower end" positions in data processing and programming.
But Marcus Courtney, president of the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, a union affiliated with the Communications Workers of America, said high-level white-collar workers were just as endangered as anyone else.
"Any job can be exported, irrespective of skills," he said. "This goes beyond training and education. Employees shouldn't snow themselves into believing that if they have an advanced certification or an M.B.A., their job can't be sent overseas."
Mr. Courtney's organization opposes the growing offshoring tide by trying to promote public awareness and political action. He said that his group was fighting for legislation like the bill being considered in the New Jersey Legislature that would allow only United States citizens to work on certain state contracts.
But Joseph Stubblebine, the chief executive of JobCircle.com, an online job board geared to technology professionals in the Northeast, said tech workers should focus on learning in-demand skills like Java and Linux programming. Mr. Stubblebine said that well-rounded tech workers who could strike a balance between business, social and technology skills would best survive the upheaval.
"Tech folks that understand what a business needs will survive," he said. "Someone who just writes codes and sits in the corner will not."
Bill Beck, a 50-year-old unemployed programmer, has developed new skills but also said he had a contingency plan. Mr. Beck, a native of Tyrone, Ga., has been laid off twice since 2001, but he has taken courses in HTML and advanced Java.
Although he is reluctant to give up on a career that has lasted 20 years, he recently enrolled in a six-week class in real estate appraisal, a field he plans to enter if he cannot find work in technology. He said that his former employer began outsourcing programming jobs to India several years ago.
Mr. Beck contemplated a move for a job in Pennsylvania but learned that the position would pay 40 percent less than his previous salary.
Mark Higby of Granby, Conn., said he planned to upgrade his credentials. He is looking into certification programs in security technology and is considering studying for an M.B.A.
While he does not attribute the loss of his position in infrastructure maintenance and design last year to work contracted overseas, he said he did believe that offshoring had made his job search tougher. After his layoff, Mr. Higby said, he was forced to declare bankruptcy so he could retain his home for his wife and 2-year-old son.
After nine months of looking for work, Mr. Higby landed a part-time consulting job with Pepperidge Farm and recently interviewed for a full-time technology position in Rhode Island. His wife started working part time at Starbucks so that the family could afford health insurance.
But Mr. Higby, 49, does not express bitterness about offshoring. "It's all about being as competitive as you can be," he said. "I'm not going to get depressed. I'm not going to give up. I want to be a big-picture guy. I don't want to go after jobs that are moving offshore, I don't want to chase after something that's running away." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ed Marx lost his programming job last year after his employer sent the work overseas. (Photo by Jill C. Becker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Health Insurance For All Americans? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "The Universal Cure" (Op-Ed, Nov. 18), Ezekiel J. Emanuel and Victor R. Fuchs do not note one important disadvantage of employer-based health insurance: its failure to provide adequate preventive coverage (which can save lives and costs), especially to workers in high-turnover service-sector jobs. 
Employers are reluctant to pay since a worker's future employer would reap the benefits. 
 In the Netherlands, which has universal, individual-based health insurance without employer involvement, it is not unusual for people to be enrolled for 20 years or more with the same insurer, providing ample incentive for provision of preventive benefits.

WARREN GREENBERG
Washington, Nov. 18, 2003

The writer is a professor of health economics at George Washington University.

HEADLINE: Schenectady Hits a New Low, And There's No Edison in Sight 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE YORK

 BODY:
Schenectady -- once so lively that Thomas Edison moved a company there and it grew into General Electric -- has experienced such a downhill slide that on Thursday, Moody's Investors Service gave the city the lowest credit rating of any municipality in New York State. 
 "It's probably about a clear a signal as anyone could receive that the city has to do something dramatic," the departing mayor, Albert P. Jurczynski, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Jurczynski chose not to run for re-election after facing much criticism for the city's economic woes. 
 According to the report by Moody's, however, it is clear that no one person is to blame. 
Like many older cities around the country, Schenectady has experienced a huge loss of manufacturing jobs. General Electric, its main employer, once had 40,000 people on the payroll, compared with about 8,000 today. 
"Schenectady was never prepared for that," said the director of communications for the Chamber of Commerce, Marc DeNofio. "The city had a tough time," he said. "It just wasn't competitive. No other big company was ever solicited." 
Perhaps even more damaging is the population decrease in Schenectady, which lies 18 miles northwest of Albany. It has lost 30,000 people since 1950. In the 2000 census, the population stood at 61,821, a 33 percent decline over 50 years. 
Attempts to fix Schenectady's problems have ranged from raising property taxes by 25 percent in 2003 to urging Guyanese immigrants to relocate from Queens. Mr. Jurczynski promoted his community as a place in which they could experience urban living, but in a much larger house than they could buy in the New York City region. 
"It's one of the best things Schenectady has going for it," said Mr. Jurczynski of his recruitment program, which he credits with attracting as many as 5,000 Guyanese. "They have a similar work ethic of my Polish grandparents, and they're buying up older homes and renovating them." 
But the programs have not done enough, according to Moody's. "They have deteriorating financial conditions," said Edith Behr, a vice president and senior analyst. 
In Schenectady's 2004 budget, which includes a tax increase of 7.8 percent, city officials did not include police overtime and wage increases for two unions negotiating with the city, leaving analysts convinced that the municipality's projected deficit of $250,000 would balloon.
One of the city's parking garages poses a major problem, having lost money each year since 2000, resulting in a deficit of more than $2.5 million, according to Moody's report. 
Officials are negotiating the garage's sale to Metroplex, the Schenectady County-sponsored economic development agency, but talks have not dealt with that deficit, and if the city has to bear that debt and other losses, the municipality will see an overall deficit of about $4 million, according to the Moody's report. 
Because of those factors, Moody's lowered Schenectady's bond rating to Ba2 from Ba1, making it and Cicero, a town 10 miles north of Syracuse, the lowest-rated of 364 rated municipalities in the state. 
In 1996, Mayor Jurczynski suggested that the city abolish itself and consolidate services with Schenectady County. The reaction was so negative, though, that he said he felt like he "ran into a buzz saw." 
But now that he is leaving and the Moody's report is dismal, Mr. Jurczynski said he hoped the new administration would reconsider at least a version of his proposal. 
Meanwhile, he said, Schenectady is rebuilding its downtown and working with several organizations that help regions recruit high-tech firms. 
That's welcome news to the Chamber of Commerce. "Hopefully, we're going to be innovators again," Mr. DeNofio said. "We've hit rock bottom. We can't go any lower, so the only way to go is up. It's not going to happen tomorrow, but in 10 years from now, hopefully Schenectady will be back on the map."

HEADLINE: Spoiling (Carefully) for a Fight 

BYLINE:  By Matt Bai; Matt Bai, a contributing writer, will be covering the 2004 campaign for the magazine.

 BODY:
In a green-and-beige hotel suite overlooking the Detroit River, John Edwards sits cross-legged, his back to the bleak Canadian vista, absently bouncing his stockinged foot. The day started so inspiringly, with Edwards, the North Carolina senator and presidential candidate, bounding up to the pulpits of two African-American churches and energizing crowds who'd never heard of him. ("The Lord is in this place!" he shouted, to elated calls of "Yes, sir!") But now, a few hours later, here he is in Room 661 of the Renaissance Center Marriott, surrounded by a circle of half a dozen senior aides who are prepping him for tonight's Democratic debate. Nodding impatiently as he shifts in his chair, Edwards has the look of a man whose date has dragged him to a foreign film.
 David Ginsberg, Edwards's communications director, tells him that the organizers of the debate, the Congressional Black Caucus and Fox News, have notified them that there won't be a discussion on foreign policy. This is good news for a campaign staked on domestic issues, but Edwards shakes his head warily. "They'll never get through this thing without talking about Iraq," he says. 
In the five previous debates, Edwards's strategy has been to avoid the verbal darts the other candidates have been aiming at one another. Instead of garnering headlines with one-liners, Edwards has been hoping to reach the voters watching at home with talk of his "Real Solutions for America" plan, a booklet full of policy proposals. The strategy isn't working out so well. Current polls have him close to the back of the pack, jockeying for position with Al Sharpton. 
Ginsberg and other aides have recently begun prodding Edwards to be more aggressive, to make his presence felt, to mix it up in some of the testier exchanges. "We all agree that you did really well with the last debate, getting engaged in the fight," Ginsberg says. 
"And we've seen, in the last two weeks, Dean lumping his opponents all together and attacking them as Washington insiders," Ginsberg continues. "You're not from Washington."
Edwards sits up. "This is something I want to know," he says. "How long has Dean been in politics?" Edwards himself has been in public life for only five years, and he can't quite understand how Dean has managed to cast him as just another Washington lifer.
"Since 1986, right?" Ginsberg says, looking around. 
Christina Reynolds, Edwards's research director, begins typing away on her laptop.
"What did he do before that?" Edwards asks. "Just practiced medicine? For how long? And where? At a hospital?"
Reynolds looks up from her computer. "Exactly 20 years, that's how long he's been in politics, Senator." Edwards nods thoughtfully. 
The advisers point out some other weak spots. Dick Gephardt has been linking Dean to Newt Gingrich because Dean once spoke in favor of raising the retirement age for entitlements. Perhaps Edwards should join in. "That's absurd," Edwards says dismissively. "No one believes he's like Gingrich. I think we just need to say that he wanted to limit the cost of Medicare, which is exactly what the Republicans wanted to do."
Then there is Wesley Clark's war position; he has been criticized for a lack of clarity. Edwards shakes his head. "I don't think I want to be in that," he says. "I just don't really want to go there."
Edwards seems chiefly concerned with how best to talk about his plan for the economy. On one hand, he has a series of proposals to create jobs. But he also likes to rail against the growing tax burden on working families.
"I just need to know whether you would rather have me hit jobs or work force," he tells the group. "Because it's very hard to do both in 60 seconds."
Edwards and his wife, Elizabeth, are partial to the jobs argument. His aides are more invested in the workers-versus-the-wealthy message -- which leaves Edwards groping for a clear answer. 
Robert Gordon, a young policy expert with an almost freakish recall of arcane data on every conceivable subject, suggests that Edwards talk about wage-earners first. "If you have enough time left, you could still talk about jobs," he says.
"There's just not enough time," Edwardsreplies. "Sixty seconds is just not very much." He sighs dejectedly and rubs his head. "What would you say about prescription drugs?" he asks. "I mean, if I had three minutes, I could crush it. But what can I say in 60 seconds?"
I have embedded myself, to use the latest Washington lingo, with Edwards's debate team because I want to know if presidential debates like this one, packed with so many candidates and coming so early in the primary season, are anything more than a pointless ritual. The Detroit showdown is, remarkably, the sixth full-scale debate among the Democratic hopefuls this year. While the debates do have the value of articulating a broad Democratic critique of the president's agenda, the campaign staffs have largely come to see them as black holes in the schedule, sucking candidates away from their chosen battlegrounds. The viewing audiences, meanwhile, have dwindled to the point at which, if this were some new reality series, it would have been canceled midseason.
I'm also wondering whether a guy like John Edwards can do what lesser-known candidates have traditionally done, which is to use the debates to establish his relevance to the race. Long touted as a Southern successor to Bill Clinton, Edwards has a trial lawyer's courtly eloquence, the most coherent set of policy proposals in the field and -- hands down -- the best hair in politics. But unlike the voluble Sharpton or the squarish Joe Lieberman, Edwards has struggled to define himself with voters.
It's not for lack of trying; perhaps because he looks so polished, Edwards spends much of his time repeating, at a rate of about once every 40 heartbeats, that he grew up in a tiny town and that his father worked in a mill. It's true, but it also sounds canned and thus has the effect of distancing him from the very working-class ideal he's trying to embrace. 
The Detroit debate doesn't open auspiciously. As Edwards suspected, the first round of questioning is all about Iraq. The voices of the candidates bounce off the ornate walls of the historic Fox Theater and make their way up to the battered old dressing room above the stage where the Edwards team watches the live feed on TV. "They always do this," Ginsberg complains, referring to the organizers. "They just lied. They said there was no foreign-policy section. We had three conference calls with them."
The Iraq grilling goes on for a full 45 minutes. "John's going to kill us," Ginsberg says, slumping in his chair.
Edwards gets only five questions all night, which he answers adequately -- and forgettably. His final question comes in a round in which Gwen Ifill, the PBS reporter, is asking all of the candidates about their perceived weaknesses. "The expectations for you were so high in the beginning that you were on the cover of Newsweek magazine," Ifill says. (It isn't true, though Edwards might wish it were.) "What happened?"
There are low groans in the dressing room.
"First of all, nothing happened," Edwards says, unhelpfully. He is the fourth candidate to answer in this round, and yet he seems a little taken aback by the question. "I'm doing great in Iowa, moving up in New Hampshire, got a double-digit lead in the state of South Carolina. I'm very proud of what's happening in my campaign." He gets hold of the wheel and steers himself onto the familiar tracks of his stump speech. "I am fighting for, in this campaign, the very people that I grew up with," he says, "people like my father, who worked in a mill all his life." 
"What a bunch of silly questions," Ginsberg says, looking away from the TV.
After the debate, Edwards and most of the other candidates are hustled into what's known as "Spin Alley." It's one of the stranger scenes in American politics: aides hold up placards that say "Edwards" or "Dean," and reporters and cameramen swarm like wasps around whichever candidate interests them most. The whole thing resembles a kind of adolescent playground nightmare, with all the cool kids getting chosen while the less coordinated players wait awkwardly under their placards. At one debate this fall, aides to Representative Dennis Kucinich literally grabbed wandering reporters and implored them to come interview their boss.
Several reporters surround Edwards. There are more questions about why he isn't winning the race, but none on his policies.
The debate wasn't a total loss, Gordon tells me hopefully as we leave the theater. "We got attacked," he says, "and we got named a few times."
More than anything else, presidential debates are remembered for specific moments. George H.W. Bush checking his watch. Al Gore sighing repeatedly. Ronald Reagan, in a primary debate, scolding, "I paid for this microphone!" (Lou Cannon, a Reagan biographer, wrote that Reagan tended to ignore policy questions in debate prep, preferring to practice one-liners.) Such moments give narrative to personalities; they enable us to understand, in a concrete way, what it is we like or disdain about a candidate. They also generate headlines. It's not the 10 things you say in a debate that matter; it's the one that leads the evening news and the next day's paper. 
The general consensus this fall is that there are too many candidates and too many debates, and that they sound about as spontaneous as a George Foreman infomercial.
"They're not debates," Paul Begala, one of the party's leading debate strategists, said. "You have a collection of people with their canned lines, some of them good and some of them not good, and they just recite them in random order. In fact, maybe we should just do that. 'Senator Kerry, could you please give us your line on Medicare?"'
Begala said the best way to fix this mess would be to somehow winnow the field, giving a smaller number of candidates more time to answer each question. When I repeated this suggestion to Sharpton, who has clearly been the most agile debater thus far, he scoffed. "What are we really talking about?" he asked. "A minute or two? It's not like some of them were on the verge of brilliance and then somebody cut them off!"
I asked Sharpton to rate the debating skills of his rivals. Gephardt and Kucinich show the most passion, Sharpton said, while Lieberman is the most sure of his convictions. "He don't care if they heckle or boo, that's who he is. I respect it." Dean, he said, "can come off as arrogant or even mean-spirited." Sharpton likened Kerry to a prizefighter who scores well in every round but never lands the knockout punch.
I asked him about Edwards. "He suffers from his handlers maybe building something up that he couldn't live up to," Sharpton said, sympathetically. "I don't blame him for that. I think sometimes you can be overpromoted, and it can hurt you in the end."
Some Democratic insiders, including at least one friend of the senator's, suggested to me that Edwards might have something to gain by remaining tepid. The 50-year-old candidate, who has already said that he will give up his Senate seat, would be a natural pick for vice president should he lose the nomination, and his chances will be better if he doesn't savage the eventual nominee.
Then again, if Edwards still has any chance of winning the nomination, it rests in his ability to differentiate himself as a fighting Southerner. The best possibility for Edwards goes like this: Dean beats Kerry and Gephardt in Iowa and New Hampshire, and Edwards takes South Carolina, setting up a showdown between Dean and Edwards as they head into the remaining Southern primaries. If that's the plan, Edwards needs to convince Southern voters that Dean isn't the friend of disadvantaged blacks and white rural men that he purports to be. And that means that at some point, Edwards may have to pick a fight. 
He gets his chance a few days later, when Dean tells The Des Moines Register that he wants to be "the candidate for guys with Confederate flags in their pickup trucks." The comment draws angry rebukes from Sharpton and other candidates, who say it's racially insensitive. Edwards is furious for a different reason: he thinks Dean, the New Englander, doesn't understand that most Southerners don't drive trucks with Confederate flags. For Edwards, Dean epitomizes the kind of Northern elitist who insists on seeing the South as it used to be, not as it is.
On the morning of the next debate, a "Rock the Vote" youth event at Faneuil Hall in Boston, the staff gathers in Edwards's Washington home to discuss this new opportunity at length. Edwards agrees to raise the issue, but he's reluctant to turn it into a more personal confrontation. Even after his plane lands in Boston, he tells his aides, "I don't want this to be about Howard Dean."
It takes only three questions for a black audience member to confront Dean about his remark. Seemingly stunned by the question, Dean digs in, becoming flustered and defensive. Behind his podium, Edwards smolders, his resentments about class and region building. Edwards sees his opening, and like any good cross-examiner, he won't let it pass.
"Let me bring in Senator Edwards with his comments," says CNN's Anderson Cooper, the moderator.
"Well, let me say, first of all, unless I missed something, Governor Dean still has not said he was wrong," Edwards begins. "Were you wrong, Howard? Were you wrong to say that?"
Dean looks as if a beam has just broken loose from the ceiling and landed at his feet. "No, I wasn't, John Edwards," he replies, and he defends his statement yet again. As Dean struggles, Edwards takes a few menacing steps toward him, and then he strides onto center stage.
"Let me tell you," Edwards seethes. "The last thing we need in the South is somebody like you coming down and telling us what we need to do. That's the last thing in the world we need in the South." Surprisingly, the Boston crowd bursts into cheers. 
He pivots the issue expertly back toward the youthful audience, just as he and his aides discussed in his living room. "One of the problems that we have with young people today is people talk down to you," Edwards says in his best lawyer's drawl, index fingers jabbing the air. "Exactly the same thing happens with people from the South. I have seen it. I have grown up with it. I'm here to tell you it is wrong. It is condescending. And the only way that we as a party are going to win the White House back is to reach out to everybody and treat them with the dignity and respect that they're entitled to."
The applause is heartfelt. "He got just plain mad!" Ginsberg says in the hotel suite, grinning. 
Reynolds looks up from her laptop. "He was awesome!" she says. "That's the best I've ever seen him."
At the commercial break, Jano Cabrera, Lieberman's spokesman, wanders into the Edwards suite and swipes some M&M's. "That was great, by theway," he says. "That was un-be-liev-able."
In Spin Alley this time, the reporters are crowded three deep around Edwards. Ginsberg stands nearby, lost in his BlackBerry. The Associated Press is moving an article on the debate, and Edwards is quoted in the second paragraph. 
Edwards is hustled onto the set of a live radio show. "When you get the stage, you make a hell of an impression, Senator," the host says admiringly. Edwards stays on long enough to reprise his condemnation of Dean and talk about his love for Bruce Springsteen -- the kind of personal detail reporters hadn't been asking about much before tonight. Then he steps out into the plaza at Quincy Market, striding through the raw ocean air with a new, purposeful swagger. He slaps a cop on the shoulder and shakes the hand of a sound-truck engineer.
I mention to his press secretary, Jennifer Palmieri, that he seems happy.
"Oh, yeah, he's happy," she says. "You do get your moment. You have to wait sometimes, but you do get it."
There's a buzz on board the "Real Solutions Express," Edwards's state-of-the-art campaign bus, as it chugs up Route 95 in New Hampshire the day after the Boston debate. This may be the most encouraging day Edwards has had as a candidate. He's prominently quoted in all the national papers, and he's the subject of a rare laudatory column in The Boston Globe. Dean finally apologizes publicly, which seems to give Edwards the familiar satisfaction of a jury verdict.
Edwards and his wife sit eating sandwiches at a cozy little booth at the front of the bus. I slide in next to Elizabeth and ask the senator what made him suddenly go on the attack.
"It really wasn't very planned," he says. "I think it's important for people to see that when it matters, you will be as tough as you need to be. And that's why I did it."
Edwards arrives at a Concord vocational school to give a major policy speech on his ideas to shore up family savings. It is the kind of issue he says he believes should dominate the campaign, and yet, before he utters a word from his prepared text, he chooses to deliver a short statement rehashing his position on Dean's remark. 
It is a nod to reality. He knows this moment will be part of tonight's news lead, and even if it isn't the John Edwards story he'd most like the voters to see, at least he'll be news for another day. He takes questions from reporters after the speech. None of them concern predatory lending or tax credits or anything else in "Real Solutions for America." They're all about Dean.
Bathed in camera lights and surrounded by microphones, Edwards seems not to mind. Sixty seconds, he is finding, can last a lot longer than you might think.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
What Partisans Embrace, Politicians Fear

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IN one corner are the social conservatives with their fists raised against gay marriage, girded for a new battle in the cultural wars. "Politicians don't want to face it, but they're going to have to," warned Sandy Rios, the president of Concerned Women for America, a Christian group. "It's going to be used by groups like ours as a litmus test."
 In the other corner are gays, lesbians and their supporters, fists aimed at those who would press for a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage. "They'd better think long and hard before they push this, because they're going to have a war on their hands," said Tony Kushner, the playwright, who won a Pulitzer Prize for "Angels in America." "A real movement for an amendment will electrify this community and bring about an entire new generation of dissent and civil disobedience." 
 In the middle of the ring are President Bush and the Democratic candidates for president, caught ever more uncomfortably between the edges of their parties. Last week's ruling by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court allowing gay marriage in the state incited both sides of an angry debate that, for better or worse, may well become a pivotal part of the 2004 campaign. 
For many candidates, the ruling was bad news. Culture wars tend to drown out what the parties consider election priorities. Mr. Bush wants to run on the economy and national security, the Democrats against Mr. Bush's policies in Iraq. Cultural wars can be personal and bloody. In any case, nobody wants to run on gay marriage -- and not only because nobody knows how the issue will play in a campaign. 
For now, though half of the nation supports gay civil unions, some 60 percent of Americans oppose gay marriage. Most of the Democratic presidential candidates also oppose gay marriage, but they all support extending legal benefits to domestic partners of gays, and some explicitly support same-sex civil unions. Mr. Bush has not publicly said whether he supports same-sex unions, but in the 2000 presidential campaign he said that as governor of Texas he would not support them.
"It's front and center, and it's a terribly difficult issue for everybody on both sides," said Charles Francis, a Bush family friend and the co-chairman of the Republican Unity Coalition, an influential gay-straight political alliance.
The political danger for the president, Mr. Francis argued, was that he risked looking intolerant by siding too strongly with his conservative supporters. For now, Mr. Bush has taken a cautious course: he opposes gay marriage, like the vast majority of Republicans (75 percent, according to a poll conducted in October by the Pew Research Center) but he has not yet endorsed a constitutional amendment to ban it.
"We're hopeful that the campaign will steer clear of this amendment," Mr. Francis said. "It's an issue of tone. It's the issue of writing discrimination into the founding document. Also it's so distracting from the real priorities of the campaign, which are his leadership, the war in Iraq and the economy."
But Mr. Bush's most conservative supporters vow they will pressure him to back a constitutional amendment, and threaten consequences if he does not do as they wish. "If he doesn't take leadership, he's not going to have the support that he needs," Ms. Rios said. "I'm not saying he won't be re-elected, but I'm saying he's running a risk."
Former Vice President Dan Quayle, who launched his own culture war in 1992 when he criticized the television show "Murphy Brown" for exalting single motherhood, said that Republicans should campaign against gay marriage as "another attack on the institution of marriage" and tell voters that "marriage is the only way to bring children into this world." If he was running himself, Mr. Quayle said, "that's the way I would approach it."
The Democratic candidates may face bigger problems. While Mr. Bush's opposition to gay marriage keeps him in step with three-quarters of Republicans, the Democratic candidates opposed to gay marriage find themselves in step with only half of their voters. (The Pew poll found that 52 percent of Democrats opposed gay marriage.) In other words, the Democrats in favor of gay marriage -- 39 percent, according to Pew -- could see their party's presidential candidates as running scared on the issue.
Mr. Kushner is one of them. "The Democrats have done an appallingly bad job of running around in circles on this," he said. "I think you could get up and say, 'Listen: there's the marriage you have in church, and there's the marriage you have in City Hall with a license, and those laws should govern all people who get married. It has nothing to do with God.' "
BUT will Mr. Kushner's feelings of alienation result in Democrats not voting for Democrats? In other words, how much will the issue actually move votes? Political commentators say the issue is too new to voters to tell.
"It's not like gun control, when you can go back to 1972 and 1996 and say, 'See, this is who votes on this issue,' " said Grover G. Norquist, the president of Americans for Tax Reform, a conservative group. "When people talk about unemployment, they have a sense of how this affects votes. On a new issue, people can tell you their prejudices. They can extrapolate from other issues, but elected officials don't know.
"If Teddy Kennedy thought this was a huge winner issue for him, he'd be on TV saying we must talk about this from now to November. If Sam Brownback thought this was a huge issue, he'd be out holding press conferences saying the Democrats are toast. But neither team is jumping out."
In fact, though Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, reacted to the Massachusetts ruling with only a brief supportive statement issued by his office, Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, is expected to sponsor the legislation for a constitutional amendment in the Senate. Representative Marilyn Musgrave, Republican of Colorado, has already introduced a constitutional amendment in the House.
"This is something that people get," Ms. Musgrave said. "Much of what goes on on the Hill is esoteric to the average person out there, but they read one sentence and they understand what's going on with this."
But in a sign that even some conservatives are concerned about alienating moderates, Representative Tom Delay of Texas, the Republican majority leader, said that a constitutional amendment would be a last resort. "Amending the constitution is never our best recourse," said Stuart Roy, Mr. Delay's spokesman.
For now, the presidential candidates on each side seem to be waiting for the other guy to strike first. "If gay activists try to use the Massachusetts decision to nationalize government sanction of gay marriage," said Ed Gillespie, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, "there's no way it doesn't become an issue."
But as for whether there was a need for a constitutional amendment, Mr. Gillespie would not say yes. He carefully repeated the White House formulation, saying "we will support whatever policy is necessary."
As Mr. Norquist concluded, "Somebody with focus groups is going to make a lot of money figuring out where all this comes down."
